reviewText:
Been playing this for about an hour and a half and I have to say I'm really impressed. Her Story is a throwback to the old FMV games that were made back in the 90s, only this time it isn't â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, it's actually surprisingly great. The purpose is to try and find out - by going through archive footage of numerous police interviews with a woman that took place two decades earlier - what happened to her missing husband. This is done through keyword searching, so it's best to play this with a pen and paper handy as a video will throw up another clue or word that could be vital in your investigation.

As an exercise in non-linear storytelling Her Story is incredibly well written and a huge amount of thought has clearly gone into not just the dialogue and plotting, but also into the length of the videos. Some of them can be as short as 3-4 seconds and at first viewing seem absolutely redundant. As you delve further into the archives, however, they can take on a whole new meaning. The actress who plays the subject of these interviews deserves huge credit for her work here, her performance only truly reveals its brilliance the further you progress and you begin to notice her intonation, mannerisms and overall demeanour are all absolutely perfect.

If you're after something truly different, interesting and original then look no further. Her Story is a little gem of a game. Recommended.

reviewText:
In a medium where evolution is typically measured in polygons and development costs, itâ€™s fitting that possibly the most innovative game of 2015 would be something so unassuming.

Her Story places you in front of a computer monitor circa 1994, and lets you loose to dig through hundreds of police videos revolving around a single woman and a very peculiar case. You are told nothing other than how to operate the software needed to access these videos, and then left alone to attempt to crawl through the archive.

Her Story doesnâ€™t lend itself well to trailers or quick descriptions. It isnâ€™t flashy nor does it immediately show its brilliance, but that subtlety is an integral part of why it manages to do so much with so little. The low rent aesthetic provides a texture â€“ aged video footage, a faux 90â€™s desktop, dated clothing â€“ and then drapes it over the narrative to fully pull you back in time as you attempt to put the pieces of the mystery together.

How Her Story looks though, or even what it has to say to a degree, isnâ€™t why itâ€™s so fascinating. To be sure developer Sam Barlow does an incredible job setting the tone through familiar, nostalgic imagery, smartly opting to omit authenticity where it isnâ€™t needed while still nailing the feel of the 90â€™s. Itâ€™s all remarkably well-considered, but where Her Story pushes games forward is in how it approaches narrative as nonlinear and undefined.

Because of the limitations of your in game computer, you can only ever access five videos at once, using the search box to scrub through video transcripts for keywords. What this means in practice is you have to search out every bit of the narrative for yourself, being locked out of broad searches so as to require you to actually think like a detective and put the puzzle pieces together for yourself. Her Story is the first game Iâ€™ve played where I actually felt as if I was the one solving the case, following a trail of breadcrumbs I had to seek out and which often didnâ€™t lead in a straight line from beginning to end, requiring I go back and dig up old clues to find a new lead.

I became exceptionally diligent in making sure to check up on every name, every address; any random detail that had the potential to lead me to a breakthrough. Her Story demands a lot from the player in order to see and understand everything hidden inside it, but the depth of its narrative and the intricacy in which itâ€™s woven together rewards those who put more time into learning its secrets. Her Story puts a lot of trust in the player to follow through on their end of the bargain and not cheat their way to a resolution, but it backs this up with such an engaging plot (delivered entirely through a masterful, demanding performance by Viva Seifert) that anyone who doesnâ€™t give it the attention it deserves is only cheating themselves in the end.

Her Story doesnâ€™t look like much, nor is it easy to do it justice through words alone, but itâ€™s nevertheless a game thatâ€™s going to be talked about for years by anyone who takes the time to look below the surface. It breaks entirely new ground for narratives in games, and is perhaps the biggest proof that FMV has a place in games beyond basic comedy. Itâ€™s a very difficult game to talk about in any capacity without ruining what makes it so great, but it all the same demands discussing and is a game I see creating ripples through the industry for a very long time to come.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
Her Story is a brilliant FMV (full motion video) detective/thriller game, developed by Sam Barlow. This is the creator of silent hill shattered memories and aisle.

You watch interviews filmed in 1994 between a police detective and a woman. Her husband was murdered and it's up to you to figure out what happend and how. Explore the police database for videos and puzzle the story together.

I recommend that you play the game in window mode and have your computer notepad ready, because you are most likely going to write down a bunch of keywords. If you wanna play it in fullscreen you can also have pen & paper nearby.

Every time you come across a keyword that the woman says, like a name or a place, you use that as a search term to find more video clues.

In a FMV game like this it is of course important to have talented actors/actresses to make the story believable. Her story only have 1  actress and her name is Viva Seifert. She does a great job performing in over 200 videos here.

Some people will absolutely make the argument that this is not a game". I don't really care what you think it is
date: it's a great experience nonetheless. I love detective games
recommended: and this one is as real as it gets.\n\nOnce you have completed the game there's even some secret achievement
hoursPlayed: a minigame and some hidden videos to explore. It's not a very long game
voteText: you can compete it within 2-4 hours
helpfulPercent: but if you wanna go for all the achievements and see every video you will have a few hours more.\n\nI value the content rather then the lenght of a game
votesHelpful: I actually think its refreshing to play a short game that I can complete in one sitting sometimes. I bought Her Story on sale cheap
votesTotal: and it was easily worth the money. I would have no problem even paying full price for this game
votesFunny: it's really that good in my opinion.\n\nWhen you play a lot of games like I do
commentsCount: It's rare to find something so different as Her Story. I'm looking forward to similar games in the future. I recommend this game to basically everyone
column16: especially those into thriller/crime/FMV/detective games."

reviewText: Her Story consists entirely of entering key word searches into a database and watching short video clips (often < 30 seconds). The mystery" exists only because of the arbitrary restriction imposed by the database--you have to find clips by searching rather than simply browsing them in chronological order.  Eventually the game will cue you when it feels you have watched enough of the clips to grasp the entire story. For me this was after a little more than an hour
date: though I got the gist of the story after about 30 minutes or so.\n\nThis is not a detective game
recommended: it's an exercise in fractured narrative.  I'm not sure why so many reviewers have pointed out a need for pen and paper
hoursPlayed: it makes as much sense as watching something like Eternal Sunshine with pen and paper. Narrative games are fine

reviewText:
My wife and I played this game together. She's not a gamer in any way, shape or form, but she loves mysteries and stories, so she was game, and we both enjoyed the time immensely.

Some tips below, but no spoilers. BE SURE to read number (1) if you plan to buy the game.

1. Be very very careful in the Settings" box. There's a button in there that says"Delete Session Data".  You might *think* like I did that this will clear out the clips you've added to your "user session" with the "Add to Session" button that shows up on each clip
date: but it does much more. It resets your entire game. With no warning! Ugh. Don't press this button unless you really want the equivalent of "New Game" with no opportunity to restore your progress. You lose all tags you've added to videos
recommended:
and the state of each video goes back to unwatched.

2. I know of no way to remove clips from the "user session" section once they've been added.

3. When you search
hoursPlayed: the videos are returned in chronological order. But when you "add to session" they are stored in the order you added them
voteText: and you can't rearrange them later. This fact
helpfulPercent: coupled with (2) makes the "add to session" useful only if you want to be lured eventually to the button of death that I describe in (1). Really bad oversight on the part of the developer
votesHelpful: but the story makes up for it
votesTotal: and I'm still overwhelmingly positive about the overall game experience because the story is so good.\n\n4. The DB Checker is pretty helpful - have a look at it early and you might figure out a way to tag your videos so that later
votesFunny: once you've uncovered most of them
commentsCount: you can watch them in chronological order. My system made use of (3) and made for an enjoyable replay of all the videos that we'd uncovered. I put post-it notes on my screen bordering the DB checker so I could more easily track rows and columns in order to tag for later chronological viewing.\n\n5. Your search results won't show all matches
column16: but rather only the first five. If there are more
column17: there will be messaging below the search results saying that. I didn't notice this for quite awhile. By adding more search terms you can narrow the results and possibly see other videos beyond the first five
column18: if that makes sense.\n\n6. There's a message in the DB checker that makes it sound like more videos are available somewhere else ("one volume missing.") This had me intrigued for the longest time until I reread the readme files (I think) and realized that the other volume probably contained footage of the interviewering constables and their questions. That's my theory anyhow. I never did find any other "volume"
column19: and the walkthrough I watched later didn't mention anything about it.\n\nEnjoy!"

reviewText:
I am really torn with this game. At first it was super exciting until I realised how easy it was and then it was over. I was expecting more simulation, much more challenge than what I got and felt kinda ripped off.
I'm sure many people will enjoy it, but just be aware that you might find it far too easy.

There are plenty of good points to this game however:

The acting was very well done, there is one pretty big plot twist in there which I think the actress did a superb job with.
The story itself, once you piece it together, is clever.

I found a bug in it, such as sometimes playing a video clip, there would be no audio until I closed it and re-opened it. This was annoying, but not game breaking in the slightest.

If you, like myself, are a superb googler, you'll find yourself using keywords that perhaps some people wouldn't think of using, and then basically figure out the entire story in several minutes. This is the reason for the thumbs down. I believe it could have been great, but there just needed to be a little more meat in the pie.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

A story worth uncovering
Her Story - the new game from Sam Barlow creator of Silent Hill Shattered Memories - is bound to cause many discussion threads to spring up around the interwebz regarding its serpentine plot that is like climbing a hill with switchbacks criss-crossing all over it. It is safe to say at this point that if you plan on picking up Her Story, I would highly suggest you avoid any discussion or forums threads where the game could possibly end up being discussed because there is a good chance you will probably end up spoiling it for yourself. If you are an armchair detective who relishes unraveling crime stories such as this one then you have been suitably warned!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=483899193
Her Story opens in the English town of Portsmouth and takes place entirely on a desktop computer as you trawl through a series of video interviews pertaining to a crime that was committed many years before. Her Story gives you very little to work with initially as you are given no reason whatsoever as to who you are and why you are interrogating these archives. Booting into the game for the first time the first clue that the game supplies you with is the keyword Murder" which upon being entered into the archive database search reveals a series of short clips pertaining to the murder of a missing man named Simon Smith and the woman being interrogated
date:
who we soon find out is the murdered mans wife.

What starts out a simple murder mystery to unravel the "why" and if not the "why" then the "who" soon evolves into something far more complex made even more intriguing by the way in which the game hands you bits and pieces of information. Her Story consists of a series of interviews that take place over a period of time that have each been spliced and segregated into smaller clips then cataloged via the use of certain keywords within the archive database so you won't be able to access any of these videos in any sort of chronological order. It is also important to note that the database search will only ever return no more than five video clips so it will often be the case that you will need to refine your search criteria if you want to get the remaining videos returned for viewing. The delivery of this type of fractured narrative actually works in the games favor because it keeps many of Her Story's secrets deeply hidden until you finally have enough information to unlock the one video that ties certain threads together. Since most players won't be using precisely the same set of keywords at exactly the same given time means that most will uncover the secret at the heart of Her Story in a multitude of different ways.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=484286597
By the time I had unraveled the mystery around the death of the local town glazier (which took roughly just over 5 hrs) I was sitting with 7 full A4 pages of keywords that I had used to search with. The last time I did this kind of note taking while playing a game was way back in the late eighties and early nineties where jotting down your thoughts was absolutely necessary if you had any hope of completing the complex adventures of the day pushed out by Sierra or LucasArts.

While Her Story is not what one could easily term a traditional game since there is not much to it other than watching video clips and listening out for clues that will enable further searches and hopefully help you uncover more of the mystery
recommended:
doesn't make it any less entertaining than the running or gunning of it featured in other games. The central mystery here is so strong that you will want to continue pushing forward in an attempt to unravel all the pieces of evidence presented to you via each video clip so that you can finally understand what it is that your are viewing. It also helps that the central character at the heart of this is portrayed convincingly by actress Viva Seifert who is able to switch from manic to depressive at the drop of a hat and effortlessly so.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=483899440
Her Story is unlike any game I have ever played before and honestly made me feel like I was a true detective at the end of it. It's a totally captivating thriller told in a unique way that unravels differently for each that play it and for those of you that often search out for unique and different gaming experiences should be placed right at the top of your wishlist or better yet grabbed from the Steam store right now. I won't be one bit surprised to see this game pop up on the end of the year "best of" lists since it is really that good!

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater"

reviewText:
Her Story is a clever visual novel type game that works by searching old video clips from a police interrogation.

Pros: Well written and super emotional story, lots of mystery, great acting (Viva Seifert is amazing in this!), and a unique game experience.

Cons: No puzzles, easy to 'cheat' your way through by guessing search terms, and kinda short at about three or four hours.

I liked it, I felt it really made me feel for her experiences (no spoilers but there is so much going on with her! Bring tissues!). The game never really ends, it just winds up and you walk away with what you've watched. You create your own ideas of what happened and what kind of person she is. I recommend it if you're into story based games or visual novels. I feel this one is pretty unique and worth the price!

reviewText: As a fan of the film Memento and the game Gone Home, I have a certain bias towards exploration of perception, memory, and non-linear discovery. If you disliked those titles, then chances are you won't appreciate Her Story and you can feel free to disregard the rest of this review.\n\nThe gameplay" consists mainly of using an artificially constrained search system to find video clips from a series of police interviews with a woman (played by British athlete and musician Viva Seifert). The implicit goal is to uncover the story / most of the clips
date: or at least the important ones.\n\nMy initial impression upon realizing that there is no apparent gameplay other than searching for clips by keyword was... "doh
hoursPlayed: the story and the excellent acting by Viva Seifert quickly drew me in and compelled me to find out the rest.\n\nClips are indexed by transcript words
voteText: so you can search either by words or names you hear in clips already seen
helpfulPercent: or by whatever relevant words (or phrases) you can think of. As such
votesHelpful: the video clip archive is a sort of graph connected by the keywords and you can follow the graph edges or blindly attempt to jump to other parts of the graph.\n\nThus what we have here is an interactive
votesTotal: non-linear experience of uncovering a complex
votesFunny: intriguing story (sufficiently qualifying a "game" by my definition). The non-linear aspect refers to the order in which every player might view the clips - this can of course impact the nature and quality of the experience. However
commentsCount: in my opinion
column16: even if the clips were viewed simply in chronological order
column17: the story is still intriguing enough to stand on its own.\n\nThe writing is brilliant
column18: and far more intricate than it might appear at first. Even now

column20: and even after having posted this review (yes

column39:
I recommend actually playing the game first)

Why is Her Story's presentation formula so effective?

Consider a typical
column40: linear story presentation. A good story will captivate you and have you guessing at least sometimes (especially mystery type stories). But presenting the material the way Her Story does
column41: out of order and interactively further accentuates that feeling of engagement

reviewText: This is a weird one.  I adore mystery games, and I thought I'd really enjoy this one.  However, within 10 or so searches, I had figured out the meat of the story, and spent the rest of the time stumbling over 5-10 second long boring videos just for completion's sake, thinking that there was something else I had missed.\n\nIt'll definitely be something you've never experienced before.  Whether that alone is worth it, I'm not sure.  If you catch it on sale for $2 or less, I would say go for it just to try it out.  Just expect a lot of guesswork if you try to 100%.

reviewText:
Ok, I have to review this game after only 1.7h played time. Because this game is a, as the description said, groundbreaking narrative game.

It's maybe a bit spoiler but the main aim of the game is to figure out what her story is. And this only way of achieve this goal is to view all her video clips and put together those narrative jigsaws. However, the challenge is, the only way of selecting your target video clips is via entering searching keywords, which are also the things you shall figure out yourselves. Kindly the developers offered the feature of saving clips, which, however, is not barely enough either. What I have been doing so far is to write down the key incidences, items, characters on a notebook, marked with the clip number, time, and her dress color.

The game provides such a seemingly simple but brilliantly creative way of telling stories. Compared to other detective-like games, it is definitely unqiue and challenging in its own league. Additionally, decent time-related graphic design, extra mini game, beautiful protagonist. I have limited academic background in game studies at this point, but to me this game could be one of the special cases for studies in the narrative games domain and video game storytelling.

RECOMMEND.

reviewText: 'Her Story' is a bit of a throwback to the days of the FMV/live action video adventure games. Those games would play out stories in a linear fashion based on some choices that you made in a choose your own adventure format. Then real life actors would act out the scenes of the story as if watching a television show, or movie. There were actually some well known actors in some of these games even if the stories and writing were incredibly cheesy even for the time. 'Her Story' uses these FMVs with live action video just like these old games do, but it doesn't follow a linear path, nor does it have you choosing the adventure based upon choices. Instead you are able to view all the stories and mysteries of the narrative by hitting points along the time line in a totally random fashion. Making it an interesting and fun way to piece together the mystery.\n\nWhen you first boot up the game you find yourself sitting at on old fashioned police computer's desktop. It appears like you are using something along the lines of Windows 3.1, or Windows 95. It is exactly like using a computer desktop so it feels like using a computer playing this game. On the screen in front of you is a police archives search engine with the word murder" typed into the search box. Upon clicking the "search" button you are presented with several videos of what looks to be an interrogation film from a suspect interview
date: which we find out immediately that it is. This woman is being questioned about a murder. Specifically the murder of her husband. Now where do we go? We have 4-5 videos here we can watch and now we are on our own. We are tasked with investigating this story ourselves to find out everything.\n\nSo how does this work? Just as you found the word "murder" typed into the search box at the start
recommended: you figure out that to find out more about this story you need to search other terms in that box. Based on the videos you watch you pick up clues like names
hoursPlayed: or other meaningful words
voteText: then search them to find more videos. Also
helpfulPercent: like anyone who may be questioning a murder suspect you think of things you would normally ask them as well that you may not have even seen in the videos  such as the location of "the body". Every time you search a term
votesHelpful: or phrase a new set of videos will pop up for you to view. They will be from random dates from the 7 or so interview sessions the woman was brought in for questioning. Each search term and phrase is something that was in the transcript from these interviews. So basically that first search of "murder" popped up every video in which the term was used. The game doesn't make it that easy though to find all the videos. You can't simply search "the" for instance and have 200 videos show up. It limits you to only seeing 5 of however many have that term
votesTotal: or phrase so you must either expand on the phrase to eliminate videos
votesFunny: or search another one to end up with those other videos. You can unlock more options after "finishing" the game to help make finding 100% of the videos easier.\n\nIt sounds simple
commentsCount: and it really is
column16: but the story being woven through the randomly watched videos becomes a very fascinating mystery. Not just about the murder case you seem to be looking for information on
column17: but there are many secrets that are uncovered through clever searching into the archives of these video interviews. Things that first seemed to be quite straight-forward end up being something else entirely. You begin to question the reality of what you have learned thus far
column18: and you start to consider many alternate theories as to what is going on
column19: who this woman is
column20: and what she may be lying about. In fact
column21: most players begin to start scrawling notes on pieces of paper so that they can remember all the things that they want to search for next. They want to find a time line
column22: or even just want to connect some dots
column23: but if this game gets you interested I can almost guarantee you that you will take out a piece of paper and start taking notes while you play.\n\nI very much suggest that you DO NOT read about this game
column24: or its story before playing it. There are many secrets that can be spoiled by doing so
column25: and it will hurt the fun of having those internal debates with yourself that everyone carries to the forums after they have completed the game fully. It is much more fun
column26: and fascinating to try and figure out what you think is going on yourself
column27: and maybe even create your own theories as you play than to have a few handed to you by someone else before you get the chance.\n\nI found 'Her Story' to be a great way to tell a story. Not just the format of giving you small pieces of it at a time through videos
column28: but also due to the disjointed time line you watch it in. Everything is learned in such a way that you will be pulling a handful of jigsaw puzzle pieces out of a hat randomly without having the picture on the box to draw reference from. Only when you have pulled a large portion of these pieces out of the hat can you begin to sort them and put them together in a manner that shows you what the picture is supposed to look like. It's a very cool way to tell a story - and an awesome story at that. However, if you're clever or lucky or both, you will find the crucial bits of info rather quickly. Too quickly in my opinion. Just by coming up with the correct search terms you can easily reveal the great and awesome mistery.

Don't get me wrong. The great and awesome mistery was great and awesome indeed. I just got there waaaaay too fast.

Seriously, one hour and about 20 percent of all clips later, I already pieced the general story together. So it's definitely too short for the 5 EUR I paid for it.

reviewText:
completely overrated little game. I bought it because it's been hyped by winning yesterday a lot of mentions and prizes at the game awards, it was on sale for 3,50â‚¬ so I guess it was worth giving it a shot.

the 70% of the game mechanics is about sorting video clips in a clipboard to make sense of a story told in a thousand tiny little clips of several interviews in a police precinct, cut so short for no â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ reason at all. and yet there are no tools at all for sorting the clips out together to be played all at once in the right chronological order... you can just SWAP them one by one! Swap! Why would anybody want to swap them? I just wanted to PLACE them IN BETWEEN other clips but guess what? you can't.

the community has been asking the developer to give them a simple function for removing the clips from the sidebar, and after FIVE months from his promise to include it in the game no updates are in sight and the programmer put up some excuse about the game getting hyped a lot so he hadn't much time at all to work on it. So... the game is going great and still you hadn't time to even polish it a bit?? what an unprofessional behavior.

anyway, back to the game, I've found the story teenage-y, there was nothing about crime solving at all or being a detective, you just have to guess keywords in a search engine (which is also limited to only the top five results! more artificial difficulty) and then put the clips of these police interviews altogether to understand what's going on. Too bad there's nobody interviewing her, too bad she's talking about her life with details of no importance at all to the case - she's even playing SONGS ON A GUITAR in a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ police precinct while being interrogated about a MURDER! That really put me out of the atmosphere, even more of her babbling about her drama-queen life, complete with a lot of unnecessary details about what's she likes to eat, what's her husband likes to do, how he wears his glassess...  because yeah, I'm being interrogated for murder, I'd surely talk about petty things like Bob Dylan songs and glasses and stuff.

Really, if you want to know more about the game, just go on youtube and find a let's play with all the clips in order. There's really nothing else here. This game might have been good for a Free To Play (check out Emily is Away for a good Free To Play similar to this one) or maybe for 1 buck, but 6â‚¬? Even 3,50â‚¬ on sale it's too much, I'd say 1 or 2â‚¬ tops is its right value.

So don't believe the hype and stay away from it, unless you really are looking for carpal tunnel injury trying to get all those clips together.

reviewText:
What a brilliant marketing achievement! Selling a short and uninteresting video footage as a videogame.
The entertainment value of this product is very similar to that of any crime tv documentary/show.
The story is on par with those shows and the way it is revealed is quite similar, the only difference is that some players might get the illusion they have an input in the whole thing.

The only interaction the viewer has with the videos is typing keywords that will be used to search and reveal some short clips from a database.
So you type a word, click search and get a number of videos that match the querry word, then watch the clips that vary from a few seconds to 1.5 min in length.
That will gradually reveal what transpired.
Thats it thats all.

Buying this product was stupid, recommending it would be dishonest, so i will just settle for stupid.

reviewText:
What even is a videogame?

I tried to play this all in one sitting as I was told that was quite possible and looking back, yes, quite. However, there is no.. ending as in there is nothing to be earned, the is no great accomplishment you simply... well you just accept what has transpired. Though I guess you are not really forced into any kind of acceptance.

I became 'satisfied' of my understanding around 2 hours in; I decided to take a break and reflect, even slept on it. Its damn near impossible to say anything directly about what happens as that is what the game is, its too BE the detective. After thinking about it some I decided to go back in and at least look at all the videos. I was roughly about say 60% of the 271 videos stored here where I became 'satisfied' But after resting I wanted to see what I had missed. If I could come across anything I had over looked or anything that I could confirm.

I still have some unclear details about things and honestly its probably best left that way. Too many details ruins what is clearly the makings of a classic if not the beginning of a new genre. Though I still have leanings towards my initial theory. Though I will say a few videos I over looked has me puzzled as to that exact aspect.

The odd thing is the game doesn't REALLY work unless the search engine is almost completely useless. I keep going back in my head and wondering if I had searched 'this' instead of 'that', could I have arrived at my conclusion sooner? Could I have beaten this clearly dastardly designed search engine? Honestly, I don't think so. The snippets of interviews you do see are out of order, and out of context and you can only assume what exactly she was asked. Each scene mildly leading you with a new buzzword until at times you get lost and searching for commonly said words hoping to land on some gold.

Before I actually played the game I thought to myself, isn't this just a bunch of youtube clips that are out of order and sort of obscured? And the answer is yes, absolutely but the fact that the search engine itself becomes an enemy to progress mixed with the VERY cool aesthetic of an old CRT and film grain with old an OS and the lights in the room flickering and reflecting on the screen, the ambiance of the sirens of police vehicles buzzing by.. Even the clickity clack of the keyboard. Makes for an unforgettable experience.

Do not skip this game and stay spoiler free.

reviewText:
Fascinating, dark, and lovely, Her Story offers you the experience of gradually piecing together a complex, layered narrative as you scrabble through a fragmented database of video statements one search term at a time.  The woman who is their solitary subject is the only source of testimony available, and the challenge of assembling something which satisfactorily resembles truth while questioning her veracity and motives is deeply compelling.  Multiple thematic symbols and threads gently hint towards one conclusion or another depending upon your subjective predispositions, but your interpretation is one that will remain openâ€”as well as uniquely yours, since no other player shared the same process in reaching it.

Actress Viva Seifert carries the entire game on her shoulders.  Her performance never feels cinematic but rather believably human, full of false starts and fidgets that vitally color her words.  She is presented through a wonderfully interlaced and dusty recreation of VHS tapes' lookâ€”and sound, as well, with the dull tocking of a wall clock audible behind the poor acoustics of the recording, which render subtitles invaluable, even to someone like me who generally abhors them.  All of this aesthetic design takes place within a classic '90s desktop that perfectly establishes the context needed to let you feel like a modern-day true-crime historian.

The occasional bits of music that play over the ambient noise of the fluorescent ceiling lights gloriously reflected off the screen create a warmâ€”if melancholyâ€”tone that puts me in mind of Gone Home, a very different vibe than might be expected of a murder investigation; it went a long way towards getting me in the frame of mind necessary for empathetically thinking about these characters' lives.  Flashes of facial reflection on the surface of the simulated computer monitor did the rest as they prompted me to wonder about my own role and the personal meaning that this mystery might hold.

Some have complained about the archive's limitation of displaying only five search results at a time, but I would argue that this is the essential obstacle which sparks the player's interaction; without it, these records would be laid bare and the puzzle would lose the novel structure that makes it so intriguing.  My one objection to the interface is that the videos saved for reference are too difficult to organize.  Swapping them around would not be too terrible in itself if only there was a way to prune clips that are no longer needed; as it is, the collection only ever grows and so eventually becomes cumbersome.*

However, this small issue is hardly a blemish on the game's accomplishment.  Her Story is very special, and I am gratified by the critical attention it has quickly received; it is already clear that it will be a lasting influence on game designers.  Players who enjoy the game and yearn for more would do well to search out Christine Love's free title Digital: A Love Story, of which I was reminded in more ways than one, as well as Barlow's classic work of interactive fiction, Aisle.



*Update: The ability to delete videos that have been saved to the user session is being added to the game.

Her Story is a game that sounds appealing if you're at all into FMV games and murder mysteries, and I bought it because of its reasonable asking price. It's a bit of a disaster. Based on the initial reviews, it looks like many people are able to get past their suspension of disbelief with how the gameplay works. If you really like mysteries and are decently forgiving with hideously contrived mechanics, the asking price is fair for its length - provided you don't find the story contrived, either. The Gameplay and Conclusion sections are spoiler-free, Plot/Writing section is not.

What I describe are symptoms of the much bigger problems. I hope this inspires more games to use FMV, because I'd love to play a good murder mystery FMV told in a fragmented way, but with internally consistent and non-frustrating gameplay - this one is a poorly written mess, marred by awful and lazy design.

reviewText:
WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS


I have been saying for years that FMV games need to come back; but sadly, this game is not a good example of what the genre is capable of. I think it in one way shows the main issue with the format and why it died: for a game of any reasonable length to fit in a reasonable amount of space the quality of the video displayed has to be awful. The longer the game, the worse the problem becomes. This game, however, hangs a nice lampshade on that problem by having the videos be from cassette recordings that were filmed in the 90s and giving the screen a CRT monitor distortion. I applaud the creativity for getting around that.

The problem, sadly, is that the gameplay is minimal to the point that I am embarrassed at how long it took me to figure out how the game was played...mostly because the game has so little content that I didn't realized I'd already started playing. You search for words from the police recordings and then watch the videos that contain those words. As you go through the videos you slowly put the story together until the game quite literally asks if you've had enough and simply ends. I felt like this would have worked really well as part of a larger game, but as it stands this game seems to take all of the very most dull aspects of detective work and tried to say that's a game. You are sitting at a desk reviewing testimony that's been put into a database that essentially turned the clips into a difficult to navigate puzzle for no obvious reason other than because the actress was the only person involved in the creation of this game.

Ultimately that was probably the biggest flaw, because without any other actors involved the story was forced to devolve into something that even a soap opera would roll its eyes at. Twin sisters separated at birth by a corrupt midwife are sharing one life a la The Prestige. Good stories show rather than tell, this one tells in excruciating detail and tries to trick you into thinking the story is more well thought out by chopping it into small clips and making you search for the pieces.

TL;DR: I don't think this game does FMV games justice. The acting is reasonable, but story is not particularly interesting due to the limited cast of only one person and the minimal interaction the player has with anything. It could have been something interesting, but ended up being pretty dull.

:edit: added spoiler warning and moved TL;DR to the bottom.

reviewText: Not Recommended: Presented as a film, Her Story might have made an interesting story presented though an unusual framing device, but as a game, it's a story let down by the means by which you are left to experience it. Coupled with over-acting from the actress of the titularly-implied character, stilted and unnatural exposition, a very bizarre and frankly inappropriate plot turn, and a lot of chaff in an already short game, I simply cannot recommend Her Story. There's some value to be found in exploring it the one time and discussing it, but this is a game you can easily replicate watching it on YouTube; very little from the experience is lost.\n\nRead the full review on Highland Arrow here[www.highlandarrow.com]

reviewText:
The amount of praise and number of awards Her Story received compelled me to give it a try, so I eagerly sat down to the game with a pen and pad of paper. Everyone I'd heard talk about it stressed the importance of keeping notes.

The game exists as a simulated Windows 3.1 desktop with various sound effects and image filters giving you that mid 1990s computer vibe. That part is done well. Actually, that part is the best part of Her Story.

The gameplay consists of watching a 90 minute interrogation video, split up into almost 300 individual clips that are each a few seconds long. You consume these videos randomly, as you enter a word into the search field and it returns up to five videos which contain that word in their transcript.

I'm okay with experience" games. Or "Interactive fiction". However
date: Her Story is really pushing this concept
recommended: in that there is no interactivity to this fiction (you are choosing which clips to watch in what order
hoursPlayed: but you're not making any choices) and the "experience" is . . . well

reviewText:
While I appreciate the idea, there are not many elements to this that qualify it as a game. It is more like an interactive story narrated in a different way than usual. That is one of the reasons I bought the game, but since there was nothing more to it, I found it quite disappointing.

About 60 minutes into the game i figured out the story and although it is very unlikely, I didn't find it bad. It is just that you don't get the option to really solve the game. Basically you decide when you've had enough and finish (after accessing a certain amount of information, that is).

So, I guess if you like visual novels and don't mind them being short, this game might appeal to you. If you expect a detective game, like I did, then you will not be satisfied,

I'd really like to see something like this with a more detective like approach..

reviewText:
You've been given access to a police database containing videos of a woman being interviewed over the disappearance and possible murder of her husband: you'll slowly uncover what happened and why by searching the database and listening to what she has to say.
Her Story is a detective game that challenges you to make sense of what you're looking at and come up with effective search words to unlock more, hopefully important, video sequences: it won't be everyone's cup of tea but it's an interesting experience for sure.

PROS:

-simple yet effective art style

-decent, if minimal, soundtrack

-Viva Seifert gives a great performance, her acting and body language add a lot to her lines

-a very interesting story featuring a few twists and appropriately mature content

-requires you to listen and reason to come up with valid search terms, the detective work is enjoyable and taking notes is almost a must

NEUTRAL:

-not everyone'll appreciate the simple gameplay or the fact you're simply looking up and watching videos, for some it won't even be considered a game

CONS:

-going through inconsequential videos can get a bit dull

-depending on your skill you might easily find out what happened or be left stranded

-while the interface is simple a small tutorial'd have helped players realize how it works (e.g. how to fast forward or rewind videos)

-not very long (I'd say 2/2,5hrs to find out what happened plus another hour if you want to watch all videos you've missed) and no replay value

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=668358151

I sadly can't plainly express many of the things I liked about the game as doing so'd require me to detail certain events or dialogues: doing so'd lessen the experience of anyone who hasn't played yet so, as usual, I'll be very vague. The story and narrative are, imho, pretty great and manage to stay enthralling even as you necessarily uncover them out of chronological order. There's lots to watch and you'll be faced with mature themes, sordid stories, false leads or simply useless bits of info.The fact you only hear answers without the starting questions means you'll have to think about what you're watching to make full sense of it: more reasoning'll obviously be needed for you to find out leads and decide if and how they fit in the investigation. It's difficult to remember every possible keyword so taking notes'll help you remember what to search for and, for some, it might be a great external tool to organize leads and try to understand what happened.

I have to admit that, at times, watching useless videos can get dull: of course they're there to make sure things don't become too easy but watching her answering how she wants her coffee each day isn't exactly fun. Depending on how good you are at guesswork and/ or your luck you might also find yourself stuck without knowing what keywords to use: other times you might have an hunch on what happened but find it hard to come up with the right word to find the video you're looking for. As a whole the system works though and I had no problem in finding enough leads to be given the option to exit the database and finish the game.

Her Story'll sit well with fans of the detective genre as the basic gameplay found here is all about looking for clues and making sense of what you find, there's also a good story here for those that value narrative over gameplay: if you are in the target audience the game will be a rewarding and original experience, one I thoroughly enjoyed.

reviewText: Her Story is a really interesting game. It reminds me quite a bit of Analogue: A Hate Story, in that it focuses on digging through an old computer database, trying to piece together the big picture from scraps and snippets of stories (though obviously they have very different subject matter, and Her Story uses live-action video instead of text). Part of the challenge is testing out your Google-fu skills and trying to figure out what search terms will uncover new videos. Then, even when you have most of the videos uncovered, you still have to try to piece together what you think happened.\n\nIf you're interested in unique, narrative-driven games, you should definitely give it a try. It's priced right, and I thoroughly enjoyed my experience with it.

reviewText:
My Impression:
I saw the high metacritic score and the description seemed to portray an investigative game with real cut scenes. Reality is that it's not a game. It's an experience. You search for keywords in a database. Next, it brings up a video with the word spoken by the people in the video. The point is to find all the clips and determine what happened in the case.

Positive:
+ Cool story
+ Interpreting what actually happened

Cons:
- Price
- Tedious
- Too easy to find the ending clips without finding out anything before hand
- The interrogator never talks in the clips

TLDR:
Finding the clues for the final scene are easy to do. What happens next is that the game drags on pointlessly. You know the main events, and are forced to find the 4-10 second clips. I got baited by the high metacritic score (not sure why it's so high) and the -40% for $3.59. I can only recommend this game for $0.99 or less, and even then, eh.

3/10

reviewText:
Her Story is a FMV game with brilliant storytelling that will practically blow your mind if you stick to it. I discovered this game via one of  MrNinjaSquirrel's reviews. His review was promising and I was interested so I spared the dime to try this game. It has been sitting in my library for a couple of months, then I realized that I had it. I decided to spare the afternoon, ended on sparing a whole day and a half.

At the start of the game, you find yourself facing an old computer with the data base of some video interviews by the same woman and told nothing else. You are only given the information that the whole video footages are destroyed due to an old fire - you read this from an old notepad file on the desktop - and you have to use the data base of cropped video pieces to learn furthermore. It seems that within a week's period in 1994 summer, a woman gave separate interviews to the police about a case. Who is she? What is her case? Why is she so damn important to you anyhow? What is Her Story?

You watch and LISTEN to the videos - I'm serious, listening is half of the game - , try and catch some key words, search them in the data base to reveal some more videos. Interviews are recorded as fragmented pieces with time stamps, so you can observe which one comes first. The tricky part is that your program is capable of displaying only the first five entry in the data base for each searched word. You have to find alternative word choices to reveal all videos to gather enough information about the gist of what's going on.

I have to warn beforehand: this game is for the patient and the story driven only. In the sense of game mechanics, all you do is type some words on a search bar and watch videos as they appear based on the search term. If you decide to organize the videos on a linear timeline to try and understand the unfolding of events, good luck. I tried, and successfully managed - and fed my OCD to its limits meanwhile. The resulting story was a total mind blown!

Little nuances, body language and word choices of the woman, fragmented tales gathered together to make a whole adds up to a genuinely award worthy game! The actress Viva Seifert's performance alone makes Her Story an experience to remember. It would possibly be self-explanatory to mention the name Sam Barlow also. He is the writer and director of our marvelous interactive story, also known for games such as Silent Hill: Origins and Silent Hill: Shattered Memories.

If I were to write any more about this game, I could not possibly restrain myself from revealing some kind of plot point and wreck your future experience with the game. I suggest you to pick a friend to accompany you while you play this, who should be equally patient as you. Deducing theories and guessing the truth behind all these fragments was my favorite part. So basic, yet also so satisfying.

reviewText: Her Story is an interactive FMV game where you take on the role of an (initially) unknown person who is sifting through video footage at a police station. Throughout the duration of the game, you sift through a little over 300 video clips of several interviews from 1994 of a British woman named Hannah, who is overly obsessed with fairy tales. By the end of the clips, the player will have a full understanding of what event had transpired, and also who they are within the game.\n\nI'll admit, the main selling point of this title for me was the fact that it was made by Sam Barlow. I'm a huge Silent Hill fan, although Shattered Memories is far from my favorite. Unfortunately, Her Story does not live up to even a fraction of the hype that has surrounded it since its release date in 2015, nor has it lived up to the potential of Sam Barlow. The title is little more than a glorified movie on Steam, masked as an FMV game. But Belphegore

reviewText:

There are people saying this is not a game, which is true, it's not. Not really a negative though; I love Choice of Robots and that's not considered a game either. So don't let that sway you.

I commend the developer for this unique title but I found few redeeming qualities in it.

The game is about 2.5 hours long and the gameplay is basically you accessing a database and watching videos to get keywords to find more videos in sets of 5 until you log and apparently get when you came for (there is no end video so I don't see the impact of the ending at all). reviewText:
8/10

This is a rather unusual game, where the entire gameplay consists of watching old clips of a woman being investigated by the police, across a period of a few weeks in 1994. The player cannot hear the questions, but can type search keywords, as all videos are full text indexed. The interface is pretty limiting and deliberately made to look like some archive software from that era. Up to 5 results per search terms can be accessed and you can keep bookmarks but canâ€™t delete them. You can also add your own keywords.

Watching the clips tells a non-linear story, and the ability to understand it depends directly on the search term the player comes up with. The story gradually becomes clearer the more videos you watch, but even if you manage to watch all of them thereâ€™s more than one possible interpretation. If youâ€™re looking for chewed up ending, youâ€™re not going to get it here, but there is closure (or at least thatâ€™s how it felt to me).

The game is great for â€œover-the-shoulder co-opâ€, where two or more people consult about the story, try to think together about new search terms and exchange theories about what happened. Needless to say, only one person needs to actually type the keywords. Itâ€™s also advisable to write down findings and revisit the more hard to interpret clips with these additional findings in mind.

The game may not sound so interesting and the screenshots sure arenâ€™t appealing, but the interesting story and the great acting by Viva Seifert turn it into something very unique and captivating. Highly recommended.


Note: I did not play this game for 20 hours. Steam continues to count also when a game is minimized. The typical game times for this game (according to HowLongToBeat[howlongtobeat.com] are between 3 to 6 hours. If you want to find every possible clip, you're likely to surpass these times, but not hit double digit hours.

reviewText:
I have had two different experiences with Her Story.

When I first played the game, I began fiddling with the search engine trying to uncover what happened to poor Simon.
I did not get very far, and began to lose interest and decided to play something else.

A few monthes later, I decided to boot up Her Story again. It was nagging at me that I could not understand this game at first, and I wanted to know exactly what you are supposed to do in this damn game. I begin looking through the search engine and watching clips again wondering what was going on, and by chance I had discovered a huge revelation about the game that completely turned Her Story on it's head.

It was surprising to see my innate assumptions about this murder case get blown out of the water, and even then it just continued to slap around my unfounded conclusions as to what was actually going on. The games plot has serpentine twists that remind of me of the early works of M. Night Shyamalan film. I found my self going back to my personal video archive to cross reference new footage, and then finding even more revealing tidbits helping me piece together the entire narrative of the story.

The closest analogy I can compare as to what kind of gameplay experience Her Story contains would be that of taking a 1000 piece puzzle, opening the box, and dumping the pieces on your table. Digging through each piece until you find the ones that connect, and the connecting the chunks of information you have, all the while looking at each piece for every minute detail. You can not rely on merely observing the same patterns over and over. You have to pay attention to whats being said, certain details and clues, the appearance of the subject, the times and dates of the videos, everything. I definately think keeping a pad and paper is a requirement for this game, because once you start digging deep into this game you will need it.

Whenever you engage in something, you have a preconceived notion of how something will work; there is always a structure and a expectation of how to interact with that structure. Her Story tears this expectation down not only in how you experience the content, but how you engage with the structure of Her Story as a video game. The game does not hold your hand and lead you on a linear path to understand how the story gets from point A to point B. Other than a couple of readme.txts placed inside of the game. it does not really tell you what you are doing, or why you are doing it in  the first place. The game does not time you, the game does not grade, the game does not give you a score or tell you what you have accomplished. The game does not give an elicit definition of the challenges and roadblocks that will set before you. Only when you have researched and observed enough significant videos to give you a understanding of what exactly happened during the murder of the man named Simon will the game nudge you into giving you an answer, and once that happens you will know exactly what Her Story is.

One of the criticisms I have seen is Her Story is not a game! It's just a bunch of FMV clips!". I have noticed people who say this have put only an hour or less into Her Story. As much as I don't like being dismissive of people's personal opinions I have to say it...their opinion does not matter. They have not put in enough time to understand what this game is. It is definately a game. It will challenge you

reviewText: Recommended with reservations.\n\nHer Story sends you digging through archived police interviews to get to the bottom of a murder and the bizarre story behind it. The game itself takes the form of wrestling with dated software and its extremely limited ability to present disorganized, decontextualized short clips of video ranging from about 3 to 90 seconds. They're at least transcribed so word searches will check against the transcripts, but without meaningful tags, organization by chronology or subject, or any way to easily remove red herrings from your painfully limited search results. So the real game" of Her Story is understanding your interviews
recommended: seizing on hints for further search terms
hoursPlayed: and coming up with your own.\n\nBut there's a problem. This is a game that lives and dies by its deliberately hobbled search mechanics
voteText: but a glaring oversight by the developers makes it possible to power through everything in chronological order without ever scratching your noggin. And it's a trick simple enough that I thought of it within the first few minutes. You have to consciously avoid using it if you want the story to unravel in roughly the direction the developers intended.\n\nOne last warning: This isn't some classic detective whodunnit. There's some mystery and ambiguity to it all

reviewText:
Wow. This was a real treat. I picked this up on a whim, and my wife and I decided to casually start it after dinner last night. We didn't turn it off until we finsihed it. Yep, its that engrossing. This is an onion-skin game if I have ever seen one. You will be peeling back layers for hours. What starts out as something that seems quite simple, turns into anything but.

Whoever the single actor was, she did a damn fine job. Props to her.

Essentially, you are filtering through very short video clips and trying to piece together what is going on in a who-dunnit style murder mystery. Describing the game beyond this is territory for spoilers, so do yourself a favor and experience it for yourself. Stay off the forums until you have finsihed the game/formed your own opinions.

The amazing thing is, that while this is a top-notch experience, they actually managed to sneak in a good amount of actual game elements. Its not *just* something you watch. You definately interact.

Pros:
+This is as fresh as it gets as far as novel indie game fun
+It will suck you in and have you discussing theories long after the game ends
+The acting is very good
+The ambience is perfect - almost spooky at times

Cons:
-No big deal here, but if it matters to you - you may not get a good ratio of dollars to hours. But seriously, who cares when its this good
-I want more!

I wouldn't even wait for a sale. Get this, and grab a friend or two and see what each other think happened in this engrossing story.

reviewText:
Being into unconventional games, this one caught my attention, and it sounded promising enough.
But it doesn't work out very well.

Here's what you basically do in the game:
You are in front of a computer (in-game) and you have to search a database for keywords for which you then receive the first 5 matches.
The clips are all about the same murder case, showing the answers the suspect has given throughout the interrogations over a few days.

Additionally you have a DB Checker tool that displays the position of the last played clip. This way you can put it easier in order and even assign it a positional number.

Now, I guess the idea is that you hear about new keywords in the clips, and then you search on with them so you get the complete interrogation. But that's not how it works.
After bruting for 5 hours I noticed a major flaw there with which you can just cheat through the game really (I'll mention that one at the bottom again).

The Story itself
Storytelling is good and it probably wouldn't work too well if you just watched it in chronological order. But even then it would still be a good story.
The issue is, the storytelling doesn't work at all if you spoiler ahead by accident really because you find a clip which is set on the last day.

So really, it doesn't work either way.

Now, your best bet in my opinion is to not play the game at all. The gameplay is crap anyway, it's just a time waster at best. Just watch a longplay on Youtube instead.
OR - there's a flaw in the game that let's you get the clips in chronological order easily. Just reset the whole thing, search for blank. That gives you the first 5 clips because that's the default keyword.
Change that keywords to 1,2,3,4,5 - search for blank again. Keep on going with 6,7,8 - you get the idea.

Bottom line. Nice story, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ game. They â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed it up big time.
The game could work, I'm convinced. But not this way.

reviewText:
Successfully breaks from standard gaming genres to expand what types of experiences can be considered a game.

Her Story is actually a fairly simple intertwining of gameplay and live action video that together form a  hugely effective experience. On their own, each component would not be as compelling. Sitting at a virtual computer from the 90's typing search keywords into a database might recall school research trips to the library. The videos themselves, the meat of this game, would lose some of their sense of mystery and nearly all of our personal investment in them if we were allowed to view them all at once in sequence. However, in pairing these two, this game created something new; something that made me feel more like a detective than any game, show or book has before.

Unlike the game's structure, the story told within the videos is far from simple. Without spoilers, the things this woman talked about in these police interviews kept me interested and engaged. Who was this woman and how did she view the events that led her to where she was? As I pieced things together, sometimes new information would come to light that made me rethink what I thought I knew. Enough care and detail was put into these videos to make them seem real, like I was getting a peek into one woman's life.

None of this would have worked without good writing, acting and production of these videos. Various industry publications have nominated and given awards to Her Story for these aspects. How the interviews are divided also deserves credit. You never learn too much from a single video, but usually you get enough to trigger new ideas for keyword searches. Some of these divisions do get frustratingly short, though, making them difficult to discover and not very informative. They're realistic from a police interview perspective, but this realism comes at a cost to the gameplay that I don't think is worth it.

Toward the end of the game the pace begins to sputter as the number of unwatched videos grows small. No longer did I feel like a skillful detective picking up on details and then using them to uncover new information. Instead, I eventually felt like I was grasping at straws, hoping to get lucky. This may very well only be a problem for completionists like me that don't like to use guides if they can help it. I strongly suggest that you play the game until the pace at which you are finding new footage begins to bother you and then go find a guide for 100% completion. There are some videos that only have one spoken word in them that I'm fairly confident I NEVER would have found without help.

reviewText:
Her Story is well, a story. Told in various little video CCTV clips that you are shown. The story unravels while you have a look at them and try to piece it together.

Graphics 7 of 10
The graphic mainly consists of various video snippets from a police interrogation. So no detonations, no over the edge graphics, just basically a movie that is played.

Music    7 of 10
Well, there is rather no background sounds or music or something like this. All the sound there is, is the defendant/ witness talking. Still she has a nice voice and what she's saying is never cheesy or feeling odd.

Gameplay 8 of 10
There really is no real gameplay. All you do is try to piece together the story of a murder and the incidents leading to it as told by the wife. Even though you don't do that much besides searching for clues and typing various keywords to find more video clips it's very gripping. Somehow. It's really hard to explain what's so gripping about the story, but somehow it is. You get to a point when you really want to know more about the girl. Did she do it? Or didn't she?

Final verdict
Must buy for all game afficionados with a liking for a deep and intriguing story and mind the absence of real action.

reviewText:
Her Story is quite a unique game and that makes it so interesting. Full Motion Videos in games aren't exactly a new thing, but the gameplay mechanic of this is.

You watch through interrogation clips of a british woman and try to piece the puzzle together in your head. You can use search function to bring up the clips, you type in a word and every video with that word comes up. But you only have acces to five at a time, so to narrow the search results you need to add another word. And of course these clips wont tell the story in chronological order so here is where the puzzle part comes.

I might have been too hyped about this game from the disussions and reviews so the ending didn't quite feel satisfying enough. I also didn't get the story as a full on my first playthrough, so that might have affected my feelings about the game too. But I did go back to find all the videos. And liked the story overall.

It's hard job for an actor to be the whole focus of the camera all the time, people pick up everything you do and say. Viva Seifert did good job on her perfomance. Also the the look of these old videos added to the authenticity and mood.

I can't really recommend this game to everyone. If you are looking for more traditional game, this might not be for you. But if you are tired of all the shooting, platforming, min-maxing and want a fresh take on what videogames can be, you should try it!

reviewText:
==== Review ====Synopsis
Her Story is an amazing FMV tale of mystery and intrigue where you must utilize your fine detective skills in order to piece together a story using archived video footage of 7 interviews. These 7 interviews detail the background of the candidate's missing husband. Viva Seifert, the interviewee, won numerous awards for her superb acting in this game, helping it become one of the most popular indie games in the summer of 2015. Even though I don't have many hours logged into this game on Steam, I have previously completed it with a friend.

Gameplay
With nothing much to start with, you first bootup the police video database and begin to watch a few seemingly non-interconnected clips, sporatically taken within the seven different interviews. Your job is to type in keywords discovered throughout your investigation in order to pull up other unseen clips. Some of these keywords are fairly obvious, such as: Hospital, Husband, etc., yet others are extremely obscure (the final keyword). A database tracker helps you visualize which/how many clips you have seen, and if you are getting close to the final tapes (in chronological order).

Interface
Throughout gameplay, there will be an active session of 5 or so clips, and if there are more than 5 clips for a search result, you must view some of them in order to have access to the rest. A very helpful feature is that notes can be added for each clip. This really helps if you leave and want to pick the game back up down the line. The depth in this game is magnificent, yet the UI can still use a lot of work. Other than that, this unique story is truly a masterpiece.

==== Shortcut ====I would not advise using this method to play the game, yet if you have beaten the game and want to view every tape, this method shown below will help you do that in chronological order.

Every clip's note has the word BLANK written inside of it as a default setting. If you search for BLANK, the database will continue to pull up every video you have not seen. This method only works if you add a note (i.e. a number) to the video you just watched, so that it will no longer come up as a result.

==== Score ====
Great
- 9/10

reviewText:
If you have the time, please sit down and play this game. This game is incredibly well written and well acted. I have rarely felt this engaged in a video game. Pen and paper are a necessity in order for you to follow along.

PROS:
The actress was perfect.
The writing is on point.
It makes you think.
A story that provides evidence for multiple (conflicting) theories. (I made this a pro despite having conflicting evidence, purely for the fact that the game allows the player to come up with their own deduction without them being spoonfed a proper answer)

CONS:
Gameplay sorta ruins the game. You will encounter some crucial information very early on rather than at a natural time.
No background music/very little ambient sound.


I think that this game was wonderful. A nice experience that I believe is very deserving of the positivity surrounding it.

reviewText:
Allow me to start off this brief review by establishing one fact: this game is brilliant. Part of this brilliance is that it isn't a traditional sort of game, but rather an entry in the recently emerging genre of 'narrative games'. I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing, and I believe this is possibly the best way to experience it, so I will avoid spoiling that to anyone who might actually be reading this.

It is important to know that you're in front of a computer throughout the entire game; investigating a murder case by watching over 200 (short) video clips segments of seven interviews, all of the same woman (the victim's wife). That's about it. To find particular clips you must search key words. Depending on the word you type into the game, a list of videos may show up, each a short segment of one of the interviews with the deceased's wife. To understand what happened, you must watch the clips, listen out for other key words (usually names or objects) and then search for those as well. In the end, all the pieces come together and this intriguing tale makes sense.

This is a fantastic detective game which completely stands out tall from other games with a similar premise.

Highly recommended.

2733.
That's the number of words in the notes I took for this game.
This game was amazing. It instantly drew me in with the story. To find these fragments of the story and try to piece it all together was an almost mesmerizing task. To put in a search term and have it return new footage felt so satisfying. It really makes you feel like you're uncovering a mystery.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves a good story. I also highly recommend taking notes. It will help a TON.

reviewText:
Her Story is a throwback to the classic FMV games from the 90s, but will you want to play this one ?

The story follows on Hannah Smith, her husband Simon is missing and she's one of the main suspects . I can't go into further detail cause that would spoil the entire game.

The game is made in the style of the classic FMV games. The entire style is very 90s and even the computer you use runs on the classic Windows operating system.

Gameplay is very simple. You are using an Police operating system to watch videos to gather pieces of the story. You have a search bar where you can input words and search for videos. There's also a flash game you can try out on the side. The gameplay is very simple and easy to get used to.

Audio design is great. From the computer starting up and the nice soundtrack, to the very impressive audio design in the videos. Overall the audio design and the soundtrack are very impressive.

Game is kind of short. The game is around 4 hours if you watch every video. There's not much replay value whatsoever. Overall this game is pretty much a one playthrough type game.

The game works perfectly, no bugs whatsoever. The only issue I could find is the steam overlay not working correctly.

Her Story is an incredible experience. Every detective story or adventure game fan has to play this game no matter what. The actress does an incredible and the story is incredible. Overall this game is a must own. One of the best games I've played in 2015. This a tip for people who will play it in the future. It's very easy to get spoiled in the game if you find some videos in the final days of the interviews so it's best to pull up a list with each video in order. I give Her Story a  9.5/10

reviewText:
If you ever watched CSI, NCIS, Law and Order, X-Files, or Sherlock,

Then get this game.

If you're entertained at the idea of an interactive story that will be unique to how you discover it,

Then get this game.


Clever stories are clear when they must be, and mysterious when they ought to be. They must shroud you in riddles when you feel close, and pull back the curtain when you feel as if you have reached the end. This game does exactly that.

Narrative 9/10
Acting 8/10
Sound 10/10
Style 10/10

Ruling: Must Play

reviewText: This was so much more engaging than I was expecting! I had heard good things and seen the previews, but nothing does it justice until you experience the game and play it for yourself. The gameplay is so simple, and yet it was so engaging and extremely interesting! I just had to find out how everything went down, and could not stop until I found every piece of footage. And the ending (no spoilers), left a chill going down my spine. Lots of twists that I was not expecting! I honestly really enjoyed the idea of live action being inputted into this game. It made everything seem so much more real, and was very spooky.\n\nExcellent game that I would highly recommend!!

reviewText:
Through an old computer you have access to videoclips of a woman talking to the police about her missing husband. The videos were taped in 1994, and they were digitised, transcribed and made searchable so that it would be easy to find specific parts of the interviews that could be relevant in court. However, the footage of the detectiveâ€™s questions have been lost so there are only about 270 short clips of the womanâ€™s responses. The clips are not accessible in a straightforward manner, but they are at least searchable so you can type in a keyword to get the clips where that keyword is mentioned. Sadly, only the first five hits for each keyword can be retrieved. From this you will try to figure out what actually happened in June 1994.

From this description it is clear that Her Story is an unusual game. There is no other gameplay involved than typing keywords and watching videoclips, but it really works! It is not a straightforward story that is coming through the grainy taped videos, and I really wanted to know more about what happened. After finishing the game in a satisfactoily manner (actually watching all clips) I realised that I had spent more than four hours watching 90 minutes of photage of one woman responding to questions while enjoying it. This could only be possible through the excellent acting, and it may be the first time I think of excellent acting in a computer game. Well done Sam Barlow (creator) and Viva Seifert (the woman).

There an important flaw in the game idea of Her Story: it is certainly possible for a player to use certain keywords by chance and immediately receive crucial information about the case. Luckily for me, I seem to be very much into the other direction with watching almost all clips before getting a reasonable idea about the events. There is thus no guarantee that the order in which a player may see the clips makes sense from a narrative point of view. In addition there is absolutely no replayability value in a game of this type, but I think my experience from playing the game was so good that these flaws do not matter for me. I had four great hours!

reviewText: Playing this was an interesting experience. You are given access to an old police computer terminal and video clips of a woman being interviewed. It has a really unconventional style, which will probably catch you off guard if you're expecting more traditional gameplay.  It isn't clear what your goals are, who you are playing as, or what information you're trying to uncover. And I don't think that's a bad thing. The game intrigued me and had me asking questions all the way through. I wanted to keep digging deeper into the clips so I could learn more about this woman. The more you uncover, the more questions you begin asking yourself. I don't want to say much more about it. I think it's best to go in blind.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's an FMV game, and as such it's already a niche title. The only thing you're doing in it is typing in keywords in a search box and watching videos. It's not exactly innovative or original, similar FMV games existed before, but the game is well aware of this and tries its best to deliver a non-linear murder mystery. There are two major twists to be found, and there's a lot of psychological drama. The actress performs quite well, and the story works even if it's a bit too far reaching at times. However, if you suspend your disbelief just enough (no, there's nothing paranormal about it, not like that) it does deal with some interesting themes.\n\nThere's not a lot of gameplay to speak of, as you can see. There's a minigame easter egg, but that's it. If you ever liked FMV games and don't mind a neat idea, then give it a shot. If you're looking for something more substantial with deeper mechanics, look away.
