reviewText:
This game is 1 in a million. You really feel like you're piecing together a police case. The story itself becomes more and more twisted with each new video you watch.

The presentation is unique also. You're sitting in front of an old CRT monitor as you browse through interview videos of the police database. The actor does a great job also, as her reactions felt believable.

The game doesn't hold your hand either, as you need to think of the best keywords to find the releveant videos and you need to keep track of what was said in each video segment by yourself. There are no indications of progress either.

One negative aspect is that, if you left the game for a few days, it's really hard to come back and figure out where you left off.

I highly recommend this short but amazing game.

reviewText:
Hesitation.

It's on your face at the beginning, less so on hers. You're looking at a series of grainy videos from years past, recalling bad haircuts and embarrassing fashion choices. And her? She might be looking at being accused as an accessory to the murder of Simon Smith. Perhaps it's not so bad for you, in balance.

Sam Barlow's Her Story is a classic mystery game that subverts the 'choose your own story' genre for the Google generation (which my parents have caught up to now so perhaps I might even have them try this one out). Using a series of search words and phrases, you sift through a database of police interview videos captured many a year ago of one suspect: the titular 'her' in Her Story. Each video has been fully transcribed (in the background) so if a word is contained within it, it will show up in your search results. But it's not as easy as Googling, I mean typing in, 'murder' and 'suspect' and hoping to narrow down the field posthaste. Each video is loaded with a tantalising mixture of nebulous emotion, hard facts and delicious red herrings. The more you watch, the closer you get to the truth, or sometimes you find yourself going off on tangents on a hunch. There were a few times when I though I'd had it, only to discover a contradiction (which made me yell Objection!" at the screen a few times) which required me to rethink my line of thought. This is amplified by the fact that the interviews take place over several days. The sense of time is palpable: the interviewee isn't in the same mindset every day so what you get out of her varies beautifully. It's worth mentioning that the acting by Viva Seifert is wonderful and makes the experience emotive and involving: there are times when she draws you into her confidence with throwaway lines and cheeky grins

reviewText: Overview Oh man, do I have some things to say about this game. While it may not be for everyone, I found this game unequivocally immersive when compared to just about any game I've ever played, with a splendid and thought provoking story to boot. In this review I'll go through this games format, immersion factor, story, and some closing thoughts. It will be spoiler free, despite how much I want to share my personal opinions on what happened in this story.\n\nFormat While it may seem like a strange thing to do a bit on, this game has a format/display that I've never seen in a game before. I don't claim to have played every game ever made, but I'm pretty sure that it is because it has never been done. The main jist of this is that there are several videos  that you must find to gain knowledge on Her Story's- well, story. What do I mean by find? Well, the majority of your time in Her Story will be spent searching terms in a search bar. If the word/statements you feed into the system that contains the videos is said in the clips, those videos will show up. However, only 5 will show up at a time, so you can't just search the" and get half of the clips. While many claim this to be a very boring and tedious system

reviewText: This is perhaps the purest incarnation of an investigation game we're ever going to have the pleasure of playing. There's something really riveting about realizing that certain words are coming up repeatedly, and the longer you delve into the statements, the more you become aware of just how much work had to have gone into scripting the dialogue for this game so that each video would branch into the others in a semi-planned manner. Each time you find a new video, there's this great little sense of accomplishment, and the video itself is the reward. The interface is brilliantly appropriate and simple, and although there's an option to save clips for future reference, I personally find just writing keywords down on a notepad is easier. Her Story has a lot of twists and turns as you piece it together, and those moments where your entire view on the situation changes are really difficult to pull off in any narrative, so I have a lot of respect for this game. Definitely worth the purchase, especially if you like mysteries or language puzzles.

reviewText:
4.2 hours. At least, that's what my Steam stats show for playing and completing Her Story - a genuine surprise amongst overwhelming freeplay embarassments and clickfest messes.

4.2 hours. It started simply enough - a recommendation on Kotaku, a follow-up search showing generally positive reviews. A brand new laptop. A desire to play a bit away from my usual console comfort. A fond remembrance of FMV titles from when I first started gaming, ranging from the Mad Dog McCree laser games in the arcades to my beloved The 7th Guest and Tex Murphy. Finally a decision to purchase. $5.99. Reasonable.

4.2 hours. Hmm. That comes out to more than a buck an hour. But is that a fair assessment? There is a reason I don't go to the movies anymore - I can wait for all but the biggest to come to Blu Ray or HBO. A movie could average $5 per hour, and I'm not willing to pay that. Recently, with titles like Dragon Age Inquisition and The Witcher 3, the cost per hour is supremely lower for an amazingly outstanding experience, in the 50 cent or lower range. That is amazing. But again, with Her Story, is that fair?

Look. It all comes down to enjoyment. And boy did I have that in spades. From the ancient 80s interface to the surprisingly lack of frustration given the minimalist instructions and direction. It just all made sense. It just worked. It was really, simply fun.

Can you imagine what would happen if the actress, Viva Seifert, wasn't able to pull this off? It's a one woman show (he says with a knowing wink) and she addresses the challenges exceedingly well. I catch myself here, desperately wanting to discuss futher but knowing to spoil the tale here is to spoil the entire game. And there simply isn't enough time. We only have

4.2 hours. Completed everything except the odd 2-player game thrown in as a...what? An example of previous programming achievements? A toss back to that same era? Would a cop really have a two player game like that on a crime database computer? Again - 2 player? (Psst. There's an achievement tied to this game. Seriously. Only thing I didn't finish.)

So do I recommend this? Yes. It won't be for everyone. It requires a bit of patience, a bit of deduction, a bit of appreciation for the old, the retro knowingly popping its head up brilliantly. It requires some suspension of disbelief, and more maturity than many may have, regardless of age. It's not deep, not really. And the trick is a single-ride pony - heck, the game said I was done much earlier than I was ready for. But with that said, yes, I still recommend this. I enjoyed it. The ride was refreshingly clean, the mind trip left a conundrum for longer than it should have been, second and third-guessing continued and I loved that as well. Give it a try. It won't take long.

4.2 hours.

Give or take.

reviewText: I think this game would probably cause some really mixed reactions from the gaming community.  Some would probably praise it for the unique way in which the story is told, while others would likely criticize it for its ambiguity.  Personally, while I see both sides, I definitely think that Her Story is something special.  The plotline can get frustrating because not all the details are revealed and you have to fill in the blanks as best you can with your own theories, but that's what I love about it.  I love that I felt like I needed a pen and paper to write out a timeline of events in the order in which I believe they took place, and then talk to someone else and realize that they came to a radically different conclusion.  It's only a few hours long, and finding the last few bits of story in the database can get really frustrating, but overall, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Her Story is a game of playing detective: searching through random clips of a woman (played by Viva Seifert) being interrogated in an attempt to gradually piece together the full picture of what has occurred, and why.

Conceptually, it's interesting, and the game tries to make the experience as authentic as possible, giving you a Windows 3.1-esque interface with which to search the database with. If it's a good concept you're looking for, Her Story certainly has it - but I feel that the execution falters on a couple of levels.

On the gameplay level, the restriction to five videos per search gets rather annoying, especially when new keywords aren't always easy to come up with. It seems like a necessity, to avoid trivializing the game (you'll realize this if you think to input a blank search, which returns all videos), but it doesn't improve the experience any.

But more significantly, on the story level, the game feels a tad unsatisfying.

I won't say too much even behind spoiler tags, but essentially, what the precise state of affairs is with regards to the interrogated woman, is never confirmed. Instead, after viewing enough clips, you receive a call" asking if you're done; answering yes is your game ending
recommended: final revelation about the player character.\n\nHer Story is a game based on a concept and a story about a woman's life. If that overrides the questionable execution - both story and gameplay wise - then you'll like this game. For me
hoursPlayed: it didn't quite make it."

reviewText:
Although it is far from the masterpiece many are claiming it to be, for Â£4.99, this is well worth your cash.

[SPOILER FREE]
The game has you searching through interview footage of a woman who has reported her partner as missing. However, the video clips you will be watching are cut up into tiny segments - some last two or three seconds, others last over a minute - and aren't displayed in the correct order.

In order to find more clips, you have to enter key words into a database, and videos containing these words will be returned in the search. For example, upon starting the game up, the key word 'MURDER' will already in the database, with a selection of videos on show. You will have to watch these clips, then pick up new key words spoken by 'her', which you then use to find more footage.

There isn't really an end to the game as such. Once you think you've worked out what happened, you're done. If you really want, you can continue to search for every single video clip the game has to offer, which could be considered '100%-ing' the game.

Positives:
- The user interface is very authentic.
- Each clip has some minor detail to spot.
- The game generates some 'light-bulb' moments for the player when you figure something out.
- The acting is good but ...

Negatives:
- ... it is very theatrical, which takes away from the immersion. It doesn't feel natural.
- Some plot points are ridiculous, while others are taken so far they become over-the-top.
- No way to write down your detailed findings in the game, so you'll need to have some paper handy.
- Spotting certain details early on can result in you solving the case very early into the footage bank.
- The game hints at what is really going on far too early - not through footage, but through a desktop event.

Her Story is definetly worth Â£4.99 for the 'light-bulb moments' alone, although a tighter and more believable story could have elevated it to greater heights.

reviewText:
Her Story is such a unique game, quite unlike any game I have played in my life. This is an indie game developed by Sam Barlow and it is a detective game that is about the interrogation of a British woman suspected in the murder of her husband. It is a murder mystery that began in 1994 and is divided into many brief video clips. The womanâ€™s interrogation/interview is divided into videos stored in the police database. You see what looks like a desktop interface from Windows 95 and the South East Constabulary logo.

Your objective is to enter keywords to find video clips stored in the database to get an idea of the circumstances surrounding the death of her husband, Simon. The game begins with you entering the keyword â€˜murderâ€™. The keyword â€˜murderâ€™ leads you to a number of video clips to get you started on how to get acquainted with the police stationâ€™s search bar and how to get acquainted with the crime story. What is fun about entering keywords to obtain video clips of this female suspect is that it is so nonlinear that you can experience the story in different ways. Therefore, every playerâ€™s experience with the narrative will be different. Players will play FMVs in so many different possible orders. An entered keyword can bring up a video relating to the beginning, middle, or end of the narrative. You will learn about the different events in the womanâ€™s life and the people who interacted with her prior to her husbandâ€™s death.

What is amazing about the fragmented structure of the game is that each video is intriguing and made me want to find out more about her answers. Some videos feel like I need to find out more about her in a previous video that I had not played whereas other videos made me like I need to figure out the best keywords to bring up subsequent video clips to find new revelations and possible twists in this mystery. So, it feels like a jigsaw puzzle that you are trying to put together by putting videos together using creative keywords that you can figure out by watching and paying careful attention to videos you have already uncovered. The interface allows you to store video clips you have watched for possible later viewing again. Just when you think you figured this woman out, you feel like there are twists and turns in subsequent videos that make you feel differently about her. At one point, I felt some sympathy towards her in a series of videos, but in the next series I was highly suspicious of her because of the way she behaved in the videos. I later felt like she was delusional when answering some questions. So, I had mixed feelings about her as I was trying to put together this jigsaw puzzle of videos. There is a database checker app installed in the desktop that keeps track of how many videos you have found. This database checker shows green colors for the videos you have already watched and red for videos you have not yet watched.

Entering keywords feels simple at the very beginning. However, the keywords get trickier as you will have to enter multiple keywords since the murder mystery seems to deepen as you progress through the story. I actually ended up writing hundreds of keywords on paper for future reference so that I can enter them to bring up more videos. Multiple keywords include word combinations relating to places, names, and times of the day. This game made me like a real detective trying to break the murder case wide open. However, some players may become frustrated as they get deeper into the narrative because of the greater need for word combinations in order to find the video clips they have not yet found.

The video clips appear to be recorded on VHS, which is a sign of the times back in the 1990s. The woman portraying the main character, Viva Seifert renders a superb performance, with her British accent being credible and brilliant. For a game with FMVs focused on one person and does not change screens, there is a lot of emotion and excellent sound design. I was left wishing that I could hear the questions from the detective since I was not able to listen to them. It is quite strange that a murder suspect would enter the interrogation room with a guitar and play a song in front of the detective.

If you feel like taking a break from the game, you can indulge yourself by clicking on the rubbish bin desktop app to play an Othello-like game, Mirror Tiles. There is an achievement called score draw that requires you to end the game in a draw, which is quite hard to do and requires lots of practice.

I played a detective game titled L.A. Noire, a detective crime drama story that was very well done. However, I found Her Story to be more unique as a detective crime drama since it felt more realistic and emotional. This game has the drama of classic crime drama TV shows without all the shooting you are used to seeing on TV. Her Story is as interactive a detective story as any that I have ever played as you have control over what pieces of the story you will watch and in any order. I highly recommend Her Story to anyone, no matter what their favorite game genre is.

My Score: 9/10

reviewText: Enjoyment out of Her Story increases with your willingness to immerse yourself in not only the story, but the game mechanics themselves. The story of Her Story only works if the actress is believable and the acceptance of your mysterious blonde identity plugging away at an outdated computer. Viva Seifert is astounding and I tried my very best to uncover all that I could about her life. Accepting and utilizing the search function as best as possible is its own obstacle. The challenge is player created as there is no end game. Search terms come five at a time from keywords the actress uses or your own guesses and interests in her life.\n\nMy time with Her Story was extremely enjoyable until I hit a wall in my leads, searches, and patience. I used the game-given option to leave satisfied and the credits rolled. Afterwards, I went for all achievements and quickly quit the game. As I said, the second that you remove yourself from the story and play this as a game to complete to the end, it loses all interest and the remaining clips become an achievement trudge. Even though I hit a wall, I have to recommend this for how interesting and memorable this brief FMV clip searcher and watcher is. Whatever you put into Her Story, it will give back double.

reviewText:
A Murder Mystery that is a very unique in many ways. It is nice to see some games that take chances and are confident enough to pull off a game like this. For me certain aspects remind me of Tex Murphy (One of the only good fmv games back in the day) and the old Police Quest games. While not quite as much gameplay as those other games, the vibe and atmosphere is there, along with a good performance by the leading lady. It might not have the level of depth or different gameplay mechanics as some of those other games, but it still is very enjoyable.

Some might cry that this is not really a game and what not, but for me it is very much a game and a wonderful, unique and engrossing experience. I hope we get many more of these types of games in the future. Yes you sit at a computer and search for videos, but it is so much more than that. You really feel like someone who is going back to do some research of some old murder mystery. At times I wasn't sure if she was guilty or if she was innocent, being truthful or lying, that really says alot about the acting done by the main character in this.

You have to listen in this game and pay attention, put on your detective cap as you watch, listen and search for things on this computer that might help you. For the games price it is a must try, especially if you like mystery or muder mystery,etc..  Did you hear her mention someone new? Type that name into the computer to see any other videos recorded with that word used in it. Get in that chair, turn on this old computer from the mid 90s and get to work Detective!

On one side this game is unlike anything we have really ever had, but on the flip side it reminds me a ton of things I liked in the past (Tex Murphy, Twin Peaks, Police Quest, detective shows,etc..). Excited to see where the developers go next with this, I hope this is the start of a series or the first a large collection of smaller games. Maybe with a new murder mystery each time? Add in some more variety in gameplay and the possibilities are endless.

For 6$ this is a flippin' steal this has been one of the better, more interesting and unique games I have played so far this year. What it lacks in variety of gameplay it more than makes up for (and then some) with wonderful acting, great atmosphere and a sense that this is something special that is hopefullly spawn many more devs to take chances. If you need tons of action stay away, but if you like the stuff I have mentioned in this review give it a try!

reviewText:
Interesting non-linear crime story succeeds despite minimal interactivity
The gist: A short and minimalistic, but well-executed experiment in non-linear storytelling. Recommended if you like to piece a story together from clues. Contains no action or overt puzzles, and very little interactivity - but the intriguing narrative, competent acting, and general sense of mystery are strong enough to create an enjoyable experience for curious and open-minded players.

Her Story" is an experimental game in which you explore a murder case from 20 years before. The game gives you a database of 270 short video clips that show the victim's wife during several interviews at the police station. Gameplay consists solely of entering search terms into that database
date: and watching the clips that the search resulted in
recommended: which will give you ideas for further search terms. There is no (obvious) way to see the clips in chronological order
hoursPlayed: and you only see the wife's replies to the detective's questions. You never see or hear the detective. Your task is to understand what happened those 20 years ago
voteText: and why.\n\nI found the story well-designed and interesting to explore - it provides a good amount of detail
helpfulPercent: you learn a bit about other characters and their backgrounds
votesHelpful: and there are several revelations that kept me engaged and gave me a sense of progression. The non-linear presentation enhances the mystery (by never giving you complete information) and fosters immersion (by letting you feel like a detective exploring a set of data). The non-linearity also makes it possible to discover some very revealing bits early on
votesTotal: but the story is complex enough to not give all of its secrets away easily.\n\nThe acting of Viva Seifert is spot-on. This is not immediately obvious because her role doesn't give her many opportunities to show off - most of the time
votesFunny: she is supposed to play a realistic British middle-aged woman in a rather formal situation. But after closing the game
commentsCount: I realized that I had just watched the same single person talking monologues for 90+ minutes

column17: and without her ever giving me the impression that the scene was rehearsed. That's pretty impressive.\n\nThe game is quite short. All the clips combined amount to 95 minutes of footage

reviewText:
tl;dr -> Every witty thing I could think of was slightly spoiler-ish, so I'll leave it at: after completing this game it had me questioning my reality. 11/10 existential crisis trigger.

I received a review copy of this game and was very excited to try it because the gameplay looked novel and interesting. I was very satisfied and pleased with my experience.

If you like full-motion video (FMV) and detective work, then you will enjoy this game. Note, however, that the game is very short, and can be finished in ~1-2 hours, depending on how quick you are (and whether or not you want to complete the video database). I really hope that more games like this are released, as the execution and presentation was very well-done.

The aesthetics are great because of the short FMV clips you can watch and listen to - the presentation of the computer interface is reminiscent of old-school IBM's, adding to the immersion of being a detective" during pre-internet days. The background music is simple but nice
date: complimenting the relaxed gameplay and overall pace. The quality of the FMV clips is high
recommended: with good acting by the single story character (you only see and hear one person). I enjoyed the well-written story
hoursPlayed: however
voteText:
one interesting (and unavoidable) possibility is you getting the story in an odd order because of the nature of the gameplay (which will be explained later in the review).

Controls are simple and will mostly involve you clicking the mouse and typing search keywords (as well as tags/notes to yourself). The tutorial is presented as a readme file on the desktop and explains how to play very clearly. The "goal" of the game removes any learning curve because you are free to play at your own pace and can quit whenever you are satisfied with what you have pieced together. It is highly recommended that you have at least an average understanding of the English language to fully appreciate the game.

Gameplay consists of you using different search keywords (and strings) to call up police interview videos

You can also tag videos to help you remember details - I tagged "critical" videos and tried to group videos together to help find common themes (like frequently-occurring events or names).\n\nWhile you play

column19: as well as a clock program. For achievement hunters
column20: the mini-game and database (watch every video in the pool) ones are the most difficult to get. If you do not care about achievements

column22: even if you are watching most of the videos. Replayability is very low because you will already know the story of the game if you revisit it. I plan to get some friends to try it and watch their thought processes during the journey (especially my gf
column23: who is working to become a police officer).\n\nOverall

reviewText:
This was a solid game and worth the $5.09 I paid for it.

+ Solid story
+ Solid acting
+ Good thematic cohesion
+ Good atmosphere

- Main reveal comes a little too easily and is not terribly original
- Very simplistic gameplay
- Little replay value.

Bottom line: You should be able to tell by the trailers and description whether this is a genre you would like and, if it is, you will enjoy this game.

Extended Review:

The writing is good, better than many games, but it doesn't quite reach literary heights. I feel too often video game players are so quick to elevate game stories just because they're so often looked down on and that causes some exaggeration. It was a good story with some flaws. Telling a story completely through one-sided dialogue has its limits for how invested I become. The big reveal of the story is hardly original and borders on being a trope. Plus, it felt like I came to understand the main truth a little too quickly and easily. Some red herrings or other characters might have prolonged the mystery.

That said, there was a lot of skill in having the various parts relate to each other and tie in thematically. As I was going over the files a second time, I could see how certain phrases and events reveals a slice into the truth. This web was artfully woven in its completeness and cohesion.

The acting was well done for the most part but it really seemed like there should have been more emotion present at times, especially when certain people's fate becomes clear. The dialogue was well done overall but at times felt like it was trying a little too hard to be natural. Still, a good performance by the actress.

There truly is not much of a game. You simply query for words and unlock videos and watch them. The fun is understanding the mystery and the layers of that mystery. It would have been nice if there were documents or pictures that you could have viewed as well, to give a fuller experience (and it could have provided some misdirection to keep the mystery going).

While the database query system is a bit of a conceit, it does make it so that players will have much different experiences based on what they view and when they view it. I definitely appreciate that. Of course, there really is not much replayability, especially if you've viewed all the videos.

It was a relatively easy game to get 100% achievements on, which is nice. You can see my 100% achievement guide  here if interested.

reviewText: I cannot really tell if I can recommend this game or not. It's not a bad game and not a great one either. The idea behind is neat and the story is good. You don't need to use your brain to play it, since every keyword for searching the database can just be a random word out of a random video. It's not easy to unlock every single video (though there are tricks for that, which I used, because it's boring to just make guesses) but you don't need to anyway. I had the solution at around 30% of the the overall playtime and only continued playing to get the achievements. I think five euros is too much to pay, so take the chance when the price is low.

reviewText: It is difficult to discuss this game without inadvertantly giving away any spoilers, but I feel up to the task so I'll give it a go.  Her Story is a mystery game, but is not linier as are most story games, including most mysteries.  In this game you are given guest access to a police interview recording data base for a cold case from the 1990's and absolutely nothing more. All the video files have full transcripts, and to search for files on a given topic you enter the word you believe might help you in your investigation, and it will return all videos which have that word in it... with one problem. Your pass to the police data base is a guest pass, and therefore if your search word was over inclusive you might get 112 hits, but will only be able to view the first 5. Therefore search terms  such as it" or "was" won't be very useful whereas if you have reason to believe that she might have needed a gizmoidaphods you can enter that word and it will display all the clips containing that word
date: and since it is a less common word the results will likely be more manageable (in fact since it is a made up word I just now created
recommended: the results are likely to be null which is even more useless. But hopefully you get the point).\n\nThe game is short
hoursPlayed: but absolutely unique in concept and design. The story takes many twists and turns and harbours many surprises made all that more interesting by they are revealed to you out of order. It takes a really keen mind to take all the bits of evidence
voteText: put them in order
helpfulPercent: and come to an unasalable conclusion.\n\nThe game mirrors reality in one key way. It never tells you if you came to the right or wrong conclusion. As would be the case with any reasonable inspector whose sense of his own abilities are not over-inflated in such a case

reviewText:
A man named Simon is missing. His wife, Hannah, approaches the police for help. It's clear that not all is right with her. It's up to you to find out what happened using only a collection of video clips from police archives. It's a simple premise that opens the door for rich storytelling.

This is a game by Sam Barlow, the man responsible for Silent Hill: Shattered Memories, a game acclaimed for its dynamic storytelling. Her Story, while obviously smaller in scale, manages to live up to the same standard.

The entire game is spent searching for video clips by inputting keywords into the archive. There's some guesswork and some puzzle solving involved, but not much else. This may be too simplistic for some, but for the purposes of telling an intruiging story, that's really all that's required. Viva Seifert's performance as Hannah is exemplary, the script is expertly written, and the plot's many twists and turns will keep you interested to find out more. And when you do finally find out the truth about Hannah, you will be at once disturbed and sympathetic. This is a hard feat to do, but Sam Barlow has managed this perfectly.

This is a game for people who love a good story. Nothing more, and nothing less. Suffice to say, if you need explosions on your screen every few seconds in order to be happy playing a video game, this game is not for you.

Another thing to note is that this game is not very long. I managed to reach the end in a few hours. Getting all of the achievements takes quite a bit longer, but either way, you're still getting your money's worth.

All in all, I am amazed at what an indie developer, armed with only a small budget and determination, can accomplish.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: Pronoun game: the game My biggest worry when it comes to games that focus on a narrative and the reason, I think, why so many people respond so negatively to most of them, is that their stories or philosophies are spoonfed to the player without any means of engaging with them. Either they lack an  active component at all, or it's completely disjointed from the story and we get the notorious 'lugoscababib discobiscuits'. Then there are games that get the narrative thing right and give the venue for engagement without falling into constraints of traditional game mechanics like Papers, Please, Gone Home (though I know it's too passive for some people) or MLA parts of Talos Principle. I was happy to discover that Her Story belongs to the second category.  It is surprisingly engrossing for something has the player watch a police interrogation pieced into hundreds video clips, which is the only storytelling medium this game employs. Players have  no significant role in the story (not explicitly at any rate) and yet, thanks to non-linearity added by the interactive dimension, what could have been just just above avarage short film if shown from beginning to end, is a truly great detective/mystery game.\n85/100

reviewText:
Her Story explores new areas for video games as powerful means of storytelling. No other media can unfold a nonlinear narrative as uniquely as Her Story does.

The game is meticously written, allowing everybody's playthrough to be a bit different but still ensuring that whichever way you choose, you will meet intriguing riddles to solve to put all of the puzzle pieces together. Short clips are made in a way of either revealing tiny bits of the story or sending you down the wrong path.

In Her Story I have found precisely the unrepeatable experience I look for in video games. Its only (minor) handicap is the decrease in enjoyment upon replays. But then again, I did deem it unrepeatable.

4.5 / 5

reviewText:
This game isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea and I can understand that.

You make very little choices and you don't really HAVE to solve anything and infact the whole game aspect of it kind of takes place as realization in your own mind. I can see how some people might get bored because other than hunting down keywords, you are essentially just watching videos.

However, if you like puzzles and crime mysteries its worth it to give this game a shot. I went through pages of notes listening to the story, drawing conclusions and loved the way the story is presented to you in a shuffled matter where you are slowly piecing together the truth in your head.

Cons:
Can be a little tedious. I eventually stopped using the tag system at all and just took notes of keywords as if I was listening to the interviews myself and it helped speed up the process. This eventually turned into flow charts of different ideas. Flow charts are definately not something many gamers look forward to.

Its possible to get to the conclusion of the plot while bypassing all the filler. Then, to see the end of the game, you have to go back and find all that filler through keywords you might have missed. Trying to follow the story by using keywords that go with the flow of the story might help to prevent this.

Pros:

Believe it or not, it's realistic. I actually had to organize police interviews for my local PD one summer and, funny enough, this was extremely similar for writing out reports.

Great story. If you like shows like Law and Order and other crime dramas, you would probably like the way this unfolds. Its dark, unsettling, and creepy.

Good acting. Even though you are essentially looking at one actor the entire time she still keeps it dynamic and interesting

In conclusion, this game would be a good fit if you have a personality type that is patient and logical with a knack for getting to the truth of the matter. If you bore quickly and need something faster-paced then this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
I'll start by conceding that this game is definitely not for everyone, especially given that it is fairly simplistic.

To me, the concept is brilliant. The appearance and feel of the game itself was really immersive for me: the ambient sound, mouse and keyboard sounds, the appearance of an old CRT monitor.

The story was very interesting, though I don't think that it was necessary to cut the clips to be so short. That being said, I did enjoy the process of searching the database to find ALL of the videos, even though I know that this is what a lot of reviewers disliked, finding it tedious.

All in all, I really liked this game and I recommend it, but really think of how much you'd really enjoy searching for 271 short videos using nothing buy keywords in a database that only shows 5 results at a time.

reviewText: Fun little detective game. The game is basically a simple text adventure, where you type in keywords to unlock video clips, so the game play is mostly in you working out the sequence of events and lines of questioning (you'll probably want to keep some notes!). Lots of little clues throughout so possible to solve quite early on if you pick up on certain things. Short but enjoyable.

reviewText: After getting the hang of using useful search terms to narrow down clips, this game became very intriguing. Unraveling the story clip by clip and uncovering the background of the character(s) became addicting. The twist at the end is something I wasn't expecting at all, but if you've uncovered enough clips before you log off it makes complete sense.\n\n5$ for this game is the perfect price, once you've unlocked all of the clips there isn't much replay value, unless you missed an achievement or want to chronologically watch the clips. Overall, I highly recommend this game if you enjoy uncovering and piecing together stories. I've never played a game like this and wish there were more like it.

reviewText:
Absolutely brilliant. I stayed up all night following rabbit trails, and now I'm done, it's still staying with me.

It's a difficult game to review without spoilering. All I can say is that it's the only game that actually made me feel like I was investigating--not looking for hideen objects, not being guided down a path by game designers, but following my own guesses and clues and gumptions. In the end, the hotly debated solution wasn't the point so muc as the journey of getting there.

The interface was perfect, the storytelling unique and effective, and the acting was incredible. This is one of the games that will always stay with me as a point of comparison. 10/10

(As an aside, unlike many reviewers, I have fond memories of FMV games like Frankenstein: Through the Eyes of the Monster. But this is a far better use of video.)

reviewText: Summary: For the price of a DVD you get a game that is unique, engaging and a triumph of deign.\n\nGame" is a multifaceted term
date: but even then it should be applied loosely to Her Story. It is not so much a game as an experience. You
hoursPlayed:
piece together a story through a series of video clips stored in an achieved database. You use search terms to bring up results of which only five are accessible. Having watched more clips you refine your search and over time piece together a compelling story.

What makes Her Story interesting is the moments of understanding as you unravel another layer of the story. It is both satisfying and perplexing as each reveal creates more questions.

The acting is decent and nuanced enough for you to spot things you missed on you initial run through. The writing is good as well; the final jigsaw picture interesting and intriguing. However the genius of Her Story is in the design. The achievement of structuring the writing so that it allows the narrative to develop in a satisfying and engaging way while also accommodating the multiple search paths thousands of different players is incredible. The unique design is worth the cost as it is a singular experience.

Definitely recommended."

reviewText:
You are given a creepy 90s terminal with a video search program. The search results returned are all videos of the same woman being interrogated. The goal of the game is to find as many video clips as possible by entering the correct search queries.

As you progress, you'll probably be asking these questions: Who is she? Why is she being interrogated? Has a crime been committed? Who is actually using the terminal?

If you pay attention you'll be able to solve the mystery.

One of the best parts of this game is the suspenseful background music. It will change to fit the mood as you encounter secret after secret.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of everything involving the detective/mystery genre this was a must buy for me. I finished the game relatively quickly, not what I was hoping.
This game covers a lot which I didn't expect and it was a beautiful surprise. E.g. there are multiple 1-3 second clips of just her saying Yes" and "No" and you can see how different they are by the way she stresses the words. Simply the variety of clips and the clever answers you really understand the character.

To sum up the experience:
- Didn't need a lot of notes as a person who read a lot of crime novels and such
date: so figuring out the ending was easy.\n- Even though I finished it fast
recommended: the game is a bold step to try and I would like to applaud the developer for taking the plunge because it worked out perfectly.\n- Also a big bow to the main gal (Viva Seifert) and her acting. (Congratulations on the Best Performance award at The Game Awards 2015
hoursPlayed: you deserved it.)"

reviewText:
Games make life vastly more simple then they really are. Good Vs Evil, Princesses and evil tyrants. It's all very black and white usually in video games, then Her Story comes along and challenges those ideas. At it's root, Her story is a simple game but one that tells an incredibly powerful story that is delivered by incredible story telling and acting. This is a puzzle of a story, one that can be approached and put together in multiple ways. Individual players will have a unique experiences and one play session will move about things in different ways. That is the brilliance and fun of Her Story, unraveling this puzzle, piece by piece. If you are looking for something flashy and feature rich, you might not enjoy Her Story. It's a simple game but what it does have it delivers in great fashion. The music, the atmosphere, and most of all the portrayal of our main characters. This is a tale that has many twists and turns and puts many ideas and thoughts into your head. I started playing this and couldn't stop playing until the end, which left me with more questions then answers, but not in a bad way. It makes you think and that is what I loved about it.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/xPJMWxXtI9Q
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

All of these videos are fragments of on tape interviews that were conducted with a young woman who sometimes acts very shy and meek...then other times very playful and cynical... and the more keywords you plug into the search, the more videos and pieces of the story you get until you find out everything. reviewText:
I'll start by conceding that this game is definitely not for everyone, especially given that it is fairly simplistic.

To me, the concept is brilliant. The appearance and feel of the game itself was really immersive for me: the ambient sound, mouse and keyboard sounds, the appearance of an old CRT monitor.

The story was very interesting, though I don't think that it was necessary to cut the clips to be so short. That being said, I did enjoy the process of searching the database to find ALL of the videos, even though I know that this is what a lot of reviewers disliked, finding it tedious.

All in all, I really liked this game and I recommend it, but really think of how much you'd really enjoy searching for 271 short videos using nothing buy keywords in a database that only shows 5 results at a time.

reviewText:
First Impression, Subject to Change. very mild spoiler, may contain massive spoiler (depends).

TL;DR: A jigsaw puzzle for people who like to listen rather than talk. The number of pieces and how they fit together is fixed. Not a detective game (see below). The game does not seem to have an (obvious) agenda.

The game is based on a simple mechanic. The game is akin to a jigsaw puzzle, where the pieces consist of video tape recordings of several interviews. Each piece is associated with a date, and certain words. By searching for the words, you get a list of up to five pieces that you can choose from.

The game is not a detective game, because all you have is the recordings. You don't have any hard information, and you cannot compare the statements made to any facts or other surrounding information.

By finding the right words, it appears possible to draw every single piece of the puzzle from the stack. In other words, the   'truth' of the game is fixed, and independent of player choice. For this reason, I consider the game a somewhat missed opportunity.

[mild spoiler below]

The game has a theme of mirroring, reflections, and watching (back), which I really enjoyed. I would've liked to see this themed explored more radically. Instead of a single set of pieces, the game could adjust what pieces would be available to the player based on the search terms selected. This would make the search history into a network of association, that would reflect on the player, rather than the subject in the videos. Instead of trying to fit the jigsaw together, we would have a player building a map of their own associations. A reflective surface for the player to see.

Such a  mechanic could lead to some very interesting discussions with other players after the playthru, as they would have different experiences, and different ideas about who dunnit and why (the game may actually have this property, this is an early review).

I recommend the game to people who enjoy listening rather than talking.

reviewText:
I'm usually intrigued but very disappointed with games that proclaim strong story via unconventional means. I hated Dear Esther and didn't much care for The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. On the other hand, I adored Gone Home. For me, the story had better be damn good (which DE and TVoEC were not) and the game mechanics should either be fluid (not true in DE) or worth the trouble (not true in TVoEC).

Her Story is fluid and simple, but built around an intriguing premise: Figure out what the heck is going on, based on the interviews with this woman after her husband goes missing. It's confusing and sometimes frustrating, but ultimately worth it. The story is thoughtful and satisfying, and the gameplay is very very basic.

This last part is very important. As Brian Upton explained on a recent episode of the podcast The Dork Forest, figuring out a complicated game is a kind of story decoding in itself. As a result, piecing together a complicated story at the same time is aggravating, because it's hard to play two games at once".

Her Story does a superb job of dodging this trap by making the gameplay as simple as possible. The focus is entirely on the story
recommended: and the game is much better for it.\n\nMy one complaint is the unsatisfying finish. I can't explain without giving spoilers
hoursPlayed: but suffice it to say that I wanted something a little more concrete and/or rewarding when I got done. (I felt the same way when I finished MYST.)\n\nMaybe this is just an unfair expectation from standard video game structures
voteText: but as Brent Knowles (lead designer for Dragon Age: Origins) said: "When I invest a hundred hours into a game
helpfulPercent: I need to walk away feeling like a hero." (The corollary for me is that when I invest three hours into a game
votesHelpful: I need to walk away feeling satisfied.)\n\nStill
votesTotal: I recommend this strongly
votesFunny: and proclaim it to be a rare example of unusual game mechanics combined with intriguing story done right."

reviewText:
Her Story is a crime story where you are challenged to figure out what happened. You are sitting at an old computer with a search program that access a series of recorded interviews. All of them are of her and you become a detective, trying to piece together her story from this short video segments.

The trick is that you can't access these in order. They are sorted by keywords. This makes the game feel something like the great text adventure games of old. From the segments you watch you have to figure out what you want to search for next. So in this case everyone's game will play out differently.

While I got to an ending of sorts after a couple of hours, I know there are a lot of segments I haven't seen. I plan on spending more time with the game, refining my investigative technique, and therefore seeing much of what I've missed. One thing in particular is nagging at the back of my mind that I particularly want to reach a resolution on.

If you only want to play games with a lot of action, you probably already know Her Story isn't for you. But if you a looking for a game where story is important and you enjoy the challenge of connecting the dots, I recommend you pick up Her Story. For $6 it's a great deal, only made better by the current 10% discount.

piece together a story through a series of video clips stored in an achieved database. You use search terms to bring up results of which only five are accessible. Having watched more clips you refine your search and over time piece together a compelling story.

What makes Her Story interesting is the moments of understanding as you unravel another layer of the story. It is both satisfying and perplexing as each reveal creates more questions.

The acting is decent and nuanced enough for you to spot things you missed on you initial run through. The writing is good as well; the final jigsaw picture interesting and intriguing. However the genius of Her Story is in the design. The achievement of structuring the writing so that it allows the narrative to develop in a satisfying and engaging way while also accommodating the multiple search paths thousands of different players is incredible. The unique design is worth the cost as it is a singular experience.

Definitely recommended."

reviewText:
A very creative gameplay mechanic, some fantastic acting by Viva Seifert and a very reasonable price makes this game absolutely recommendable. Anyone that wants to experience something absolutely experimental must try this game out.

Also, Sam Barlow's previous game Silent Hill: Shattered Memories was amazing and after seeing this game be this good, I'm looking forward to his next project.

Edit: Alright, so Polygon just chose this game as their 2016 Game of the Year. While I completely respect their decision, I'm not sure what they mean when they say that this is an incredible Mystery Novel. I disagree that the game's story is that good of a murder mystery. I actually thought the overall story was pretty stupid and I had a hard time suspending my disbelief multiple times.

The way you uncover that story however is a different matter. I believe that the most powerful aspect of this game is that you're constantly psychoanalysing her and trying to figure out some information that you're deliberately not given. When it turns out you've been right all along, it feels pretty good. So manage your expectations, I guess.

reviewText:
Her Story
This review was last edited when I had completed enough of the game that I believed I understood what had actually gone on.

Short ReviewAn innovative FMV game with a fairly minimalistic interface based largely around watching short video clips of a woman being interviewed in 1994 in relation to a disappearance. You access the video clips by typing in key words and so do not necessarily view the videos in a coherent order. It is up to you to piece together from these video clips what actually happened.

Long Review
I'm not sure I can expand much on the short review other than to say this is my first FMV game which may explain why I was so taken with it as the genre is new and exciting" to me.

I thought the acting was decent and the dialogue was engaging

reviewText:
TL;DR - 80-90s retro fun. Will prove you wrong if you think FMV games couldn't ever be good. Check out 5 seconds of playthrough if unsure.
NOTE: Story isn't written in this review as game is reliant on mysterious plot.

For those unfamiliar, FMV stands for full motion video where you are playing a game that is based primarily/largely on the usage of pre-recorded video clips. Though it is no longer a frequented genre in video gaming, during the 90s, FMV games on CDs would often lead me into the darkened halls of many a thrilling Sherlockian mystery adventure. Unfortunately the majority of FMV games were downright awful. Pre-recorded videos with a small quantity of scenes by actual actors caused the a gaming experience to feel boxed in. Astoundingly, Her Story does the exact opposite while still being as classically FMV as FMV games go. It displays FMV like a shield of pride with the added old school touches being tasteful to a tee. As the game is turned on"
date: the screen whirring into action like any early 90s PC would
recommended: making the familiar creaking and croaking
hoursPlayed: players are introduced to their in-game desktop. The thick 90s computer monitor flares a little and in its reflection can be seen the old tube shaped fluorescent lamps that were common fixtures in most public buildings back then
voteText: flickering and popping from time to time. It is like playing a game in the past without the annoying performance issues. The glare on screen where you can see a better reflection towards the end made me jump a little here and there. It is fabulous as a "moodsetter" like many of the other suppositious yet important details that worked towards the game's impressive little plot. In addition to the other details
helpfulPercent: the background music between searches where players are looking at the desktop felt like a good touch and appropriate in terms of guiding players (reacts to clips/progress etc). There is such an abundance of both subsidiary and essential detail in this game that I'd be happy with the mere nostalgia prompting ambiance. It is an added bonus
votesHelpful: which isn't too recurrent in indie games these days where there is a deficiency in either style or story
votesTotal: that makes Her Story such a good FMV. It differs because players can feel as if they are in control as every person works towards the ending down a differing path depending on how they decide to investigate which is conducted solely by which searches are brought up how and when. The secret to any game that lacks the variety and freedom of choice by "genre default"
votesFunny: is to give the player as much control as possible within the walls of that rigid reality. Within the uncomplicated
commentsCount: search - watch - find clues - check Db repertoire
column16: players are given room to stretch and investigate on their own. The mastery is in the details so it is crucial to pay attention. Everything is told methodically and the acting that seems off in places makes much more sense once you piece the evidence and videos together. You are the "detective".\n\nThis superlative story told through proficient acting by the talented Viva Seifert (also musician/former British gymnast) weaves a surprisingly thick plot into a very lugubrious tale and the eerie horrors of the truth become more evident the more you unveil. The "wifey killed him" synopsis we are inclined to linger on in theory is not as discernible in-game as you'd imagine and it'll keep you guessing and alarm you at several progression points. It'll make your thoughts run wild but mostly you'll be wrong with those assumptions until you get the whole picture
column17:
as in as close to 100% off the clips as you can. The short clips have a role in that you're piecing together a very large puzzle. The splintered pieces of a total 7 interviews leaving you with 271 videos spanning between mere seconds to a couple of minutes will feel jumbled up so receiving the story in abstruse titbits as such makes you feel like your own little Jessica Fletcher and adds to the anticipation of piecing everything together. If possible I imagine it would be a fun "couch co-op" game for an afternoon in with a friend/SO taking notes and guessing the story together (plot contains mature content).

Other interesting things:
- Doesn't stop running while you do other things so you can open up your notepad and type there if you'd rather that over pen and paper
- Search history is helpful. Anti-Glare Filter is a nice touch. Yellow subtitles are very British.
- The odd title is actually fittingly chosen
- Database Checker on your desktop screen will display the overall progress you make
column18: creating a timeline for your discoveries so investigation will be smoother\n- Each keyword brings up 5 clips at most (excluding default keyword*). Keep a list of words that stick out in clips and if you get too stuck
column19:
use default keyword to bring up whole Db

*Default keyword: BLANK Using the default is not optimal. Uncovering new snippets in turn revealing new clues/plots urging you to solve the case yourself is most of the fun.

TIP: All clips found will have the default keyword in its details. I assigned a number for every new top she wore. Examples: BLANK5
column20: BLANK1 etc... An easier method is just deleting the whole keyword for each clip watched
column21: never to return. ;)\n\nThough the sweet yet unnerving finale didn't feel as inspired
column22: the wrap up was still nicely done. People who are new to FMV games may find it harder to get into
column23: but it has a good depth of story to tell for the short game (3-4 hrs) that it is and I recommend it to people who enjoy a good tale. Chances are it's either going to feel like something new and interesting or old school and nostalgic.\n\nBought game on dev's site: $4.99 (Steam key + DRM free version)."

reviewText:
I don't dislike this game... But I wouldn't recommend it to anybody.

The acting is a little over dramatized, sure, but the story is pretty well written, it has a few twists, and there's a lot of subtlety I could see were clues for the ending you're supposed to discover at the end.

The problem was the end for me I discovered in about 30 minutes of gameplay.

Because ALL the footage is available from the start, you can choose enough search queries and gather all the information you need to find the big 3 plot twists far too quickly.

The game isn't *bad*, it's a story you unlock by searching for more information. Starting with a little and working your way up. The problem is in it's execution. Once you know the end of the story, everything else is just details.

I think if they'd figured out some way to lock the content... perhaps unlocking interviews 2 at a time or something, would give you more progression, extend the gameplay, and leave the twist endings for the end. But as it happens there's very little gameplay for what you can see had a lot of effort put into it.

If a sequel were made adressing this one fatal issue, I'd buy it.

You think you understand what happened, and then you find another link that turns it all upside down.

It's hard to say anything about this game without detracting from the experience.

Highly recommend."

reviewText:
I have a soft spot for the multimedia and FMV PC adventure games of the early and mid-nineties. Many were just sh*t with bad gameplay and/or were trying way too hard to be movies instead of being confident in the medium itself (I mean did you ever see Ripper's cast? Christopher Walken, Burgess Meredith, Paul Giamatti, etc., it really wanted to be  a Hollywood movie badly) But despite their sheer flaws a good number tried to push the envelope to make games something more than just seeing numbers go up. They were weird as hell like Bad Day at the Midway, Phantasmagoria 2, and The Dark Eye, and some were way ahead of their time such as MODE (Go look up supergreatfriendâ€™s LP of it on YouTube, itâ€™s a great LP for a great game) or just overall good like Tex Murphy and Gabriel Knight 2. Even if they sucked they tended to be creative and by the turn of the 2000â€™s that oddball spark kind of died. Her Story is the spiritual successor to those games, a creative game that pushes what a game could do in a new direction, but without any of its predecessorsâ€™ flaws.

Her Story, is created by Sam Barlow, the writer of Silent Hill Shattered Memories. I love the Silent Hill games  and I played SM when it first came out, it stands as easily rivaling the original trilogy in several ways in my eyes and, in retrospect, it also trail blazed the modern style of adventure games which led to games like Walking Dead, Life is Strange, and Kentucky Route Zero, which I all love. So I thought it would be a safe bet to preorder this game and boy was I not mistaken.

Her Story is a game dripping with atmosphere, the gameâ€™s UI is an old Windows 95 era computer complete with screen glare. You play the role of an investigator searching the policeâ€™s archives on a murder in 1994 of a man and the ensuing interviews with his widowed wife. The interview videos are all cut up into small clips and you have to use the archive search to type in keywords to find clips. Because of this you pick up bits of the story one piece at a time, listening to what the woman says for anything possibly notable. This is enthralling and it also insures that not everyone will go through the game the same way. The writing is really great considering how itâ€™s told and how tricky it must be to make sure everything is consistent. Unlike many of her FMV actor predecessors, the actress who plays the woman does a really good job, one that you will appreciate more when you dig deeper into the game. It wouldnâ€™t be nearly as good if it were just some video game avatar instead of a real person.

Overall Her Story is another shining star in how do quality video game narratives and it should rightfully become a classic. Anyone who has interest in this should buy it this instant, the asking price is pretty much a steal. More games should take inspiration from this game.

reviewText:
Her Story is a game where you watch snippets of video, ranging from a few seconds to a couple of minutes each, of a woman being interrogated by the police regarding the murder of her husband.

Your job is to piece together the story.  You do this by searching for key words, which will then pop up new, unwatched videos.  The more videos you watch, the more clues you get as to what to search for, but also as to what happened in the story.

The videos are not in any order, although each one does have a date and a time stamp, so it is possible to piece them together chronologically if you wish.

There are well over 200 videos in all.  The beauty of this game is that no person will play it exactly the same way as anyone else.  Each person will watch the videos in a different order, but ultimately will get a clear picture as to what happened so long as they find enough videos and think about what they've learned.

I can't stress enough the brilliance of this game design.  Sam Barlow really set the bar high for what a thinking man's game can be.  Once you start to learn some of the twists in the plot you'll be glued to the screen, trying to unearth that next video that will shed more light on what's going on.

To top it all off, there are a couple of different theories on what the story is actually about, it's up to you as the player to decide for yourself which one is actually true.

Viva Seiffert, the actress, is amazing, and the music is perfect.  This is absolutely a must-have game.  No one's ever done anything quite like it.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's a really bittersweet experience. The story, a murder story, is interesting, and hooks you up really good. But when I finished it, I didn't understood what happened. At all. And that's a hint something went wrong somehow.
The big questions you are trying to investigate are left unasnwered. While investigating you made some theories in your head, and at the end, they are still valid. Everybody has its own favorite theory, just head to forums and find it full of clueless people looking for answers, and quite some clueless people pretending they have the answers.
The game is either left open for good, or maybe it's us mere mortals not being able to interpret the clues properly. Anyway, as a objective sampling, I think it's a bad sign.
Do I recomend this game? It's a difficult answer. It's been quite enjoyable time while it lasted, plus some more time discussing trying to figure it out... but in the end I got quite a bitter taste realizing the problem i was trying to solve just had no solution.
One good bonus: it take quite a courage to try out something as different as this game.

reviewText: I wouldn't exactly call this a game in the traditional sense, but it is a wonderful interactive experience.  You have access to a computer database containing video recorded answers to questions from 7 different interviews with a person of interest. Every word she says is documented and can be searched for, which is how you unlock additional files. It's up to you to figure out what went on. There is no set 'end.' The end comes when you are satisfied with your understanding of the case.  You do not need to unlock every single file to fully understand what is going on, but I would recommend it for the full experience.

reviewText:
If you are interested in the different ways a game and it's narrative can be presented then this is an essential purchase -
This isn't about solving a mystery but getting the whole story - and paying attention to get access to that story.

Get a pen and paper because you will stack up the keywords to search for and bit by bit reveal the story - If I had one criticism it was a particular search I did early on revealed a lot of the end part of the interviews, but that still doesn't detract from the telling of a tale. (in a sort of self generated pulp fiction mixed up timeline probably unique to each player).

Highly recommended!

Letâ€™s try to do this without spoilersâ€¦

Her is incredible.

You access a police database with 90â€™s recordings of a woman being interrogated about the death of her husband. Observe, listen and type what you pick up on the search engine to find more videos. Then, you fall down the rabbit hole as you form your own theories about what happened.

And it starts unraveling before you. Itâ€™s so enthralling that you canâ€™t stop. The story, the acting, the mistery is so well done - Itâ€™s the Memento of games. Yes, itâ€™s only like 2 hours of gameplay. But thatâ€™s the lenght of a movie and for 6 bucks! Totally worth it.

reviewText:
This isn't a game where you're trying to win, this is a game where you're trying to find out the truth. I got sweep up in finding more pieces to the story and learning about what I can about this woman's life and the mystery surrounding it that i didn't even notice how long I've been playing it.

This game isn't going to be for everyone since it is pretty much punching in words into a search engine and watching videos out of order. You're not solving a crime so much as you're trying to understand why and how things happened through her interviews. The story is a bit of soap opera plot but the way its presented and how the player goes about unrevealing the order of events makes you want to dig deeper for more clips.

If I do have some complaints, its that if you're a completionist, finding the smaller clips once you've pretty much watched all the bigger, more narritive clips can be tedious. There is also isn't an option once you've found all the clips to watch an edit of all of them in order (unless I missed finding that option.) Also, unless I missed something, we don't learn what happened to her after these interviews.

Overall, if you're someone who loves stories in video games and are open to new forms of interactive narratives, I would recommend this game.
voteText: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Let me preface this by stating that this is not a game for everyone. The gameplay is entirely focused around the use of a search engine to enable the player to watch videos (in full FMV glory). There is no real way to lose, nor is there any clear objective. Instead, the player is left to figure out what is happening on their own, with only their keyboard and a database of videos. The story is entirely non-linear, and allows the player to chart their own path through the narrative. You watch a clip, you form an opinion. You watch another clip, and that previous opinion is completely changed. The path I found through the story involved plenty of twists and turns, shattering my preconcieved notions, and ultimately creating a memorable experience. Your path could be a linear telling (though it would be very unlikely) or it could be nonlinear string of nonsequiters. Forming the plot is the experience, so make sure you avoid spoilers, though do know that the story is well-written and captivating. It will probably leave lingering questions, and that's ok.\n\nBesides the story itself, The acting by Viva Seifert is great, and not just for an FMV game. The aesthetic is simple, but effective, emulating a late 90's, early 2000's computer. The sparse soundtrack is effective when it plays, and as effective when it doesn't. If you are looking for a unique, intriguing, and effective use of experimental storytelling in gaming, then look no further. Her Story is more than worth the $6 asking price, and should be played by anyone with an open mind.

reviewText: TL;DR: Great FMV-based game where the mystery unravels differently for each player, depending on the way they choose to investigate the material.\n\nIn Her Story" you are presented with a first person view of a monitor from which you can access a database of video clips from various interviews relating to a particular individual that was under investigation in the year 1994. You are not given a pretext for why or how you should proceed. You are driven by your own curiosity. The game presents you with a few starter clips
date: from which your investigation can head in any direction you wish. The way this proceeds is via tags or keywords.\n\nEvery clip (which are all quite short
recommended: mostly <1 minute) is tagged with several keywords related to what is being said in that clip. For every keyword that you search
hoursPlayed: you will be presented with all clips that contain that keyword
voteText: with the caveat that you'd only get access to five clips (seemingly
helpfulPercent: the ones most relevant to that keyword). You never hear the questions that are given to the individual
votesHelpful: only her answers. This is an interesting form of story exploration as you have to infer the line of questioning from the context.\n\nThe way you choose to search the database will greatly change your experience. You might figure out the mystery early on
votesTotal: or you might only understand the story after a lot of investigation. It was very entertaining to get these snippets out of context and chronological order and having to tie it all together in my head. Despite the way that the story was presented
votesFunny: I never found it really frustrating as some other games that have done this form of storytelling before. I guess it had to do with the good writing
commentsCount: and the trimmed up story... almost all what is said is relevant and doesn't feel like fluff. Props to the actor who did a convincing job saying these all these lines to the camera
column16: it must not have been easy! Finding the right keywords to use was entertaining and had a puzzle-like feel to it. You have to be attentive and jot down keywords that might be relevant while listening and then try to search for them. It was very satisfying to see how one seemingly innocuous keyword opened up a series of relevation to me. It will be a different experience to everyone who plays it! I suggest playing in one sitting to keep things fresh in your mind (or
column17: you can add clips of interest to a playlist of sorts for easy access later). Four to five hours of playtime.\n\nNote: I managed to get almost all the clips on my playthrough
column18: but it gets tedious to find them all towards the end. It turns out there are a few clips that you are very unlikely to come across normally so do not stress about it you will be able to view them after completion."

reviewText: I have always been a fan of good storytelling in any medium, whether it is a video game, movie, or even a song. Adventure games and RPG games interests me the most because of its stories. Her Story is one of those games with a good story to tell. A woman is interviewed seven times by the police about her husband and we play as someone who is searching through an old database of these videos. For people who likes their game to be more fast paced, this is definitely not for them. The gameplay only revolves around typing key words to find videos of this woman's interview. Since we will be typing the key word ourselves, the videos will be shown at random regardless of chronology based on the key word we enter. We will form the story ourselves by making sense of all the videos (of which there are literally hundreds) and connecting the story in our heads. This game works best if you keep a pen and paper next to you to write all the possible key words to try. The experience is very nice and a throwback to old school adventure games.\n\nThe feeling of playing this game reminded me of playing Gone Home and Analogue a Hate Story/Hate Plus, especially Analogue a Hate Story and its sequel. In Analogue you're also required to read all of the text in an abandoned spaceship. The feeling of watching a story unfold is also reminiscent of Gone Home. The twist of Her Story is not that surprising and you'll probably figure it out within the first one or two hours of playing, but that is not the point. Watching the story unfolds and piercing together all the clues is what makes this game. The acting of the actress is also really really good. In summary, this is a good game with a good story and a unique way of playing that I really really liked. The story and twist is not as good as Analogue a Hate Story, but overall Her Story is worth your time, especially since it didn't take very long to finish.

reviewText:
A harrowing game. I hate horror games, as jump scares and spooky ambience get to me really quickly. This is not a horror game, but hits a few marks. I think it's all in her eyes. Whoever this actress is, she is fantastic and really terrifying. I kept hoping she wouldn't look directly into the camera.

The game is really just watching video clips, and finding the clips themselves is more like busywork than gameplay, but watching the clips themselves in this form is incredible. Somehow taking a literally linear framework - a set of 7 interviews - and turning into your own interpretation of a story, it's incredible. I mean you could see the 'ending' of this game in one keyword search, but it's incredibly unlikely.

This game made me think about a bunch of stuff no game ever has gotten near. I don't know if it could work as a genre, but Her Story" is an incredible experimental game I wish I could forget and play over again."

reviewText:
It's an FMV game, so you're playing an Indie Narrative Simulator, and while that might put a lot of people off, along with the name, which is unfortunate, as it has political baggage the game doesn't carry.

There is little to no mystery in this game.  If you're looking to solve a mystery, you may get bored very quickly, but if you like sifting through clips to complete a story in its entirety, hoping to find some glimmer of secret information, to put the pieces together, you will love this.

There is little to no 'game'.  It's interactive fiction.  You're entering words into a search database and sifting through clips of interviews.  So buyer beware, but I loved it....and I generally HATE Indie Narrative Simulators.

So I bought this on sale, only $5.99 which is a good thing because I haven't been able to play it. When I attempt to play a video all I get is some audio, no video appears. I attempted to troubleshoot this through verifying game cache as well as using the internet to find that many others are experiencing similiar if not more severe issues.

This annoys me greatly as although it was a cheap game i'm still paying for a product none the less and that product has not been provided to me. My computer easily meets the requirements and whilst purchasing the game at no point was I adivsed the game was still essentially in a beta and that bugs were common.

Now I tottally understand why this game has bugs and stuff, its an indie game and the makers don't have the recources, but all i'm looking for is a warning maybe? When I see a game on steam i expect it to be delivered the way it is advertised.

Sorry about this. Some versions of Windows have this problem because they're don't include an MPEG4 codec. Other players have had success using the K-Lite codec pack
date: but I'm told this is often full of spyware so won't recommend this to anyone unless they're comfortable with something like that."\n\nIt was great that I got a reply but i'm essentially being told here that even though I have paid for the right to download and play this game

it will be unplayable until I download a third party program that may or may not be rife with spyware.
