reviewText:
After the Y2K, seven video interviews of a lady get fragmented into hundreds of clips. Your task is to uncover the truth by searching for keywords and getting results from the computer's automatic transcription. YouTube should really adopt that tech as the transcription is spot on.

The game doesn't explain much more than this. By watching the clips, you uncover pieces of the story and find more keywords to try, like names of people or words that you think she used elsewhere. Search results are limited by 5 at a time, so you're forced to narrow searches down in some cases. This limited and unstructured stream of information makes for an unconventional experience. Fitting the pieces together and discovering the truth on your own was very rewarding to me.

Some were turned off by the at times awkward acting and some of the story's twists. I can see where they're coming from, but overall I thought this was a very enjoyable experience. The range of emotion from the actress is pretty impressive, and the story has enough depth that I could spend four hours looking for every clip to make sure I didn't miss anything!

reviewText:
A fascinating bit of narrative-driven gameplay. The premisse is fairly simple; you have access to an old computer loaded with small videoclips taken from 7 different interrogations related to a murder in the mid 90's. Unfortunately, they are not catalogued properly, and to find them, you have to search for keywords. What you'll find, are these videos of a woman being questioned, and ultimately its up to you to make up your own mind on what transpired.

The game isn't so much about following the proceedings and using evidence to affect the narrative, but rather experience these interrogations in a fragmented state - and piece them together in your own mind to form a coherent narrative.

Such as it is, the story is dark, creepy, tragic and JUST vague enough to leave me questioning my own interpretation - even after having watched all the clips, both in and out of order. If you can look past the lack of traditional" gameplay
date: the experience is a brilliant example of what makes this artform unique.\n\nHer Story has a strong vision
hoursPlayed: a powerful narrative

reviewText: An utterly fascinating way to tell a story that could only have been done as a video game. The setup is simple, you're just accessing a police database of interviews of a woman about the murder of her husband. But each clip is short and can only be found by typing in the right keywords. The more you watch the more ways you find to further investigate the whole story.\n\nWhile there are achievements, the real exciting moments are when you start connecting the dots of the story in your head which then give context to clips you've previously watched. The game does have a point where it ends" and it brings with it another further revelation that nicely gives more context the game's setup
date: but you'll probably want to dive back in to find the story bits you missed.\n\nA truly unique game that's well executed

reviewText:
This is the game the Sega CD should've had, though maybe it would not have had the processing power to handle saving videos to a queue or saving a log of one word searches...

Here's the thing, I like twitch games but when it comes to more story based games I ...frankly, want less traditional gameplay and more story. The developers wanted to make a detective game on a shoestring budget and the budget informed the decisions to make a more compelling experience than if they had a ten million dollar budget for a 3d adventure game...

so i'm sure i missed a lot but after one sit down I think i get the storyline, and it's clever. the acting is solid and there's definitely something here in terms of gameplay and presentation that is compelling enough for it to workif the creators want to tread here again.

reviewText: I don't need to describe what this game is about, enough reviews do that. They flounder over how interesting it is and how it makes you feel like a real detective. Well, no.. it doesn't. You have no goal other than to type in search words to unlock all the clips, and when you've finally done that, the game doesn't even offer you a way to view them all in order so you could maybe make more sense of it all (you can load the videos up in a video player and watch them yourself, but still.. I don't get why this isn't an in-game option once you've unlocked all the clips). I also didn't like how the clips cut out the questions being asked. That would have been a nice addition to add as a complete game reward. But no, this falls a bit flat for me. It's over-hyped right now. I kept seeing reviews pop up in my feeds about how great it was, so I caved and bought it. Sadly it took me more than 2 hours to beat (barely), but I'm still going to request a refund. I wouldn't recommend this to friends to buy, I'd more likely suggest that it is interesting" but tell them to go watch a video of it on YouTube instead of spending money on it."

reviewText: Her story is an indie game from Sam Barlow the designer for Silent Hill Shattered memories and sees you navigate an old computer database trying to find out information on an old murder case from 1994. The database is a mess and without the ability to view the whole interview you must instead search for clips by searching for words that appear in the transcripts.\n\nFor example if choosing a term such as Speeding" or "witness" appears in the transcript of one or more clips in the database
date:
they are shown to you for viewing. You can only see 5 clips at a time so this encourages you to search for more obscure terms as you try and unravel the mystery of the murder of Simon and the interview of his wife.

What really drew me in to the game was how well it really made me feel like I was doing genuine detective work. There is no tutorial or guidance you are merely looking at a computer terminal knowing you need to solve the case of a murder. Not for years have I used a scrap of paper to write down notes as I progressed through the game and this approach to â€œHer Storyâ€ was fantastically nostalgic.

The game relies on you as a playerâ€™s interest to drive the narrative forward. Even though I am a notorious â€œcut scene skipperâ€ I was so engrossed in the world of the game at no point did I skip any of the sequences. Had this game appeared on the SEGA CD 20 years ago this would have been a killer app we would still be talking about today.

The time setting of the game is perfect. The dubious operating system with references to pop culture from time such as Amstrad computers
recommended:
â€œYouâ€™ve been Framedâ€ and Ceefax. 1994 is also a time that many of this gameâ€™s target audience will remember but that is not to say that younger gamers will lose all points of reference. The video clips have been perfectly designed to look old. I spoke to Sam at a press event a few months ago and he told me how making the clips (that were filmed on a HD camera) look like â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ VHS from the 90s was one of the harder tasks.

The game is not perfect however. It took me about an hour and a half to solve the murder and probably another hour to find most of the spares clips. There is also a very obvious cheat you can do in order to make the game show you everything without trying although I did not pick up on this until after the end credits. My biggest issue however was the gameâ€™s apparent lack of a real ending. At a certain point when the game feels you have seen enough to piece together the story a very out of place MSN style chat menu appears that simply asks you â€œDo you know what happened?â€ At this point you do not have to actually explain anything you simply say â€œyesâ€ and the game ends. I would have defiantly preferred something a little more interactive and satisfying that essentially a popup menu asking me if I had had enough.

Her Story is something different and a game that I would 100% recommend to any fan of detective dramas or anyone looking for something a bit unusual. Her Story is the best FMV game ever made and one that you should definitely add to your collection.

For our video review of the game please check out the link below: http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-grades/150627_game-tutor-grades-her-story"

reviewText:
An original and fun investigative game.

The game consists entirely of video clips taken from police interviews with the central character. It's up to you to piece together the scraps of information, digging deeper into the system to find more videos, using new search terms you pick up from your observations.

It's hard to go into any details without venturing into spoiler territory, but the game itself is definitely worth a play if you fancy a bit of a head scratcher.

It's fairly short, but the perfect length for a game of this style and price. If you aim for a quick finish you'll have this done in around two hours, but 100% completion will take you a little longer. I managed to get that in just over three hours.

Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Interesting but short game.

You feel like a real investigator, piecing together clues and analysing what's being said. I actually started writing down what was being said on some paper - a game hasn't made me do that for a while! If that kind of thing appeals to you then it's probably worth the short amount of time it takes to complete.

I won't spoil the ending, although most things appear clear and that gives some satisfaction, it leaves you with some sour taste that there are still some unanswered quesitons. I hoped for more, so much more. Some penultimate end where I could use all the information i'd painstakenly gathered to fufill my role as detective. But no. It ends with you being just slightly less confused then where you began. It could've and probably should've been a lot better. Still worth it just for it's individuality though.

reviewText: Her Story is a fascinating take on interactive fiction.  It's an ambitious concept that doesn't directly involve the player or their choices like most pieces of interactive fiction.  Her Story takes place a number of years after the events have already occurred and presumably resolved themselves, and it's merely the player's job to suss out in their own mind what did or didn't happen, and then discuss that with others. There's no real win" state and you leave when you're satisfied. Only you can decide when you're truly satisfied.\n\nYou pick away at Her Story's narrative in a non-linear fashion by searching key words in a database and then watching clips of an interrogation that directly reference what you're searching for.  Clips are very rarely found in the order in which they occur
date: so you must continue refining your searches to continue a line of thought most of the time. It's a bit of a word puzzle and language is the only thing that matters.\n\nThe only clues you're given are the testimony of the interviewee
recommended: and the questions being asked by the detective are intentionally omitted
hoursPlayed: leaving only her answers to go by. Is she telling the truth? Is she blowing smoke? Again
voteText: that's for you to decide.\n\nThe system does come with some kinks. Each search can only return a maximum of five results at a time
helpfulPercent: requiring you to refine or repeat searches with slight differences.  This limitation adds a bit to the "word puzzle" idea
votesHelpful: but can also make the game feel clunky and padded at times.  There's no real easy way to re-watch clips other than searching for a specific term again. There's a visual database that keeps track of clips you've seen
votesTotal: but this would have served more purpose if you could use it to re-watch clips.  It feels like a bit of an oversight or missed opportunity.\n\nDespite its flaws
votesFunny: it's hard not to admire Her Story for what it's doing and how well it does it.  The acting
commentsCount: framing

reviewText:
Partyâ€™s Over, Oops Outta Time

If you were around in the 90â€™s you can count yourself lucky for having experienced one of the greatest decades in living memory.

The decade that bought us the best of Green Day"
date: "The X-Files" and the bizarre symbol that Prince changed his name too
recommended: also witnessed the fall of the Berlin Wall  (ok so that happened in â€˜89
hoursPlayed: but they were still knocking it down in the 90â€™s) and the rise of the Full Motion Video game!\n\nIt was an idea ahead of its time
voteText: (Full Motion Video
helpfulPercent: not the Prince symbol
votesHelpful:
that was just weird!)
The potential of the â€œinteractive movieâ€ was huge but the great FMV gaming revolution faltered before it ever really hit its stride.

Lacklustre performances by bewildered actors practicing their craft in front a green screen didnâ€™t do the genre any favours
votesTotal: neither did the fact that the technology available in the 90 wasnâ€™t really ready for the demands of the format.\nMost titles came on more CD-Roms than you could count on one hand
votesFunny: shuffling CDâ€™s to find the disk the game demanded next became part of the â€œfunâ€.\nHaving said that
commentsCount:
I still look back on the era of the â€œinteractive movieâ€ fondly.
Coming on a handful of disks made the game feel special and the content itself had a cheesy charm all of its own.

Sadly the FMV genre went into decline and by the time the world had stopped worrying about the millennium bug and the re-release of Princesâ€™ 1999 had faded from the charts
column16:
FMV was dead.


Party like its 1999

Itâ€™s a shame that FMV titles have been absent for so long
column17: but that is starting to change thanks to the flourishing indie scene breathing some new life into the genre.\nWeâ€™ve had â€œCloud Chamberâ€
column18: an underrated trailblazer released in 2014.\nâ€œContradictionâ€
column19:
a hugely enjoyable murder mystery set in rural England and now Iâ€™ve just wrapped up a play through of â€œHer Storyâ€ another engrossing entry in the FMV resurgence.

Thereâ€™s definitely been a subtle theme running through these modern titles.
Cloud Chamber was an investigation game; Contradiction was an investigation game and guess what...
Thatâ€™s right; â€œHer Storyâ€ is an investigation game too!

In fairness
column20:
all three have taken very different approaches to their investigative styles of play with varying degrees of success.
â€œHer Storyâ€ is probably the most unique in terms of how you play through the experience and itâ€™s important to note that this is an â€œexperienceâ€ not a traditional game.


Welcome To Paradise

When you load up the â€œexperienceâ€ you will find yourself looking at an old VDU connected to a police archive.
You are logged onto the terminal as â€œAuth_Guestâ€
column21:
no other information is given regarding your identity or purpose.
On the screen you will see a rudimentary search engine linked to transcripts of several police interviews which took place throughout the year of 1994.

These interviews are all of a young lady being questioned regarding the death of her husband.
Typing a word into the search bar will bring up segments of video footage which includes that word from their corresponding transcript.
One word has already been typed into the search engine... Murder.

The results of this search (a handful of video clips) are already waiting for your attention.
After watching these initial clips you will have discovered that the woman being questioned is a possible suspect in a murder investigation.

Beyond that anything I write here regarding the jigsaw of a narrative would almost certainly spoil your experience but I can say that youâ€™re about to start a uniquely intriguing journey of discovery with a mind twisting story that will likely stay with you long after youâ€™ve turned off your PC


The Truth Is Out There

The simple â€œmeta-searchâ€ game mechanic used to track down the video fragments is surprisingly effective.
Youâ€™ll watch a clip and if the suspect mentions something that sounds interesting you can dig a little deeper by tapping a relevant word or two into the search bar.
Each fresh search will hopefully bring up further unwatched video clips which will give you ideas for key words to search for next.
Every new clip you find will fill in another fragment of â€œher storyâ€

This search engine treasure hunt creates an unexpected and welcome sense of anticipation with every keyword you enter and for the most part it works extremely well.

Thereâ€™s always a chance that youâ€™ll uncover a video clip unintentionally which might reveal an important nugget of information before youâ€™re ready to hear it
column22: but this is a non linier journey of discovery
column23:
all the video clips are time stamped and if you do stumble upon something unexpected itâ€™ll just provide another opportunity for fresh keywords and  another topic to explore.
Back peddling to unveil the narrative which led to an unexpected revelation can be just as fun.

This kind of unexpected early reveal of a pivotal clip isnâ€™t too much of an issue.
Whilst there are no â€œclosed doorsâ€ with regards to the searches you can perform
column24:
you simply wonâ€™t know which words will bring up these â€œkey momentâ€ clips until youâ€™ve spent some time listening to the interviewees recounting of events.

Of course you could always just throw random words at the search engine and see what comes up but by taking this maverick investigative approach youâ€™ll undoubtedly lose out on the sense of accomplishment achieved when you follow a trail of keywords to discover a pivotal piece of footage.


I Want To Believe

The delivery of the narrative through these video clips is superbly implemented.
The detectivesâ€™ questions are never played on the clips
column25: only the answers given.\nThe whole experience is just you
column26:
the search engine and the woman sitting at a table looking back at you whilst answering questions youâ€™ll never hear.

Iâ€™m not sure how much of the dialogue is scripted and how much is adlib but the fact that it flows so naturally is a testament to both Sam Barlow and Viva Seifert (the creator and the actress respectively).
The responses never feel stilted or overly dramatised; theyâ€™re engrossing
column27:
subtle and always feel â€œrealâ€.


Walking Alone

This believability canâ€™t only be attributed to the quality of the script but also to the excellent performance given by Ms Seifert.

reviewText:
Interesting but short game.

You feel like a real investigator, piecing together clues and analysing what's being said. I actually started writing down what was being said on some paper - a game hasn't made me do that for a while! If that kind of thing appeals to you then it's probably worth the short amount of time it takes to complete.

I won't spoil the ending, although most things appear clear and that gives some satisfaction, it leaves you with some sour taste that there are still some unanswered quesitons. I hoped for more, so much more. Some penultimate end where I could use all the information i'd painstakenly gathered to fufill my role as detective. But no. It ends with you being just slightly less confused then where you began. It could've and probably should've been a lot better. Still worth it just for it's individuality though.

reviewText:
A FMV â€œvideo gameâ€, ultimately Her Story is really nothing more than a movie with a very strange interface. This pretty much points to the primary flaw in Her Story, as the actual story being told by the videos is best viewed sequentially, but the interface of the game makes it so that viewing the videos sequentially is extremely unlikely.

Hannah is the main character of Her Story, and indeed, the only one who shows up in the videos. The central conceit of the game is that Hannah was a murder suspect in 1994, and the protagonist is going through an old police database, wherein the videos are sorted by keywords in their transcripts. This sounds like a clever idea, but in practice, it doesnâ€™t really work very well at all; beyond being very confusing, it suffers from the fact that it is entirely possible to search for the wrong keyword and end up stumbling across the gameâ€™s central twist five minutes in.

Unsurprisingly, I did exactly this by simply searching for the most innocuous of the names I had come across first (for the record, it was the name of one of Hannahâ€™s childhood friends). This resulted in me happening across a video which spoiled the gameâ€™s central plot twist, and consequently I spent the rest of the game trying to piece together everything else in the hopes of finding another twist, and then failing to find one.

The net result of the search interface is that you are likely to watch lots of garbage scenes, with odd scenes which are really important thrown in between them. Some of the videos are nothing more than Hannah saying â€œnoâ€, while others are minute-long monologues explaining crucial plot or character details.

Worst of all, if you actually watch the videos in order, they follow the standard variances of a plot; the rise and fall of action as the police officers piece things together before Hannah finally explains exactly what is going on in the final interview. As a movie, it makes sense.

But as a video game, it makes no sense at all.

It has other flaws as well â€“ as a murder mystery game, one would think that little details would be pretty important, but as it turns out, the people who made the videos didnâ€™t actually pay much attention to time constraints. On many occaisions, something happens â€“ such as a character changing clothing, or taking a polygraph â€“ which ignores the necessary setup time, with the videos happening too close together in time. At first, I had assumed that these little mistakes was related to the plot twist, but eventually I realized it was simple laziness on the part of the game creators.

If the plot was actually viewed in order, it might be passable, though the awkward interface of the game still would make it annoying. And if parts had been locked off until you had figured some stuff out, it might have worked. But as-is, the thing is kind of a mess, and while the central idea wasnâ€™t a bad one, the UI and erratic pacing as a result of it being made into a â€œgameâ€ (which it really isnâ€™t any more than searching for stuff on YouTube is a â€œgameâ€) makes it hard to really get into it properly. It is possible to spoil the entire plot of the game within five minutes, and a lot of the videos end up feeling a lot like filler, especially when viewed out of context.

reviewText: First off, this game" is not a game. Just as there are popular story-based games that are just called "walking simulators
date:
this one is simply just thinking and repeatedly typing phrases to watch something over and over.

Does that mean the game is necessarily bad? No. But it's not something amazing I would say that must be played. It is simply unique because I do not think I have seen something like it before, or at least not in the same style when it comes to FMV games from years ago.

There really is nothing to say in terms of general review material. I cannot say much on graphics, sound, or gameplay. The graphics are an old computer screen showing FMVs. The sound is generic computer noises and the woman talking. The gameplay is clicking videos and searching for them with words to solve a murder mystery.

I enjoyed it for what it was, simply because it is new (and simultaneously nostalgic). Some videos are interesting and even pretty creepy, while there are many very short videos that are filled with fluff. I just wish they hadn't separated videos so much like that. It wasn't really necessary to have THAT many videos when a lot do not have much useful information. I understand not all videos should give main story points, or else that is pointless. But having many videos with a single word was also pointless.

But really, the biggest flaw of this game is how easy it is to get a grasp on the story. Within just over 30 minutes, I already found some videos that basically gave me the general idea of what to expect to find in the rest of the story. And less than an hour or so after that, I had found all of the most important videos, really.

I wrote things down as I went along and by the end of the game I had utilized 130+ search terms or phrases to find 100% of the videos. But I had come up with some phrases that led to the most important videos within the first 25 phrases that I had come up with, and by the 40th phrase, I had found the one which signified the possible endpoint" for the game. But instead
recommended: I purposefully didn't watch videos with terms that I thought were most important
hoursPlayed: because I thought it would end the game and destroy my progress.\n\nI found out eventually that it didn't
voteText: so I ended the game
helpfulPercent: then just continued and found the rest of the videos because I was being a completionist
votesHelpful: and not because I was that excited to look for more videos. In fact
votesTotal: the majority of the last videos I found (like the last 25-35% of the videos I found) were mostly boring and had no story to them.\n\nIn the end
votesFunny: I liked the game
commentsCount: but don't think it's a masterpiece by any means. So
column16: if you aren't genuinely interested in the whole idea of trying to search for and watch videos in a disjointed manner to piece together an alright (but nothing too great) story
column17: then do not bother. But if it intrigues you
column18: give it a whirl."

reviewText:
Use keywords to search a police database for fragmented video clips related to a crime. Try and figure out what happened.

Simple concept, pure execution but over too quickly. I would love to see this idea developed further in a future game.

8/10

Pros:
+ Interesting concept - who knew that searching for 200+ fragmented interview clips and trying to piece it all together could be so much fun? Having to scribble down notes on pen and paper was engaging.
+ Retro 90's atmosphere achieved with minimal graphics
+ Convincing acting by Viva Seifert, who single-handedly carries the game
+ Trying to find all of the video clips without cheating is genuinely challenging
+ Slightly ambiguous story open to interpretation (2 theories about Her Story have been analyzed in detail by players)


Cons:
- Extremely short (2-3 hours unless you are trying to find 100% of the clips)
- A bit too easy to find key clips that reveal major details
- A few pointless, filler" clips that consist of one word
- Not easily able to play discovered clips in chronological order. It would have been nice for the UI to handle this for you at the click of a button.
"

reviewText:
Her Story is one of the most intriguing and compelling narrative video gaming experiences Iâ€™ve had this year. A full-motion video (FMV) game, Her Story consists of watching a series of seven police interviews of the same woman in what appears to be a murder investigation. You are given no contextual information and must piece together what is going on to uncover the whole story. The catch is that these video interviews have become fragmented on an old database and are only viewable in segments between a couple seconds to a minute in length. Using clues from the viewable clips and their audio transcripts, you must search the video database using words or phrases you suspect will appear in  the missing video fragments.

This fragmented approach to storytelling leads to a delightful journey of confusion and discovery, as you jump back and forth in a timeline of events and must use your wits and careful observation to discover what is really going on. The game does not hold your hand or explain the story in any way - it is up to you to uncover the great plot twists and revelations that Her Story has to offer. The sole actor playing the woman being interviewed does a great job at delivering some well-written lines; the game never came across as being corny or lame.

There are, however, a few issues with the game. The game does not account for a game-ruining exploit that allows the player to easily uncover all the missing video clips. I also experienced several crashes while launching the game in OSX and some of the achievements failed to unlock the first time through. However, these crashes did not corrupt my game progress and the remaining achievements unlocked after a (brief) second playthrough. The gameâ€™s short runtime (2-3 hours) and lack of mechanical depth might also be a turn-off for some players.

That being said, I found Her Story to be well worth the $6 I paid for it. Itâ€™s rare for a game to force you to think the way that Her Story does and the result is an enjoyable afternoon of confusion, theorizing, revelation, and reflection. If youâ€™re into good stories, mysteries, and short, memorable experiences, Her Story is well worth your time. Bring a friend to bounce ideas off of, and donâ€™t forget a pen and a piece of paper!

reviewText: This game is absolutely different than anything you played before. It can not be review in traditional way. First thing to say is that there are minimum of ingame controls. You type a word (or more words) in database search. After you searched it you will get videos where the word (or words) was spoken. You watch these videos and write down names, places, things or whatever you want to search next. You gradually reveals the story, associate connection. Because in database all seven interrogations are scrappy you must connect it on paper or in your head. This outside-game interactivity is what makes this game really special and different. You will really want to find out what happened to this strange woman.\n\nIf you just want to relax from ordinary games or just want to try something new I'm glad to recommend this beautiful masterpiece.

reviewText:
Moderately enjoyable FMV game. Pretty decent, but short (I beat it in @90minutes and even at that, I thought it was getting a little long in the tooth in the last 10).  I don't particularly mind that myself. $3 is about the same I'd pay for the two days it takes me to get a redbox back.

In this game, you have access to a video database in a police station from the 90s and you're trying to piece together what happened in a murder.  You don't really win or lose and there's not much conflict, you just try to piece together what happened by watching videos you reference using clues from other videos to retrieve them. It's better than it sounds. It's actually pretty fun for the first hour, and ok for the last half hour.

Good game to pick up on sale, don't know if I would've paid retail for it.
-----

Well that said, it's worthy of a mention that the developers are either wildly ignorant of gaming history or liars. Despite billing itself as startingly original, first of its kind, etc,daring design, etc, etc, and critics saying the same thing, there's an entire adventure game subgenre that plays like this, except with generally better mechanics and more interactivity e.g. Missing: Since January.

There are also the more recent ARGs (Alternate Reality Games). I know I play more games than every streamer, most people and nearly every critic, but it's absurd that people think the devs did anything particularly original. This is something that's been done before, lots (which isn't to say this is all that bad, quite the contrary). This is an ARG Lite.

It's a decent game, but it's only an hour and a  half and has a weak narrative arc and less interactivity than a good ARG. Good ARGs also involve a community, which tends to make it more exciting and social.

Buy on sale.

reviewText:
Read my review of this game for Quench magazine:
http://cardiffstudentmedia.co.uk/quench/video-games/her-story-review/

If you can't be arsed with that, here's the gist of it:
The game itself is only about two hours long to get the gist of the story. The more skeptical reader might say this is to take advantage of Steamâ€™s new refund policy, but I think it is because this game is essentially an interactive version of the time-honoured tradition of British detective shows such as Foyleâ€™s War and Midsomer Murders, although obviously much lower budget. Where the thrill of those programmes comes from guessing the true story of the murder, the viewer has no real input on the story. Here, developer Sam Barlow has successfully thought of a way to involve the player in Her Storyâ€™s plot-unravelling, without it being too apparent that they are still playing a heavily scripted video game: for the most part, the only interaction you get (typing) gives the player the freedom to type anything they wish. It might not be the most exciting game around, but for less than a fiver this yarn is worth trying.

Play it for: The shock of discovering the storyâ€™s big twists

Pro: Breaks new ground in game storytelling, or at least not that seen for many years

Con: Can sometimes seem to drag on and lose your interest

7/10

reviewText:
Read my review of this game for Quench magazine:
http://cardiffstudentmedia.co.uk/quench/video-games/her-story-review/

If you can't be arsed with that, here's the gist of it:
The game itself is only about two hours long to get the gist of the story. The more skeptical reader might say this is to take advantage of Steamâ€™s new refund policy, but I think it is because this game is essentially an interactive version of the time-honoured tradition of British detective shows such as Foyleâ€™s War and Midsomer Murders, although obviously much lower budget. Where the thrill of those programmes comes from guessing the true story of the murder, the viewer has no real input on the story. Here, developer Sam Barlow has successfully thought of a way to involve the player in Her Storyâ€™s plot-unravelling, without it being too apparent that they are still playing a heavily scripted video game: for the most part, the only interaction you get (typing) gives the player the freedom to type anything they wish. It might not be the most exciting game around, but for less than a fiver this yarn is worth trying.

Play it for: The shock of discovering the storyâ€™s big twists

Pro: Breaks new ground in game storytelling, or at least not that seen for many years

Con: Can sometimes seem to drag on and lose your interest

7/10

reviewText: I heavily enjoyed it and I find the story is heavily up to interpretation (and best left that way to prevent fighting) but the longer you go at it and the more you exhaust your searches you become rather intwined. I was only let down by the fact that I wanted to do more. The computer interface is clunky and unimaginative, creating a sense of linearity you can't escape. I would've enjoyed being able to look through files, evidence and that sort of thing. But you quickly learn that you're not really there to solve a crime, just to figure out 'Her Story' start to finish.\n\nRIP Simon though, whatever happened was tragic I feel strangely sad on your behalf.

reviewText:
Her Story is a game for the desk jockey. All of the gameplay is summarized as follows; search keywords from live-action video scripts, watch said videos, keep going until the game thinks youâ€™ve watched enough videos. From the collection of videos both cryptic and vague to the poignant and verbose, Her Story hands you the pieces of a story of love, murder and insanity.

Most beautifully, I should say, is the addition of an â€˜unreliable narratorâ€™ to such an unexplored genre that is, interactive media. You search these videos by keyword, so most of the time theyâ€™re out of order or worse: Completely non-sequitur without its missing context. What appears to be a video of the protagonist (thereâ€™s just the one) confessing or slipping on her well-constructed alibi could just be a small piece of something bigger or just a small moment of stress-induced insanity. Is she crazy? Is she just shaken up? The duality of this character slowly weaving  itself together in front of you is also the only one  giving you credible information on the murder you, as the player, are trying to solve.

Where this game really shines is in its use of Engine and GUI. Iâ€™m guilty of groaning when I saw the unity logo pop-up at the beginning of the game. While a strong advocate for Unity and user-friendly game engines, I have to admit that my standards dropped a bit in expectations for a game that probably wasnâ€™t going to be as lengthy or beautiful as I hoped. Within seconds, Her Story assured me my time would not be wasted. The GUI/UI background is that of an old tube-monitor from the mid 90â€™s. A functional and UI that contains a program that runs and feels like a copycat of Windows 95â€™. As a game dev thatâ€™s had to make a similar project, I feel greatly outclassed by the simplicity and credibility of Sam Barlowâ€™s work on the user interface. Itâ€™s amazing. If youâ€™re a student in game design or just making user interfaces, I strongly recommend you buy this game at cover price.
The ending left me hollow, sad, pensive and guilty. Without spoiling anything, itâ€™s definitely worth playing this to the end. I understand that these â€œartsy gamesâ€ donâ€™t gel with everyone. But to those looking for an unparalleled look into the marriage between two ironclad mediums. Do not miss this game.
**I WAS NOT PAID BY THE DEVELOPERS NOR IS THIS A PAID REVIEW** KTHNXBYE

reviewText:
Her Story is deceptively simple but also quite cunning.  It's tricky when you think you know a word that will lead to the footage you need, but then it brings up too many responses (you only have access to the first five).  This game definitely rewards smart guessing!  Once you figure out the chat window, it's downhill from there.

My twin sister Anna and I have been playing this game on and off for a while.  She keeps teasing me with what she's learned, but I don't think it's much.  She got right mad and punched me in the arm when I wouldn't tell her what I've learned.  Play it for yo'self!  Though I may be taking some time off for a bit.  My hand's been hurting.  Guess that means it's going to rain (or something).

reviewText:
Use keywords to search a police database for fragmented video clips related to a crime. Try and figure out what happened.

Simple concept, pure execution but over too quickly. I would love to see this idea developed further in a future game.

8/10

Pros:
+ Interesting concept - who knew that searching for 200+ fragmented interview clips and trying to piece it all together could be so much fun? Having to scribble down notes on pen and paper was engaging.
+ Retro 90's atmosphere achieved with minimal graphics
+ Convincing acting by Viva Seifert, who single-handedly carries the game
+ Trying to find all of the video clips without cheating is genuinely challenging
+ Slightly ambiguous story open to interpretation (2 theories about Her Story have been analyzed in detail by players)


Cons:
- Extremely short (2-3 hours unless you are trying to find 100% of the clips)
- A bit too easy to find key clips that reveal major details
- A few pointless, filler" clips that consist of one word
- Not easily able to play discovered clips in chronological order. It would have been nice for the UI to handle this for you at the click of a button.
"

reviewText: This isn't even a game!! It's literally just a bunch of video files that you access in a GUI. A game is meant to be played to some degree. It shouldn't be just watching enough video files until the game is convinced you've finished it and solved the mystery of the whole thing. I hate this movie and that's really what it is. Just because you use FMV in your game doesn't mean that the game should be almost only FMV. Even FMV games in the 90's had the common decency to be actual games that have a significant playable element to it. The whole game is just search the videos, watch the videos, and the game is complete after watching enough short videos. This may seem obvious to most people but a game is supposed to have gameplay in it and this is almost entirely devoid of gameplay. This isn't a game!!!

reviewText: I started this game with little concept of what I was doing. Watch video clips, search for others using keywords, try to figure out what happened, but was I trying to build a murder case or prove an alibi or what? I wasn't sure. The first few clips the game give you don't offer much to go on, but did give the victim's name so I tried that, but you only get the first five clips the word was used in so it didn't offer much. I got the name of a hotel and its staff and still didn't get much from any of those. But a couple of times our interviewee mentioned an argument so I searched for that and when it still didn't offer much I thought sideways and tried fight".\n\nAnd it was in there that I got something to search for that made me go from kind of disengaged by the way I wasn't getting anywhere to getting drawn down the rabbit hole. I quickly lost interest in actually solving the murder in favor of hunting down all the details I could about the story I'd just gotten the first glimpse of. This did eventually lead me to finding out what happened
date:
but as a side effect of the story I was actually chasing rather than because I was purposely searching for it at that point.

Ironically even though I quickly stopped caring about the actual mystery the game starts out presenting to us it worked as a mystery game more strongly for me than many that keep you focused on their cases from end to end. I was really thinking about what different clips might be implying and trying to come up with keywords related to my guesses to see if they were right instead of just sorting through a pile of evidence for whatever seemed right to select.

It's not a perfect game
recommended: I suspect that it would be possible for someone not even trying to game the system to stumble onto the answer to the murder really quickly without ever getting into the deeper story and feel like the game wasn't worth their time
hoursPlayed: but if you do dig away with it you get a fascinating and unsettling story.\n\nAlso
voteText: I'd just like to take a second to praise Viva Seifert's performance. So many of the old FMV games this one took a cue from just have terrible acting even if the games themselves are solid
helpfulPercent: and this is one where having a bad actress would have outright ruined the game since it revolves around paying close attention to her. But Ms. Seifert really just sold it here

reviewText:
A FMV Visual Novel. I'm not normally a visual novel fan, but having someone actually talking that you can listen to and read her gestures, goes a lot to helping pull you into the story. There really isn't anything much to talk about in terms of gameplay, if you've played a visual novel like Analog a Hate Story, the same principles apply as you try to learn more about what happened based on the video clips.

If you hate Visual Novel gameplay, this game won't change your mind, but it's a good take for what it is.

reviewText: I normally don't do reviews because a lot of steam reviews are just people trying to out funny each other.  This game is different, I felt really compelled to let people know how much I liked this game.  Game or whatever you want to call it.  I have always been a fan of a great mystery, if you can see my hours for games like Ace Attorney you'd understand.  This game doesn't force you to finish everything.  About partway through the game you are able to be completed if you choose.  Of course that isn't something I would do, but it's possible.  I found all but 17 video files for a while and it wasn't until I found a nice way to organize the videos that I was able to finally finish all the videos.  And honestly, I feel like I wasn't being cheap or anything.  I feel like that is an option in this game, because they want you to find those files anyway you can think up.  It's very unique in that way.\n\nI honestly hope people get inspiration from this game and want to make something like it.  I know FMV has been around for a long time, but with todays technology and the smart people around I feel like this could be the start of some great video game/fmv moments.

reviewText:
I recommend Her Story to anyone who love solving puzzles and being a detective or enjoy a good story. Buy the game right now!

This game is good in that context, BUT you can figure out whtat happened in less than 2 hours. So I refunded after I have established what I think has happened and who is sitting in front of the computer. Of course it is very thrilling to take notes and map the timeline and such, and the Actress did a fantastic performance I have every seen in video games. There are many neat reference to the theme and lots to discuss for sure.

But the case is just too simple. I discover 2 of the most important 'events' after my 20 entries. When you figure out what is going on, the rest is just boring. The game didn't provide any sense of achievement or let you confirm your theory.

I will still recommend this game solely because there is the refund policy. If this game is based on a richer gameplay machanism that would be great. But now, it is still didn't jump out of the genre box.

reviewText:
I never review games, so this is more a response to other people's reviews, but yea, I get it, this is a bit like a Youtube game. I played it tonight with my other half for about two hours and I feel like I've uncovered enough of the story (and what I assume is the ending) to make a full hunt for all the clips unecessary. Is it worth the Â£5 I paid for it? Of course it is.

Great sleuth interactive fiction, well acted, uniquely presented, incredibly tight in its writing and acting, the worst thing I could say for it is that it probably would have worked on the CD32 or MegaCD and it's a shame it took 20 years to figure out what to do with FMV.

10/10, would entertain a couple of people for an evening for the price of a London pint again.

reviewText:
My on record time for this game is roughly 9 hours but I assure you now that is is much much longer than that. You see, this game is split into two parts.

The first part consists of actually playing" the "game" which is soley composed of staring at a computer and using key terms to obsessively search through clips on a database to unravel the mystery.

The second part is "finishing" the "game" and then staring at your computer and using key terms to obsessively search through the internet to unravel the larger mysteries this game creates in you.

So really you never stop playing.

Worth the time in bed staring at your ceiling as well as $6. Ignore the haters and enjoy the ride.

"

reviewText:
Her Story is a pretty interesting point and click mystery game where you have to try and work out what happened to a guy named Simon. You're not told anything. You're just presented with an old early 2000's computer, a bunch of archived footage from an interview with some lady and a couple of readme files. You have no idea what it's about, what the story is, who the woman is or anything. You're just thrown into the ocean without a life raft and have to work out how to survive.

At first, the game is intriguing. You click through videos of an interview with some lady as she talks about Simon and other various topics. You're trying to work out a mystery that you don't even know exists. But you keep clicking, listening to clips of the interview and trying to piece together in your mind what's happening. It's confusing but you keep going, because you're dying to understand what the hell is going on.

Yet at the same time this is where Her Story, in my opinion, fails.

You see, while it is genuinely interesting and engrossing, over time Her Story begins to become more and more convoluted as the pieces of the clues start to disappear. Although you'll work out what is going on fairly early into the game, the further you investigate, the less you understand. Clues become thinner, context begins to disappear and confusion takes over your mind completely, causing a feeling of frustration as you seemingly hit a brick wall.

The thing is however, and without giving away anything, you're not really supposed to know what's going on. It's almost like a cruel game played on you by the developer. If you ever wanted to know how detectives must often feel, it's probably something like this. At some point in the game you are promoted to end the story and let the credits roll, but this gives no closure to the game what so ever. The game just decides you've seen enough clips to piece together the story but to be honest, by this point I knew as little as I did when I first booted up the game. You do however unlock a code that allows you to search for random clips, in the hopes of finding one you haven't already seen. But
you never really get closure in Her Story, just a sense of utter confusion that eats away at you for hours on end.

By the time you finish the game completely you'll begin to wonder if you really do understand Her Story. But the truth is that her story is so open ended you'll never truly understand.

As long as you go into the game not expecting closure, you'll enjoy Her Story. But know what you're getting yourself into.

reviewText:
When I first saw this game in the store I thought it was just another indie non-game trying to push an agenda just from the picture and title alone. But when it got so many good reviews, I just had to check it out for myself. And I'm very glad to have been corrected.

Right away the game did not seem that special. The three initial clips were only 12 seconds long and they gave the impression it was just a regular murder drama. But oh boy, dig in a little more and soon enough you get completly hooked in the story.

The gist of the game is about finding clip fragments of multiple interrogation recordings that took place in the span of a few weeks and piece together the story.
You do so by inputting keywords in a search. The first keyword MURDER" and the 3 resulting clips are a freebie and from there you have to find the rest based on what the woman in the video says. So for example
recommended: people and objects it's a good idea to search with it.\nThe game helps you out by allowing you to bookmark videos
hoursPlayed:
tag them and shows when you have seen it or not.
It's basically one big unconventional logical puzzle.

However
voteText: the main appeal of the game are the stories (yes
helpfulPercent: multiple) that unfold. It doesn't take long for you to realise there is something not quite right with the woman in the video and after you dig a bit further
votesHelpful: things takes a surprising turn. With your curiosity piqued you start uncovering more and more
votesTotal: going down the rabbit hole so to speak. While hardly a believable story
votesFunny: its a highly interesting one.\n\nThere are 7 recording sessions and the last recording reveals all the key aspects of the story and are the ones you need to find to reveal everything
commentsCount:
while others focus on certain details and insights. So just when you thought you had figured it out a clip fragment could disprove everything.
You get a graphical feedback whenever you uncover important information and when you have gathered enough you can "finish" the game and then BAM! Major twist right in your face you could never seen coming aside from one small almost hidden clue.

The game does not have a "feminist agenda" like some people are saying. And it does deserve to be called a game
column16: because you its more than just watching videos as you have to put some work into unlocking then.\n\nThe game is very short however and has not much replay value once you got all the achievements
column17: so I'm unsure I would recommend it at full price. I got it at half-price and do not regret it. But a must buy for fans of story-driven games who can value a good story full of twists and turns.\n\nI really hope to see more of games like this until
column18:
hopefully without being driven into the ground like what happens everytime a new genre gets popular.

Pros:
- Good narrative
- Interesting concept
- Good story
- Quirky interface

Cons:
- Somewhat short
- Low replay value
- Not for everyone"

reviewText: I started this game with little concept of what I was doing. Watch video clips, search for others using keywords, try to figure out what happened, but was I trying to build a murder case or prove an alibi or what? I wasn't sure. The first few clips the game give you don't offer much to go on, but did give the victim's name so I tried that, but you only get the first five clips the word was used in so it didn't offer much. I got the name of a hotel and its staff and still didn't get much from any of those. But a couple of times our interviewee mentioned an argument so I searched for that and when it still didn't offer much I thought sideways and tried fight".\n\nAnd it was in there that I got something to search for that made me go from kind of disengaged by the way I wasn't getting anywhere to getting drawn down the rabbit hole. I quickly lost interest in actually solving the murder in favor of hunting down all the details I could about the story I'd just gotten the first glimpse of. This did eventually lead me to finding out what happened
date:
but as a side effect of the story I was actually chasing rather than because I was purposely searching for it at that point.

Ironically even though I quickly stopped caring about the actual mystery the game starts out presenting to us it worked as a mystery game more strongly for me than many that keep you focused on their cases from end to end. I was really thinking about what different clips might be implying and trying to come up with keywords related to my guesses to see if they were right instead of just sorting through a pile of evidence for whatever seemed right to select.

It's not a perfect game
recommended: I suspect that it would be possible for someone not even trying to game the system to stumble onto the answer to the murder really quickly without ever getting into the deeper story and feel like the game wasn't worth their time
hoursPlayed: but if you do dig away with it you get a fascinating and unsettling story.\n\nAlso
voteText: I'd just like to take a second to praise Viva Seifert's performance. So many of the old FMV games this one took a cue from just have terrible acting even if the games themselves are solid
helpfulPercent: and this is one where having a bad actress would have outright ruined the game since it revolves around paying close attention to her. But Ms. Seifert really just sold it here
votesHelpful: I could really believe that I was watching a real woman being interviewed."

reviewText: This game was absolutely enthralling. The core conceit is that you are able to watch individual answers to questions in a series of police interviews, but you don't get to see the questions, and you don't get to watch them in order. Instead, you search for keywords and can watch only the first 5 matching videos. This means that in spite of static content and a static plot, there is a huge amount of exploration and player choice. Unless you're very completionist, you'll see a subtly different set of videos than anyone else who plays this game. That, combined with the varied order in which you could see crucial clips and get Aha!" moments
date: deeply colors your perceptions of the story and the motivations and morality of the characters in it.\n\nI would recommend this game for the novelty alone
recommended: it's the only FMV game I've seen that really makes the medium work well. This is really one of the best experimental low budget indie games I've played in a long time."

reviewText:
Fantastic experimental game made by Sam Barlow, the same mind behind the very interesting game Silent Hill: Shattered Memories. Like SM, this game approaches narrative in videogames in a very unique way that may be worth your time and money.

It's undeniable that this is not a game for everyone, but if you like narrative experiences where you investigate, take notes and try to piece together a story at your own pace, you should definitely check this out. Also, the actress that plays the role of the woman that gets interviewed by the police definitely deserves praise for her amazing performance.

In videogames there are so many diverse and original takes on how to tell a story, and many of them differ greatly from any other media. This game is proof of that.

reviewText:
This game is very engaging, even though the 'gameplay' is pretty barebones. The story is deeply layered - every once in a while you come across a plot point that sheds everything you've seen in a new light. It quickly becomes much more than a simple murder mystery. Some of it is cliche, sure, but the sense of voyeurism and the rollercoaster ride of trust and empathy that the story puts you through is well worth the trip.

Bring a notepad and a pencil, because you'll need to take a ton of notes to piece this game together - especially if you're going for 100% completion! Investigating seemingly unimportant things can lead you down some wild rabbit holes. You'll look back on the experience as a masterpiece in storytelling and editing.

Also a fair warning, but some of the negative reviews contain spoilers. Do yourself a favour and go into this game blind.
voteText: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
[*NO SPOILERS*]

This game proved to be a fine example for complete  immersion-in both style and storywriting. The actress is playing her role convicingly and has a smooth voice to carry the well written script.
The gameplay does not revolve around holding the interview with her (that means you do not chose the question); it revolves around reconstructing the dialogue through searching for the words she might have said it one of the many clips stored in a police archive (gladly I did not get to a point where I had to put in random words in hope of a new hint)
However, this little fine twist of recreating rather than creating makes the game a unique experience, as you are not restricted to pre-written multiple choice questions- instead you shift the attention to the detail you think is the most crucial, whatever detail that is.
If you enjoy evaluating evidence and/or comprehending human motives, this game is a must buy- especially for this low price.

RECOMMENDED TO BE PLAYED AT DARK WITH A GLASS OF WHISKEY AMIDST CIGARETTE SMOKE

reviewText:
I have really enjoyed playing this game. Just got the 100% completion on it. I highly recommend this game if you like puzzles and story-heavy games. The non-linear story means that you need to pay attention to what is going on, and WHEN it went on.

What this game does well:
- The actor. Since gameplay is searching for and watching videos, she has to sell the story. And she does it well. In fact, after certain plot points were revealed to me, I really liked going back to review old videos and piece together things I may have missed at the beginning.
- The videos themselves. The videos really do look like they were recorded in the 90s. The subtitles are those dark yellow ones you used to see on TV back in the day, too. The videos remind me of the days when games had FMVs, like The 7th Guest.
- The computer. Aside from the database, you can interact with everything else on the computer desktop.  There's glare on the computer screen (and other assorted graphics that I won't discuss) that really make you feel like you're looking at the screen itself, not just the desktop. You can turn that glare off if you'd like, but imo it loses some of the immersion that way.
- The music! Oh, it gave me chills in places. After certain videos, different music will play. It startled me at first, but I think that in a game where interactivity is limited, anything extra to engage the player does a world of difference.
- The story. I don't want to give any spoilers, and of course the nature of the game means that some players will figure it out more quickly than others. By the first hour in the game, I had gotten the major pieces figured oaut. I guess it took getting around half of the videos unlocked. Getting 75% was pretty easy too, but I started running into dead ends after that. I will say that after a certain point, the game alerts you that you've found enough information to consider the game finished"
date: and at that point you can trigger an ending sequence and credits. (If you go back to play later
recommended: your completion rate is still there.)\n- It's not pretentious. There are a lot of art games that disregard "traditional" gameplay and sometimes that can alienate players. There is no fail state in this game. There is a score in that the game tracks your completion rate
hoursPlayed: and there is a win/completion state. But the game presents its gameplay and story clearly and plainly."

reviewText:
This is the first Steam review I've written, but I felt compelled to do so after finishing this outstanding game just now.

As the store page description states, the gameplay consists of you being presented with a PC screen accurately designed to look like a CRT monitor from the late 90s or early 2000s. You're given limited access to a police database that contains lots of short video clips (varying in length from 5 seconds to nearly 3 minutes) of a woman being interviewed by the police. The authentic appearance and audio of the videos are just as spot-on as the CRT monitor.

You begin by typing search terms into the search field. If that word is spoken in any of the videos, those videos will display as your search results. You then watch the videos â€“ thankfully an eye icon is displayed on any video that you have not viewed â€“ and listen/read the subtitles. As you watch more videos, you gain ideas for more search terms, which gives you access to more videos, and so on.

My immediate reaction when finishing: Holy s--t, this game! It's so good! It grabbed very quickly, and sunk its hooks further in the more I played, due to me continuing to receive what I can imagine are dopamine hits in my brain as I slowly unravel and realize things.

Obviously, I'm avoiding spoilers, but I can't recommend this innovative game enough. Maybe it's the high" that I'm still on because I just finished it
date: but Her Story currently has a very good chance of my personal GOTY. It's that good
hoursPlayed: that gripping
voteText: and that impactful."

reviewText: An interesting game. There hasn't been a game featuring storytelling like this one that I know of. I found the story intriguing and the multilayered style kept surprising me. Yet to me it's an example of how games still keep pushing boundaries on every sector.

reviewText:
A new take on storytelling, stripping away any hand-holding, allowing you to go through the story at any point and pleasantly, at your own pace. Trying to focus solely on only the investigation probably takes away from the experience, because that's hunting for clues. With the set up of the search bar, you have a very nice overlooked element that no one is going to go through the game similarly because you have the freedom to ask anything pertinent to the case. Unfortunately, with that said, some people catch onto key words more quickly than others, offsetting the balance of hours of searching. That breaks the illusion of being in the game, which atmosphere is a good part of keeping you entralled. The supposed twist is not original, but I can forgive it because it's executed well, both by writer and actress, and only once you know enough about the woman, you do see the multiple layers of the story. As it turns out, the woman seems to hog all the spotlight while the reason why she is being questioned takes a seat beside her, which could be another point that detours less story-focused players.

It took me about 3 hours to earn the ending, but I pushed forward, wanting to learn everything I could. Keeping a pen and paper handy was good, because especially in the beginning, you have many things to search for, so it's certainly handy to keep around, but if not, there are tags you can add to the video, in case you don't have any lying around. I greatly enjoyed this and thought it earned it's money's worth. I am satisfied that it fulfilled my â€œ$1 per hour of game playâ€ rule and the great story Sam Barlow penned for all of us. Viva Seifert, who played the woman, did a very good job conveying the frustration, tiredness and solemn tone.

I frankly think it's a good buy, because I've have very few games give me a similar experience, making me so excited to hunt down the truth and every facet of detail to 'Her Story'. For $6, I might give it a pass for the great content, but if you can get it on sale or, like me, you try to get every achievement, it's a nice addition to your game library.

reviewText: Really enjoyed this.  It's a detective game, where you sit at a search prompt. Each term returns up to five (short) video clips, and you have to jump from one to another, making notes and piecing together what happened.  It sounds a bit lame, but I was hooked within five minutes, and here I am several hours later having completed it.  (Over 75% of clips viewed, and I think I have a reasonable idea of what happened.)  It's quite short (took me under 3 hours), but I think the price reflects that fairly.\n\nReminds me a bit of Gone Home, but faster paced: with no need to wander around, you can experience the story fragments quicker, and the video segments are well acted.  If I have any complaint, it's that I'd have liked a definitive summary at the end of what happened.  I don't want to put any spoilers here, but there's one or two details that I still wasn't completely clear on.

reviewText:
As you have read, this is not a typical interactive game.  Instead, you figure out stories from video fragments.  It is a hybrid of media, somewhere between a book and TV with game elements.  I feel it worked very well.

The game is short, but that is to its benefit as this is something you will want to play in one sitting.  If you take a break you will may lose some of the various threads of the story you were keeping track of (even if you were taking notes on paper).

There is an option to turn off a lot of the old CRT" effects but the game loses atmosphere that way; still if you find it distracting the option is there.

A minimalist game that relies a lot on the player's imagination and thought

reviewText: This game really sends shivers down your spine. you slowly gain more and more information based on little key words here and there. each of these videos will either compliment or contradict each other. sometimes it seem like you catch her in a lie or others prove what she says. It is really a piece of modern art in its own sense, rather than next gen game mechanics, the whole story relies on your own comprehension of her statements. Very useful to have a note book next to you or use the tag box to write down notes. it really gives you the detective experience. Again this does have a creepy tone, so keep that in mind.

reviewText: After a few hours I got a solid sense of this womans life and the events that have taken place, but I know I can't trust her. Now I need to piece it all together and figure out where the lies are. I'm listening to her life while also trying to piece together her husbands life. I have no idea how this will end (as in, can I get a victory screen? can I solve this case and win"?) but at some point I'm going to make a decision. I'm going to be the detective and the judge.\n\nThe tale is deep and very well written. Within the short clips of video offered (and there must be at least a hundred of them) I get a bunch of leads to chase and each one gives me more of the story
recommended: and still leaves me with empty spaces that I want to fill. It gets darker as I go
hoursPlayed: the words of the dialogue so well chosen that following the leads slowly unravels the story with excellent pacing. It's hard to describe how impressive this is as interactive fiction."

reviewText:
This game is amazing. The only other game I can really compare it to is Analogue: A Hate Story--except Her Story uses video instead of text logs, and you have only your own search strings to guide you through the database.

The story is well-written and haunting, and told in a completely unique way. The game's themes and questions are closely interwoven with your path through the database, even with the most innocuous aspects of the computer interface itself. It's hard to stop mulling over the missing gaps in the interviews and in Hannah's story that will never be filled. The game's fragmented and disordered narrative keeps you from ever getting a sense of completeness, even as you start to piece together the heart of the mystery.

The subtly flickering screen and the pacing of discovering revelations about the story all make this the perfect game to play alone in the dark. Staying up to solve this mystery with my husband late at night, I still got persistent chills.

My only complaint about the game is that the mechanisms controlling your paths through the database can, inevitably, be detected with time. You become tempted to game the system if you can. Then, the first time you finish the game, there's information in the credits that will help you find the remaining available videos. But gathering the last missing pieces this way felt much less exciting.

However, I think that was the whole point--that tantalizing block of videos we didn't manage to access until finishing the game didn't actually reveal anything else about the story. The only information we have is all here. You'll just remain haunted by it long after closing the game: mulling over your remaining questions, trying to piece together the answers.

reviewText:
I first heard of this game from a youtuber. I saw the title, never heard of it before but seeing as i had nothing else to do i started to watch it. I turned it off after 5 minutes. I heard the youtuber describe the concept, i went and checked the reviews on steam and just bought it. The concept to me was awesome and from hearing about it for 5 minutes i realised it could be easil spoiled and i knew i wanted to experience this game for myself.

Her Storyis a really really great game. I've not seen anything like it before. If you have any interest in murder mysteries, shows based around detectives and their cases you'll love this game. You're not told anything about the case you're just thrown this database containing a bunch of clips of this woman and it's up to you to first of all piece together what the case is and then to solve it. What i found made it such a unique experience is that there is no way you can play it without a pen in hand and to be constantly taking notes on things you hear or things that dont sit right with you. I ended having a big board full of character details, timelines, keywords to search for and theories and ideas i had about the case. Never before has a game involved me so much outside of the computer screen.

Pros:
-Unique gameplay
-Involves you outside of the actual game itself
-Makes you come up with theories about the case without ever acknowleding what happens so its up to you when you think you've cracked it
-Complex story (at least what i think the story is) that is left to you to fabricate
-Makes you feel like a badass detective if you make some form of a breakthrough
-Very simple mechanics, you wont waste any time trying to get the hang of things

Cons:
-It was slightly annoying never being able to hear what the interviewer asked, only the womans responses
-Some clips seem to be broken down into very short pointless sentences
-Can't see any replayability value
To be perfectly honest it's tough to come up with many cons. Even with the ones i've chosen, i'm not completely happy with them it's really me nit picking with them. The reason i can't  come up with anymore cons is that i've nothing to compare it to, nothing that done it better or had one mechanic that really helped in playing the game.

Conclusion:
I love this game. Its unique and involves the player way more than any other game i've played. While other games are left to interpretation this whole game is open to interpretation. Whether you find that a bit annoying is completely up to you. Personally i love it. You go through the game coming up with whatever theories you can conjure up that you might think are solid but the next minute can seem ridiculous. Its a great game and definately worth the small price tag. It makes you feel like a proper detective, especially if you get a big notice board and write out everything your thinking.

Great game, really the biggest problem i have is that i cant see how you might replay it, but some games are just like that i guess

9/10

reviewText:
HER STORY. no spoilers.

i bought this game last night off steam and shouldn't have started it last night, because I stayed up an hour and a half longer than I wanted to, and now i'm tired.

in case you're unaware, it's set up like you're at an old computer, looking up police interview videos in a database. you're able to search by keywords (and by words in the transcripts of the videos). it focuses on one actress, being interviewed at different dates and times. you basically have to piece together the entire story from interview clips.

so yeah, it's an entire game about watching video clips, but it's also intriguing (so far, i'm not too far into it). if you play it like an investigator, it's more fun than just typing in random words. i've got an entire evernote notebook dedicated to this game so far, just to try to get a timeline of everything that's happened.

some interesting turns so far. definitely a couple things that made me have to re-listen to old clips (although I might just be a dummy). worth the $5-$6 (if you buy it now it's cheaper) if you think you'd be into that kind of thing. (certainly worth more than the $5 i spent on Thirty Flights of Loving).

reviewText:
Her Story attempts something entirely different than what other games do. It is not a linear narrative, it is a personal one. The reason it is personal is because you are piecing together a theory or story together in your own mind, rather than being told what the narrative is. Few games have done this as well as Her Story.


100% recommend
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText: What a remarkable achievement this game is. It's unlike anything else I've played. You have a simple interface with a search engine for a database of videos which you can view in any order you want, depending on the terms you choose to search. Fragments of the story will add up to complete the picture of what happened and each player will have a different search order and thus a different path to the end. Unusual, short (around three hours for everything) but extremely absorbing. Highly recommended.

I was a bit torn with this. In my opinion its an original enough idea and quite well executed but I think the difficulty curve initially was massive. I literally almost got bored as I was not sure what on earth to do.

I don't think its too much of a spoiler to say that the idea is to work out what has gone on - but I thought I was meant to be cracking a case - really the case is cracked and you are just finding out what happened. I am not sure why the protoganist doesn't just watch the interviews start to finish (like I did after finding them in the steamapps folder) but anyway...

reviewText:
I got this one because I do want to support independent developers, and my wife likes a good mystery.  Why not?  Then I decided to take a quick look and try to see if this might be something she'd really like.

Four hours later I find I'm completely drawn into this story and finding out the mystery, jumping and exclaiming as my own brain and detective work starts to untaggle a brilliant story that is very well acted.

My highest applause!

I now can't wait to sit back and watch as she tries to unravel this one, and hope that same gleam of discovery will come through as it did with me.

reviewText:
Visual Novels have always had a problem connecting with gamers in the west. Since they rely mostly on storytelling and limited interaction, developers have shyed away from crafting them in fear that gamers won't buy their title. Indie developers don't really have this fear, as their games are lower budget and typically cater to a hungry niche.

Her Story sort of fits that mold, but does actually offer a tiny bit of gameplay. By placing the player in the shoes of a detective, you go through clips of some women talking about a supposed murder that has happened. You can't initially tell anything that happened, but listening closely and picking up on repeating themes helps you piece together the puzzle.

As a detective, you go through a database in a faux Windows 3.1 desktop to search for clips. You type keywords into a box and specific videos will come up. You can save them to a timeline, or simply give them new tags for quick access. It feels authentic, even if it is all a simulation.

What is, without a doubt, perfect is the acting. Viva Seifert is wonderful in this game. She plays her role exceptionally well. Nothing ever sounds forced or hammy and her emotional distress can be read perfectly. Seeing as how she is the only human you'll ever see, her delivery had to be great to captivate you.

While the story does get a bit strange, it never feels out of the realm of possibility. Better still, this is basically a more interactive crime drama. If you truly like CSI or NCIS, you'd be right at home with Her Story. Since you spend a lot of time watching clips, it ends up feeling like a serialized broadcast instead of a true video game.

I suppose gamers looking for something with more hands-on activities will be disappointed, but I believe the narrative structure far outweighs what lack of traditional gameplay there is. I'm all for a solid story, so I never really had a problem with this.

The price is also perfect for what this game provides. Where a lot of visual novels fail is in asking someone to part with $20-40 just to experience. Her Story may be a one and done type of media, but at least it is priced less than a movie ticket.

It has a better plotline and acting than most modern films, too. So, honestly, you can't really go wrong. It's solid, novel and very well made. Even the little nostalgic flares don't distract. I'd say take the plunge and see the magic for yourself.

7.5/10

reviewText:
Her Story is an incredibly unique and surprisingly rewarding take on an interactive narrative.

The logic your brain engages itself in while playing this game is something I haven't experienced in anything else. I was taking paper notes as I made links between different clips and the conclusions I was eventually drawn to were really great.

If I were to nominate one game this year as being something that pushed the medium forward, as pretentious as it sounds, it would be this.

reviewText:
This game is creative. I will say, I've never played a game that involved a concept like this one.
However.
Do I feel like it deserves Video Games Story of the Year?
No.
Do I feel like it deserves Video Game voice acting of the Year?
Absolutely not.
It's original. That's about it.
And I knew what was going on in the story after watching two videos.
It's worth playing, I guess.
But not an absolute must.
