reviewText:
I was prepared to dismiss this as the kind of pretentious twaddle that catches jaded game criticâ€™s attention by being both different and short.

I was wrong, so wrong.

I sat down for a quick look at it (after having to fix some issue with videos not playing) and suddenly 4 hours have passed  and Iâ€™m in the spoiler forum comparing my theories to other players.

The game is played (maybe experienced is a better word here) by searching for snippets of police interviews via words and phrases used in them.

So you hop through a database of a couple of hundred videos, following whatever leads you find and piecing together the chain of events.

Its part detection, part voyeurism and part applied google-fu.

When you hit the chronologically last video you get a message asking if you understand now - say yes and the credits roll, you only get the closure you have found yourself - no spoon feeding.

Which is when you hit the forums and discover that the footage supports more than one possible interpretation and a lot of debate.  Then it's back to the game to look as key moments again in the light of other theories.

Her Story is the gaming version of one of those twisty ambiguous short stories that leaves you thinking about it for much longer than reading it took.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I had a lot of fun with Her Story.

The whole idea is to watch clips of a woman's interactions with detectives during multiple sessions of questioning.  I don't want to get into the story because it's an easy thing to ruin unless you go in without any knowledge about what they are investigating, but it's very interesting.  You are going to watch these clips out of order, so everything comes together at different times and things said before will become something else with more context after another clip.

The game play is very simple.  You're screen is that of an old computer with an outdated OS.  A couple .txt files give you an idea where to start.  You must use keywords to not only sift through the videos but to actually find them on the drive.  An example would be to use the word 'the'.  You would expect that to be a good start.  It is, but don't think that's going to be some sort of shortcut.  You only get the top 5 results for each search.  That could be tedious if not for the brilliant dialog that constantly gives you clues as to what new keywords you should research.  I used a notepad and wrote every keyword I'd like to look into down, which kept the ball rolling.

Graphics are not AAA by any means, but they are unique to this era of gaming.  The Full Motion Video almost like that a modern day Sega CD game would be.  The music and sound effects add to the creepy atmosphere without imposing.

And this is not a horror game, but it will feel that way as you dig deeper.  When you come to realize the what you are watching, things really snowball.  Not 'scarey' but chilling.  The ending is very brief and sudden, but it works to further impact how the game has made you feel to that point.

I recommend this game to people that want a short, interesting experience without all the pretension BS that a lot of indie games try to push onto you.

reviewText:
Her Story has an interesting concept where rather unfolding the story from beginning to end like every other medium in the world, it unfolds through recorded videos where you simply type specific tags in the search bar to get the full story.

It's a very interesting game mechanic with a story that twist and turns as you fumble through the search tags, wondering Should I take this at face value or is there just more to the story?"

It's a decent game to experience

reviewText: I absolutely adored each moment spent in this game. At first I was a little confused, and disgruntled at how little explicit direction we are given. I couldn't imagine that a game of searching keywords and watching short vidoes could be so riveting. I was immediately hooked, the story's twists and turns were surprising and I constantly learned that there were deeper and deeper layers to my understanding of the plot. The actress did a superb job of delivering her lines, and when you realize there are  the same stories told exactly the same way twice   you can't help but be incredibly impressed by her performance.\n\nI loved it, and I would recommend playing this game if you like the thrill of unravelling a mystery.

reviewText:
â€œHer Story is the new game from Sam Barlow, creator of Silent Hill: Shattered Memories and Aisle. A woman is interviewed seven times by the police. Search the video database and explore hundreds of authentic clips to discover her story in this groundbreaking narrative game.â€

Thrown straight in at the deep end the game wants you to learn yourself how to play and we kind of like that. Of course we didnâ€™t at first check the Readme doc, i mean who does?

We are going to have to keep this one very short because itâ€™ll be way to easy to give clues, hints and spoilers to the story if we donâ€™t.

GameplayYou are on the hunt through the L.O.G.I.C. database for answers and clues to her story, the story of the women in the videos and what has happened to bring her to the interviews.

Top Tip #1 - Pay close attention to not only what she is saying but everything you can see within each video clip.

StyleItâ€™s styled to feel as if your looking at a PC monitor from the 90s with itâ€™s Rounded Glare and all the UI within the game is feels like a classic OS.

Mini-GameWe took an early break from the main game when we discovered you can play Othello by checking the trash. It wasnâ€™t for long though as we wanted to get right back into the story we were uncovering.

Top Tip #2 - Play in a windowed mode and open Notepad next to the game. Trust us youâ€™ll need it whilst you listen to all the clues and try to understand who all the characters are. We had hundreds of words and phrases by the time we finished the game. It made it a lot easy and probably one of the reasons we solved the whole puzzle.

ActressBrilliant performance from Viva Seifert, she really sells the persona in the videos and makes the unraveling of the story very engrossing. So much so we couldnâ€™t stop playing till we discovered the true secrets hiding within the interview clips.

Read In Full on the Blog[www.dabs.com]

reviewText:
Her Story is an engaging detective experience.

This is not a game, this is a case that needs to be solved. And you are the one digging trough the videos trying to get the clue. At times frustrating, thinking you have it all figured out, but then, you discover a new clue and you're not sure anymore whether you are right or not. It's a roller coaster of empathy. She will mindâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you, without any regret.

8/10 would recommend to anyone that likes playing detective or likes psychological manipulation.

reviewText: An extremely simple concept, yet original and engaging. The idea that computers from the mid-90s were really awful is kinda funny - there's definately a bit of suspension of disbelief that's being asked of you here in that her interviews are hopelessly garbled and there's no record of the complete tapes (why were they ever cut up this way to begin with?) ... but then again, stranger things have happened with computers.  Anyway, the gameplay mechanic is fun, and this game pulled me in in ways most games don't.  Absolutely worth your time and money.

reviewText:
Her Story has an interesting concept where rather unfolding the story from beginning to end like every other medium in the world, it unfolds through recorded videos where you simply type specific tags in the search bar to get the full story.

It's a very interesting game mechanic with a story that twist and turns as you fumble through the search tags, wondering Should I take this at face value or is there just more to the story?"

It's a decent game to experience

reviewText: In 'Her Story' you get access to a police database full of archive interviews with a murder suspect. There are a few clips to get started, but then it's up to you to unravel the rest of the story using keywords. You can use ones you hear in the videos, or try some that make sense. The story's a bit farfetched at times, but it's fun to piece everything together. Actress Viva Seifert does a really good job as Hannah. There's also a 'gotta catch 'em all' aspect to this game, where you just want to watch every clip available, to make sure you get the full picture.

reviewText: Her Story is a throwback to the full motion video games of the 1990s and an experiment in narrative game design. You are an investigator trying to piece together what happened based on video fragments from police interviews. The game's sole mechanic is a database which you use by searching for words said in over 200 video clips. How you interpret the story is up to you and the truth" turns out to be not as simple as it seems when several twists emerge. The narrative is presented in a completely non-linear fashion (although you can attempt to put the videos in chronological order) and it doesn't have a clear-cut ending. If a straightforward story is what you want then you may not find it here. The game left me thinking even after having seen all of the footage."
voteText: 16 of 35 people (46%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
If Gone Home made you mad, you will probably find a reason to be mad at this. Maybe not.

A simple mechanic; enter a search term then watch a woman answer questions about the murder of her husband in various police station settings: Her Story is an interesting take on a way to explore and reveal facts about an intriguing mystery.

At the very end, you're asked if you understand what has happened. You're not judged to have succeeded or failed, whatever your response, and that's not really the point of this game. You're free to draw your own conclusions, based on the facts you've revealed; the fun in the game comes from the way it unfolds itself to you, and it does this very well indeed.

If you get bored, you can always play the reversi-like mirror game hidden in the recycle bin.

I played this through twice; the first time I played it as intended, and the second time I cheated somewhat to be able to view all the videos in-game. If I hadn't already played the game to its 'conclusion' the first time, I would have missed everything that is absorbing and entertaining about it, so don't make the mistake some people have, or you'll ruin everything for yourself.

This is a Good Game, and well worth $5. Play it.

reviewText:
This game is so great! Though it was a little short, I expected it in all honesty but I Know that some people want more for their money (even though I think the price is fine). So if you don't think the price is worth about 2 hours, then wait for a sale, but if you like immersive stories then you won't be dissapointed!

The acting is really good in my opinion and the way that you unravel the story is very unique. Everyone will takle it differently and they will uncover aspects at different times, it means that each persons experience is solely their own.

I do wish this game were longer, personally. Not the same story because I think that the amount on that one was enough. I just love the idea of going through old interview tapes to uncover a mystery! If another game like this is made, having a bunch of cases would make this even better.

If you are a person who loves these games which tell a story in a new and interesting way then you should pick this up! While the story certainly has twist and turns, which I didn't initially see coming but once you get them and watch earlier clips it fleshes out so much! Attention to detail is just all over this game. Pretty much if you think it looks interesting then you should pick it up!

reviewText: I'd like to start this review by saying that this game is not even remotely close to what I expected it to be. Yes, I knew it was a murder/suspense type of game where you watch videos to find out clues. Yes, I knew that it would probably take a while to complete. However, while the videos started off pretty much repeating one another, after a few minutes they got interesting. There were plot twists and events that took me by surprise, so that surprised me, since I'm the type of person to guess the plot line before I even get any major clues. I don't want to say much, in case I spoil something for those who haven't played it yet, but I definetely reccomend it to those who have spare time on their hands and those who are patient, for you will most likely need it. I would rate this game an 8/10. It's not my favorite game out there, but it's pretty damn good.

reviewText:
For starters:  this is not a game by most standard definitions.  It can even be argued Gone Home is more of a game than Her Story.  You interact with an emulated desktop and type words into a search toolbar to access interrogation videos in an evidence database.

However, the storytelling method is beyond compelling.  You stumble upon facts and details out of order, but the struggle to flesh out the meat and potatoes of the plot due to the nature of the system in place will keep you searching for every single video.

If you manage to get every video unlocked" in under two hours
date: I implore you to not troll the refund system and hang on to it.  The dev deserves to be compensated for such an intriguing platform
recommended: and this is yet another title I wish I had thought of doing first because the novelty is really fresh.\n\nSidenote:  it gets annoying at times

reviewText:
I'm not sure why I purchased Her Story. When I saw the screenshots at the front of my Discovery Queue, I thought it was a film and was prepared to remove it with prejudice. I was surprised to discover that it was a game, although it had FMV, which is often more frustrating than nostalgic. Still, it was a detective game made by the creator of a Silent Hill game, so why not give it a try?

I loaded the game up, and was immediately confused. The focus on interrogation had reminded me of LA Noire, so I expected to be playing a game where the object was to determine a subject's guilt or innocence, whether they were lying or being truthful. This was not the game I found. In truth, it was something more like Papers, Please or Please Don't Touch Anything -- a game where you repeat the same action, with slight variations, over and over to try and dig up new results.

What results is a story unfolding in a mosaic style, determined as much by the player as by the director. This is a fascinating piece of fiction, a game that left me every bit as unsettled as a Silent Hill game, but for completely different reasons. I won't spoil any of the details, but I will say this is a tremendous game with a solid amount of replayability.

reviewText: My playtime being sclightly skewed from leaving the game running, my time with Her Story was well spent and I wouldn't trade it. Even some of the time away from the game was used to read my case notes in an attempt to piece together what I had learned. Multiple times, I looked up from a note I was making while watching an interview with an eyebrow raised over what I had just learned.\nI highly recommend this to anyone interested in piecing together a fragmented story in which you start with one piece of information and find out you're missing a hundred more. I was an hour or so in before I even learned the woman's name.    Also, Viva Seifert does a wonderful job sitting in front of a camera and somehow engaing the player by answeriing the questions of an unseen and unheard detective.

reviewText:
Her Story harkens back to the old days of FMV video games and pits you against a search bar and shed loads of unorganzised video evidence regarding a murder investigation; all involving one woman.

This is defineltey not for the COD players; it's a slow, mysterious detective game told entirley through a computer screen; and not before long will you be rummaging through your cupboards for a notepad and pen in haste to jot down what scraps of information you find.  Despite its short play time and lack of a conventional ending; the story is a very captivating and intriguing tale down the rabbit hole seeking the truth. It's low price tag is also an incentive that everyone should be giving into. If you're into your detective games,FMV games or just up for something new; please pick up Her Story; you won't regret it.

Props also goes to Viva Seifert for being the real crutch for the game, if her performace was not as strong as it is, this game would literally fall apart. So thank goodness for that. I want more of this. GIMME MORE!!!!!

reviewText: This only took a couple hours to beat, but it was really immersive and made me want to drop everything else so I could solve the puzzle. I love the story, the acting, and the whole feel of the game. The premise is easy and familiar yet somehow feels exciting and creative. I do wish there had been a few more roadblocks or red herrings. It seems like you could easily get lucky on a random search word and spoil the whole thing for yourself after just a minute or two. Overall I had a lot of fun, but I'm not sure it's worth $5. Maybe if you pace yourself better than I did then it could last you a weekend.

reviewText:
The best FMV game that I have played, and probably the best game that I have played this year.

Her Story is a new breed of narrative video game where your goal is to piece together the story behind the suspected murder of a woman's husband in 1994 based on her interviews with police over 7 days. These interviews are broken into 271 segments, ranging anywhere from 1 second to 2 minutes in length. You access these interviews by searching a police database. However, not all of the 271 segments are accessible at once - you can only access them by searching the database for keywords. This leads to a unique storytelling experience, told piece by piece as you discover new keywords to search from every video. Piecing the story together is one of the most satisfying experiences I have had in a video game, and I won't spoil it by going into any more detail here.

Her Story is worth playing if you enjoyed the podcast Serial, the show The Jinx, detective/crime stories generally, and are interested in trying a new form of video game storytelling. It should only take 2-3 hours to complete, though the experience will stay with you long after you finish the game, and is definitely worth the $6 admission price.

Recommended.

reviewText:
Uncover Her Story in this simple yet clever FMV game.

PROS:
+ Fair price
+ Nonlinear game
+ Clever, thoughtful writing
+ Fascinating femme fatale protagonist
+ Minimalistic yet immersive presentation
+ Viva Seifert's subtle, realistic performance
+ Successful recreation of 90's computer interface
+ Interesting blend of of FMV clips and text-based gameplay

CONS:
- Unclear end goal
- Inconclusive ending
- Not very challenging

reviewText: I think people are so desperate for something new and different that they are falling all over themselves for this game" that really is just a bunch of videos thrown together.  If you type the right word you will reveal the plot twist in a couple minutes and then be bored for 3 pointless hours.  The developer really went the lazy route and did not try to develop the story or put together a coherent mystery.  They did not bother to bring the story to any conclusion.  The "come to your own conclusion" approach is used to hide the developer's inability to write a complete story.  The numerous Yes/No scenes in the game are proof of how truly poor this project was planned and executed.  I believe the developer probably wrote an ending to this game
date: but it was such crap that they scrapped it in favor of attempting an artsy open ended conclusion.  They failed and should never do anything more creative than working at Starbucks for the rest of their lives.\n\nThis would be a waste of money at any price."

reviewText:
There isn't very much to this as a game; Using carefully worded searches, you discover clips in a non-linear order, and attempt to discover from each clip enough info to put you onto the path to the next.

When you start, the unwatched clips will be discovered easily enough. But eventually, you will find that you need to start being very imaginitive with your searches when attempting to find unwatched sequences.

For those who haven't been dissuaded by this, you will get to experience a new way of discovering a story through an interactive game medium. Yes, there will be a lot of watching footage, but I found it interesting the way that your perceived viewpoint could radically alter depending on what footage you watched, and the order you viewed it.

This definitely won't be for everyone, but for those willing to give it a shot, you should find it to be a very enjoyable and interactive experience nonetheless. Recommended.

reviewText: Her Story shines in the little things, its moment-to-moment drama and suprises consistently on point. It's definitely the best game of it's type I have seen and played so far. Great job, I want more.

reviewText:
The developer Sam Barlow said LA Noire didn't make him feel much like a detective, Phoenix Wright did a better job but still was too rigid for his taste. So he made this game.


It is a non linear detective murder mystery in which you try to understand a case that lies 20 years in the past.
Your tool of investigation is a computer with a database of tapes, FMV clips of an actress interviewed by the police.
All are a couple of seconds long and indexed (and searcheable) by keywords and phrases.
So if our mysterious lady said the word murder" in one of the tapes and you type it into your searchfield
date: you'll find up to 5 videos in which she said that word. You can look for the word "the" and get 5 hits
recommended:
this is a bit weird to me but in the end it can be helpful if you're stuck or out of keywords to search for.
After a couple of minutes I was starting to write down notes via pen and paper and found myself already pretty deep in the mystery.
And that is how you play the whole game.


The actress Viva Seifert delivers a great and deep performance. Sometimes you watch a clip and think: 'Hmm
hoursPlayed: this is weird...'
voteText: and 2 hours later
helpfulPercent: with new information at hand
votesHelpful: you realize that the thing you thought was weird now totally makes sense. It's just an odd experience
votesTotal: and I liked that.\nLet's be honest
votesFunny:
the human brain wants to order and structure everything it gets it's "hands" on and that's exactly what makes the game apealing.
That and that little bit of voyeurism we all have inside us and can safely endulge in here.

The games big quality (nonlinearity) can also be it's downfall: If you're searching for certain words that might spoil the whole mystery for you in the first 20 minutes you won't get as much out of the rest of the clips.
I knew a little too much for my own good in the first half an hour
commentsCount: I feel. But it was still fun until the end.\nHow do you end a game like this

mostly like you played it.

reviewText: Her Story is a great game. Aside from getting completely stuck after a while, searching through the database of clips was really addicting. You slowly start to notice things about the separate interviews and the way she talks; the plot twists build up over time, then you realize them all at once.\n\nAbout getting stuck: some of the clips are just plain unfair to have to find. It's not like they contain crazy plot twists or anything, but it is annoying if you're trying to find all of them. Overall, though, great game!
voteText: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An interactive story game where you're not in control of the events, but instead are trying to piece them together. You're presented with a very spartan, pseudo Windows 3.1 interface that accepts only keyword queries. The database you're searching through is a collection of old police interrogation tape snippets covering a single case and a single woman. If your keyword is mentioned in a snippet, you can watch it.

All the archived clips are quite short, ranging from five seconds to just over a minute. A name or a thing mentioned in one part leads to another, that one to yet another and so on. This is quite an intriguing (and challenging) way to tell a story, and I have to say that I throroughly enjoyed chasing the tiniest of hints while slowly coming into a realization about the big picture.

Talking about the story itself isn't really fruitful since everyone should experience it on their own and in their own way. Suffice to say that the tale is satisfying enough, although not any kind of an instant classic or the best thing ever. I personally found the story even a bit implausible by the end when everything clicked into place, but not overtly so.

Overall, a story well worth experiencing, told in a way that has rarely, if ever, been seen before.
voteText: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First of all beware for people who expect gameplay: There practically is none, all you do is operate a database search engine to look through video interview/interrogation snippets. You pay attention to those and search the database for keywords that stood out. This way the game reveals a really well written story.

The actress in this 'game' does a really good job and the unraveling of what happened it's exciting.

The best way to describe the experience is: Think Memento. Except the timeline is even more all over the place.

I'd say it's worth a buy if you are in it for the story telling experience. If you want a mechanically good game this is not for you.

reviewText: This game is superb. Teasing the truth from the snippets of video - it boils down to a logic game - it reminded me strongly of hexcells with regards to the deductive reasoning needed. A strange comparison, maybe, but the structure is similar, working out what's what based on what you hear, and then as the picture fills out, you search for more words, isolating the specific detail that you want to nail down; you're able to answer more questions. Very engrossing. Be prepared to take pages of notes!\n\nUnusually for a game, there's no definitive 'end point' - you will work out whodunnit before you know all the details - whether you want to find out exactly what happened is down to you.

reviewText: An impressively immersive, narrative-driven game. It's small, warranting the price; but does a good job peeling away at a greater story through your search inputs.\n\nIf you enjoyed Digital: A Love Story"

reviewText:
Just like you're sitting behind your computer now, you will be sat down behind one in-game. No hand-holding and just a little read me file explaining how the database search engine works. No mission, no tutorial. It's really up to you to just start browsing clips and use your brain.
That's the greatest thing about Her Story. You're not using a character's abilities to solve a mystery, but your own insight and deductive skills. Because of that, the payoff is awesome. You really feel like you are the one that solved a tiny part of the mystery. Both the eureka moments and the goosebumps will be of your own making.

To be able to enjoy the game properly players really need a good English vocabulary. The in-game search engine is your main instrument and misspelling words will not give any results. Arguably, some in-game mechanics could be more user friendly, although keeping in mind that it's a Windows 95 computer running VHS clips, maybe it's more fitting to have to write things down on paper now and then.

Conlclusion: buy the game (it's very cheap), grab a cup of coffee, put on your 'detective working late at night face' and dive into this game. It's a testament to the possibilities of video game storytelling.

reviewText:
Grab a pad and pencil, watch some videos, and try to think of every keyword you could possibly search the database for. This is a really fascinating means of storytelling and a type of mystery game that I have never experienced before. Generally, I really dislike mystery games with their dependence on your character walking around and you having to click on tiny items to find the clues.

Her Story is nothing like that. I find the interface oddly compelling and I feel like the FMV clips work exceptionally well. I'm very impressed and pleased with this game.

There are a few tiny things that I would like to see changed with the UI to make accessing videos a little easier and Session sorting/editing a bit cleaner. But, overall I'm really enjoying Her Story and suggest you check it out.
voteText: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
LIke trying to piece together a narrative from bits and clips of things out of sequence? Enjoy solving mysteries? Dig well executed and compelling FMV? Then this is probably a great game for you.

Yes, it is only a few hours long, but it's worth the $5 or so. The acting is good, the writing and plot are solid.

My only gripes are that it's sometimes hard to hit on an exact keyword. Getting 100% is incredibly difficult, and I won't like, I hit up the folder containing the files to find the last two, and even having the dialogue I had a difficult time getting one or two things to filter to the surface.

Don't let that detract from this though, I had already solved it and you will too prior to getting 100% of the videos.

All told, I hope the team takes this formula forward and gives us another game like this down the road.
voteText: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
fantastic. it's such a simple and well-realized idea that it's shocking that no one really utilized it before.

the setup is deceptively simple - you have access to a database of archive footage of various conversations with a certain woman who called in that her husband is missing. all you do is watch videos, tag them and look for more footage by searching various keywords, so you can figure out what's going on and piece the story together.

so basically: detective work.

and it works brilliantly - one thing leads to another, you start pulling away at the different threads emerging from various videos, trying to unravel the plot. I got hooked immediately. it's basically watching a proper, well-written crime film or TV show, only instead of passively trying to anticipate the plot, you are trying to solve it.

beyond the mechanics, the story is simply good. it's a proper tale of a crime, with believable red herrings, plot twists and motivations, but also one grounded in some sort of reality. and Viva Seifert absolutely carries the show - she's great and manages to craft a believable, multifaceted character, a feat even more impressive when you consider the fact that she has no one to bounce back her lines from.

it's great and my only real complaints can be that 1. there's not more of this and 2. I kinda wish you could at least create a literal corkboard of various connections, timelines and threads inside of the game. working with a pen and paper made for a fun experience, but I wonder if having that in the game proper wouldn't make it even more immersive.

anyway, awesome. get it. it's dirt cheap and one of the most interesting things to come out in recent years.

reviewText: An experimental game in a sense. But, what makes this game such a gem is its simplicity. No gamey power ups or high scores. Just simple mechanics and story melding together perfectly to make a good detective experience. This game makes you think. Well, not really in a numbers and CSI kind of way. But, to connect the dots through listening and observation. Because, based on that the story unfolds in a personal way that is unique to your understanding even though it tells a linear and singular tale. The game is not groundbreaking storywise, but by execution. It's rare to see linear narrative in a game unfold based on player choice in a nonlinear fashion with such clarity. The only other game I have played that did the same in flying colors is Gone Home.

reviewText:
It is an interesting concept and should be played to encourage the creativity in PC gaming.

I have finished the game and can't tell a lot without spoiling it. There are a few points you should be aware of:

1) You don't need to watch all of the clips (I did watch all of them, so I am sure of that :) ) to finish the game.
2) You probably cannot access all of the clips by keywords (some clips contain only  the word yes" or "no" and with the 5 video limit you won't be able to reach them). I had to cheat (you'll learn how when you finish the game) to view them.
3) Don't expect a message like "Congratulations
date: you have solved the case!" There isn't a case to solve
recommended: you are just watching old videos.\n4) I don't see any replayability value at all. This is a 3-4 hour affair and then you are done.\n"

reviewText:
I've never written a Steam review, but Her Story is just too gripping.

If you like narrative games that don't have traditional gameplay (e.g. Gone Home), you'll probably like this. The acting is great, the directing good. The story leans a little heavily on symbolism and the premise seems a little far fetched, but it totally works. The way the story is paced while still allowing you total freedom to access any clips in any order (IF you know what questions to ask) is nothing short of brilliant. I elaborated a bit on the design here[www.goldenkronehotel.com].

Anyway, I think something is fundamentally broken when Steam shows 30% of the negative reviews (out of only 13) on the front page, but only a single positive review is promoted (out of 343 of them). Some of the negative reviewers promoted clearly haven't even beaten the game. Ugh.

reviewText:
Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Lovely piece of work. Totally recommened.

The game gets immediately intriguing in the first few minutes when you start it. And the story expands and gradually reveals itself as you keep on searching and browsing each clip.
The progress of finishing the game is like resolving a jigsaw puzzle. Finding each piece of the puzzle and putting it in the right place can be very much rewarding.
I haven't gone through 100% yet but I can tell what the picture is about. I actually used a pen and a piece of paper to jot things down. I have to say I haven't been so intrigued since L.A. Noire and To the Moon. : P
And I actually googled and learned tap code.

Ignorant buyers beware. This is an indie game.
Sure the game might not be best plotted, and the acting could be better, but I believe it should be enjoyed well enough. It gives an experience and it lasts long.

The reflection of myself on the monitor screen scared the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of me.

Might update this review sometime later.

ps: a useful tip - during each video clip, you can click the mouse to reveal the progress bar and rewind/fastforward the video as you wish by dragging it. Just for the people who are not too bright like me : P
pps: Delete Session Date will erase your search history AND totally restart your game from the beginning. So it's simply a reset button. Be careful about this.

reviewText:
This game is going to stay with me a long time. The story is compelling, well written and well acted, and the atmosphere evoked by the subject and the interface is second to none.

Some parts of the game are clunky, obscure and frustrating - but I'd argue this adds to the experience. Your tools are imperfect, just like your eventual understanding of what happened and why. You're struggling to dredge up a fragmentary story which is obscured by the interview format, the complex relationships between characters and the inability to sequentially access clips. This is important - you're never going to be 100% certain. You only need to prove to yourself that you made your best effort to understand the stories, actions and motivations of people you only really know from a set of 20 year old video clips.

Play for as long as you like but your mind will be turning over what you learned - or what you thought you learned - for a long time afterwards. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/sqiKWNXgYJQ

Her Story is a very unusual in that it's a full motion video game that was released in 2015. Don't worry, the FMV aspect of this game works really well, it's totally not cheesy and the actress in the game does a fairly decent job selling her performance. After you complete this game, it's hard to imagine Her Story not being a FMV game, I'm not sure it would have worked any other way. Her Story was made independently by Sam Barlow, who was previously the writer and designer of both Silent Hill Origins and Silent Hill Shattered Memories. This game, if you can even call it a game, shares a lot of the interesting ideas and creativity found in those Silent Hill titles

The premise of Her Story is that you are digging through a corrupted database of video interviews from a murder case in the early nineties. The database has been corrupted and fragmented, so you can't watch the interview clips in chronological order, but each video clip has been completely text transcribed, so you can search each clip by any word that occurs in the clip. So for instance, if you search murder"
date: all of the video clips that contain the word "murder" are returned to you. The other catch is that you can only see the first 5 results that are returned to you
recommended: so you'll quickly learn to be clever with your searches.\n\nThe story opens up pretty quickly
hoursPlayed: giving you some names of important characters or important events to search

reviewText:
Her Story is unlike any other detective game Iâ€™ve ever played â€“ and Iâ€™ve played quite a few mystery/detective games in my time. This unusual title was created by Sam Barlow (who also created Silent Hill: Shattered Memories), a veteran of the game design world and mastermind of suspense and beautifully told stories.

Throughout the game, your objective is to discover what happened to Simon Smith, Hannah Smithâ€™s (a protagonistâ€™s) husband. The player is presented with a police database full of video clips, none of which are in order though I donâ€™t think this actually has any bearing on whether or not you complete the game successfully.

Read my full review at: http://www.pcgamergirl.com/2015/review-her-story/
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Her Story is both a game and an experience. It's a captivating story that stems from brilliant writing and unconventional gameplay. It's gaming as a medium for storytelling at its finest.

The moment I started Her Story and was presented with a simulated PC desktop, complete with the flourescent glare of ceiling lights on the screen, I felt a strange mixture of comfortable familiarity and foreboding. Maybe it's an odd comparison, but I felt the same way when I started Papers, Please, another indie gem that skirts convention and turns the seemingly mundane into the immensely interesting. Who would have thought that doing paperwork and researching video footage could be so damn entertaining?

Her Story's writer/director, Sam Barlow, worked as lead designer and writer on Silent Hill: Origins and Silent Hill: Shattered Memories as well as the pioneering one-move indie gem Aisle. Her Story feels slightly like all of the above in its conceptualization and innovativeness, but for me it made more of an impact. This game is Barlow's magnum opus, despite its humble length and presentation. It's a case of beauty in simplicity, and I look forward to more from Barlow. I'm hoping he takes Her Story's concept and format and builds upon them, creating something even more masterful, because the potential definitely exists.

For me, a good indication that any piece of entertainment has been worthwhile is when it stays with me for a long time. For that reason, I like to give things a chance to simmer in my mind for at least a few days before forming a solid opinion. It's been that long since I played Her Story, and not only am I still thinking about it daily, but I also want to tell everyone I can to play it. So, play it.

reviewText: A really interesting piece of interactive fiction. It tells an immensely compelling story. What's so cool is that the narrative unfolds differently for each player. It's another game that I can't really say too much about for fear of spoilers.\nIf you enjoy mysteries or detective games then rest assured, you'll enjoy this one very much. 10/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The Good: The process of gathering the interview snippets and piecing the various narrative threads together has been my favorite gaming experience of the year, so far. Granted, there are very few ludic restraints here, so it really does feel  more like interactive fiction than a game. But honestly, when the whole thing feels so compelling, that seems like a petty concern.

A lot of the credit goes to actress Viva Seifert. Her nuanced performances made the gimmicky testimonal format into a viable medium for the disjointed crime narrative.

The Bad: If the actual plot were in a different format -- say a prose story or a feature-length movie -- it would be a boilerplate crime thriller. The more psychological elements would feel like hackneyed cliches. Thankfully, the medium not only hides these flaws, but turns them into a source of potential mindf*ckery and player speculation.

The Ugly: After my first near-complete playthrough, I may have spent/lost/wasted as much time researching fan theories as I did actually playing the game. There's proverbial wheat out there, for sure, but you have to sift through a lot of chaff to find it.

Of course, none of that is really the dev's fault. And it can only help strengthen the game's value as a cultural product.
